   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Serbia</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="contentSub2"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a> 
    <div id="mw-content-text" lang="en" dir="ltr" class="mw-content-ltr">
     <div class="mw-parser-output"> 
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       Country in the Balkans
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       "Republic of Serbia" redirects here. It is not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Republika_Srpska" title="Republika Srpska">Republika Srpska</a>. For other uses, see <a href="/wiki/Serbia_(disambiguation)" class="mw-disambig" title="Serbia (disambiguation)">Serbia (disambiguation)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serb_Republic_(disambiguation)" class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" title="Serb Republic (disambiguation)">Serb Republic (disambiguation)</a>.
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Not to be confused with <a href="/wiki/Siberia" title="Siberia">Siberia</a>.
      </div> 
      <p> <span style="font-size: small;"><span id="coordinates"><a href="/wiki/Geographic_coordinate_system" title="Geographic coordinate system">Coordinates</a>: <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r994658806">.mw-parser-output .geo-default,.mw-parser-output .geo-dms,.mw-parser-output .geo-dec{display:inline}.mw-parser-output .geo-nondefault,.mw-parser-output .geo-multi-punct{display:none}.mw-parser-output .longitude,.mw-parser-output .latitude{white-space:nowrap}</style><span class="plainlinks nourlexpansion"><a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//geohack.toolforge.org/geohack.php?pagename=Serbia&amp;params=44_N_21_E_"><span class="geo-default"><span class="geo-dms" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location"><span class="latitude">44°N</span> <span class="longitude">21°E</span></span></span><span class="geo-multi-punct">﻿ / ﻿</span><span class="geo-nondefault"><span class="geo-dec" title="Maps, aerial photos, and other data for this location">44°N 21°E</span><span style="display:none">﻿ / <span class="geo">44; 21</span></span></span></a></span></span></span> </p>

        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center">
          <div style="text-align:left;margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto;">
           <ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha; margin-left: 1em;"> 
            <li value="1">Kosovo is the subject of a territorial dispute between Kosovo and Serbia. Kosovo <a href="/wiki/2008_Kosovo_declaration_of_independence" title="2008 Kosovo declaration of independence">unilaterally declared independence</a> in 2008 while Serbia continues to claim it as part of its <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Province_of_Kosovo_and_Metohija" title="Autonomous Province of Kosovo and Metohija">own sovereign territory</a>. Kosovo is currently recognized as an independent state by 98 out of the 193 United Nations member states.</li> 
           </ol>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Serbia</b> (<a href="/wiki/Serbian_language" title="Serbian language">Serbian</a>: <span lang="sr">Србија</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Serbian" title="Romanization of Serbian">romanized</a>:&nbsp;</small><i lang="sr-Latn" title="Serbian-language romanization">Srbija</i>, <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian" title="Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian">[sř̩bija]</a></span>),<sup id="cite_ref-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-6">[note 1]</a></sup> officially the <b>Republic of Serbia</b> (<a href="/wiki/Serbian_language" title="Serbian language">Serbian</a>: <span lang="sr">Република Србија</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Serbian" title="Romanization of Serbian">romanized</a>:&nbsp;</small><i lang="sr-Latn" title="Serbian-language romanization">Republika Srbija</i>, <small>pronounced&nbsp;</small><span title="Representation in the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)" class="IPA"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian" title="Help:IPA/Serbo-Croatian">[repǔblika sř̩bija]</a></span>), is a <a href="/wiki/Landlocked_country" title="Landlocked country">landlocked country</a> situated at the crossroads of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central</a><sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[6]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Europe" title="Southeast Europe">Southeast Europe</a> in the southern <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Plain" class="mw-redirect" title="Pannonian Plain">Pannonian Plain</a> and the central <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Lidia_Razowska-Jaworek,_CRC_Press_8-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Lidia_Razowska-Jaworek,_CRC_Press-8">[7]</a></sup> It borders <a href="/wiki/Hungary" title="Hungary">Hungary</a> to the north, <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a> to the northeast, <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a> to the southeast, <a href="/wiki/North_Macedonia" title="North Macedonia">North Macedonia</a> to the south, <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> to the west, and <a href="/wiki/Montenegro" title="Montenegro">Montenegro</a> to the southwest. The country claims a border with <a href="/wiki/Albania" title="Albania">Albania</a> through the <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Kosovo" title="Political status of Kosovo">disputed</a> territory of <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Kosovo_9-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kosovo-9">[note 2]</a></sup> Serbia's population numbers approximately seven million.<sup id="cite_ref-auto_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto-10">[8]</a></sup> Its capital, <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a>, ranks among the largest and oldest citiеs in <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Europe">southeastern Europe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Vahid_Razavi_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vahid_Razavi-11">[9]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Continuously inhabited since the <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic_age" class="mw-redirect" title="Paleolithic age">Paleolithic Age</a>, the territory of modern-day Serbia faced <a href="/wiki/Slavic_migrations" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic migrations">Slavic migrations</a> to <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern Europe</a> in the 6th century, establishing several regional <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia_(early_medieval)" title="Principality of Serbia (early medieval)">states</a> in the early Middle Ages at times recognised as tributaries to the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Frankish_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Frankish Empire">Frankish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Hungary" class="mw-redirect" title="Royal Hungary">Hungarian</a> kingdoms. The <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia_(medieval)" title="Kingdom of Serbia (medieval)">Serbian Kingdom</a> obtained recognition by the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a> and <a href="/wiki/Constantinople" title="Constantinople">Constantinople</a> in 1217, reaching its territorial apex in 1346 as the relatively short-lived <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Empire" title="Serbian Empire">Serbian Empire</a>. By the mid-16th century, the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Turks" title="Ottoman Turks">Ottomans</a> annexed the entirety of modern-day Serbia; their rule was <a href="/wiki/Ottoman%E2%80%93Habsburg_wars" title="Ottoman–Habsburg wars">at times interrupted</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Empire</a>, which began expanding towards <a href="/wiki/Central_Serbia" title="Central Serbia">Central Serbia</a> from the end of the 17th century while maintaining a foothold in <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a>. In the early 19th century, the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Revolution" title="Serbian Revolution">Serbian Revolution</a> established the <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia" title="Principality of Serbia">nation-state</a> as the region's first <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_monarchy" title="Constitutional monarchy">constitutional monarchy</a>, which subsequently expanded its territory.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[10]</a></sup> Following disastrous casualties in <a href="/wiki/World_War_I" title="World War I">World War I</a>, and the subsequent unification of the <a href="/wiki/Voivodeship_of_Serbia_and_Banat_of_Temeschwar" title="Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar">former Habsburg crownland of Vojvodina</a> (and other lands) with <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a>, the country co-founded <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbs,_Croats_and_Slovenes" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes">Yugoslavia</a> with other South Slavic nations, which would exist in various political formations until the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars" title="Yugoslav Wars">Yugoslav Wars</a> of the 1990s. During the <a href="/wiki/Breakup_of_Yugoslavia" title="Breakup of Yugoslavia">breakup of Yugoslavia</a>, Serbia formed a <a href="/wiki/Serbia_and_Montenegro" title="Serbia and Montenegro">union with Montenegro</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-SCGSuccession_13-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCGSuccession-13">[11]</a></sup> which was peacefully dissolved in 2006, restoring Serbia's independence as a sovereign state for the first time since 1918.<sup id="cite_ref-EBRD_Country_Promotion_Programme_14-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EBRD_Country_Promotion_Programme-14">[12]</a></sup> In 2008, the parliament of the province of <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> unilaterally <a href="/wiki/2008_Kosovo_declaration_of_independence" title="2008 Kosovo declaration of independence">declared independence</a>, with mixed responses from the international community. </p>
      <p>A <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary</a> <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_system" title="Parliamentary system">parliamentary</a> <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_republic" class="mw-redirect" title="Constitutional republic">constitutional republic</a>, Serbia is a member of the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations" title="United Nations">UN</a>, <a href="/wiki/Council_of_Europe" title="Council of Europe">CoE</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">OSCE</a>, <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">PfP</a>, <a href="/wiki/Organization_of_the_Black_Sea_Economic_Cooperation" title="Organization of the Black Sea Economic Cooperation">BSEC</a>, <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Central European Free Trade Agreement">CEFTA</a>, and is acceding to the <a href="/wiki/World_Trade_Organization" title="World Trade Organization">WTO</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WTO_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTO-15">[13]</a></sup> Since 2014, the country has been negotiating <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Serbia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Serbia to the European Union">its EU accession</a>, with the aim of joining the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> by 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-European_Commission_2018_16-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-European_Commission_2018-16">[14]</a></sup> Serbia has been formally adhering to the policy of military <a href="/wiki/Neutral_country" title="Neutral country">neutrality</a>. The country provides <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Serbia" title="Healthcare in Serbia">universal health care</a> and free <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Serbia" title="Education in Serbia">primary and secondary education</a> to its citizens. An upper-middle-income economy with a dominant service sector, the country has been ranked 64th on the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Human_Development_Index" title="List of countries by Human Development Index">Human Development Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Serbia:_On_the_Way_to_EU_Accession_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serbia:_On_the_Way_to_EU_Accession-17">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[16]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div id="toc" class="toc" role="navigation" aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading">
       <input type="checkbox" role="button" id="toctogglecheckbox" class="toctogglecheckbox" style="display:none">

      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Names_of_the_Serbs_and_Serbia" title="Names of the Serbs and Serbia">Names of the Serbs and Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Origin_hypotheses_of_the_Serbs" title="Origin hypotheses of the Serbs">Origin hypotheses of the Serbs</a>
      </div> 
      <p>There exist two prevailing theories on the origin of the ethnonym <i>*Sŕbъ</i> (plur. <i>*Sŕby</i>), one from a <a href="/wiki/Proto-Slavic_language" title="Proto-Slavic language">Proto-Slavic language</a> with an appellative meaning of a "family kinship" and "alliance", while another from an <a href="/wiki/Scythian_languages" title="Scythian languages">Iranian-Sarmatian language</a> with various meanings.<sup id="cite_ref-Łuczyński_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Łuczyński-19">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Rudnicki1959_20-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rudnicki1959-20">[18]</a></sup> In his work, <i><a href="/wiki/De_Administrando_Imperio" title="De Administrando Imperio">De Administrando Imperio</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Constantine_VII_Porphyrogenitus" class="mw-redirect" title="Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus">Constantine VII Porphyrogenitus</a> suggests that the Serbs originated from <a href="/wiki/White_Serbia" title="White Serbia">White Serbia</a> near <a href="/wiki/Francia" title="Francia">Francia</a>. According to the recorded tradition the <a href="/wiki/Sorbs_(tribe)" title="Sorbs (tribe)">White Serbs</a> split in two, with the half that became known as the Serbs coming down to settle Byzantine land. From 1945 to 1963, the official name for Serbia was the People's Republic of Serbia, later renamed the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Serbia" title="Socialist Republic of Serbia">Socialist Republic of Serbia</a> from 1963 to 1990. Since 1990, the official name of the country has been the Republic of Serbia. </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Serbia" title="History of Serbia">History of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Further information: <a href="/wiki/Timeline_of_Serbian_history" title="Timeline of Serbian history">Timeline of Serbian history</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Prehistory_and_antiquity">Prehistory and antiquity</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_sites_in_Serbia" title="Prehistoric sites in Serbia">Prehistoric sites in Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbia_in_the_Roman_era" title="Serbia in the Roman era">Serbia in the Roman era</a>
      </div> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style>
      <div class="thumb tmulti tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:212px;max-width:212px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:113px;max-width:113px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:148px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Lepenski_Vir_Head.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lepenski_Vir_Head.JPG/111px-Lepenski_Vir_Head.JPG" decoding="async" width="111" height="148" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lepenski_Vir_Head.JPG/167px-Lepenski_Vir_Head.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Lepenski_Vir_Head.JPG/222px-Lepenski_Vir_Head.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1536" data-file-height="2048"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Lepenski_Vir" title="Lepenski Vir">Lepenski Vir</a> idol, 7000 BC
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:95px;max-width:95px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:148px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg/93px-Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg" decoding="async" width="93" height="149" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg/140px-Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/16/Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg/186px-Vinca_clay_figure_02.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2160" data-file-height="3456"></a>
          </div>
          <div class="thumbcaption">
           <a href="/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da_culture" title="Vinča culture">Vinča culture</a> figurine, 4000–4500 BC.
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Archaeological evidence of <a href="/wiki/Paleolithic" title="Paleolithic">Paleolithic</a> settlements on the territory of present-day Serbia is scarce. A fragment of a human jaw was found in <a href="/wiki/Si%C4%87evo" class="mw-redirect" title="Sićevo">Sićevo</a> (Mala Balanica) and is believed to be up to 525,000–397,000 years old.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERoksandic2011186–196_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERoksandic2011186–196-21">[19]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Approximately around 6,500 years BC, during the <a href="/wiki/Neolithic" title="Neolithic">Neolithic</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Star%C4%8Devo_culture" title="Starčevo culture">Starčevo</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da_culture" title="Vinča culture">Vinča</a> cultures existed in the region of modern-day Belgrade. They dominated much of <a href="/wiki/Southeastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Southeastern Europe">Southeastern Europe</a> (as well as parts of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a> and <a href="/wiki/Asia_Minor" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia Minor">Asia Minor</a>). Several important archaeological sites from this era, including <a href="/wiki/Lepenski_Vir" title="Lepenski Vir">Lepenski Vir</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da-Belo_Brdo" title="Vinča-Belo Brdo">Vinča-Belo Brdo</a>, still exist near the banks of the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChapman1981_22-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChapman1981-22">[20]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESrejović1988_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESrejović1988-23">[21]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a>, local tribes of <a href="/wiki/Triballi" title="Triballi">Triballi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dardani" title="Dardani">Dardani</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Autariatae" title="Autariatae">Autariatae</a> were encountered by the <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Greeks" class="mw-redirect" title="Ancient Greeks">Ancient Greeks</a> during their cultural and political expansion into the region, from the 5th up to the 2nd century BC. The Celtic tribe of <a href="/wiki/Scordisci" title="Scordisci">Scordisci</a> settled throughout the area in the 3rd century BC. It formed a tribal state, building several fortifications, including their capital at <a href="/wiki/Singidunum" title="Singidunum">Singidunum</a> (present-day Belgrade) and Naissos (present-day <a href="/wiki/Ni%C5%A1" title="Niš">Niš</a>). </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Felix_Romuliana,_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius,_Dacia_Ripensis,_Serbia_(42905999032).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Felix_Romuliana%2C_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius%2C_Dacia_Ripensis%2C_Serbia_%2842905999032%29.jpg/220px-Felix_Romuliana%2C_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius%2C_Dacia_Ripensis%2C_Serbia_%2842905999032%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Felix_Romuliana%2C_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius%2C_Dacia_Ripensis%2C_Serbia_%2842905999032%29.jpg/330px-Felix_Romuliana%2C_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius%2C_Dacia_Ripensis%2C_Serbia_%2842905999032%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/98/Felix_Romuliana%2C_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius%2C_Dacia_Ripensis%2C_Serbia_%2842905999032%29.jpg/440px-Felix_Romuliana%2C_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius%2C_Dacia_Ripensis%2C_Serbia_%2842905999032%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4928" data-file-height="3264"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Felix_Romuliana,_built_in_298_AD_by_Emperor_Galerius,_Dacia_Ripensis,_Serbia_(42905999032).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Remnants of the <a href="/wiki/Gamzigrad" title="Gamzigrad">Felix Romuliana Imperial Palace</a>, a <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage Site</a>; as many as 18 <a href="/wiki/Roman_emperor" title="Roman emperor">Roman emperors</a> were born in modern-day Serbia<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[22]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[23]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Ancient_Rome" title="Ancient Rome">Romans</a> conquered much of the territory in the 2nd century BC. In 167 BC the <a href="/wiki/Roman_province" title="Roman province">Roman province</a> of <a href="/wiki/Illyricum_(Roman_province)" title="Illyricum (Roman province)">Illyricum</a> was established; the remainder was conquered around 75 BC, forming the Roman province of <a href="/wiki/Moesia_Superior" class="mw-redirect" title="Moesia Superior">Moesia Superior</a>; the modern-day <a href="/wiki/Srem_District" title="Srem District">Srem</a> region was conquered in 9 BC; and Bačka and Banat in 106 AD after the <a href="/wiki/Trajan%27s_Dacian_Wars" title="Trajan's Dacian Wars">Dacian Wars</a>. As a result of this, contemporary Serbia extends fully or partially over several former Roman provinces, including <a href="/wiki/Moesia" title="Moesia">Moesia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pannonia" title="Pannonia">Pannonia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Praevalitana" title="Praevalitana">Praevalitana</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dalmatia" title="Dalmatia">Dalmatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dacia" title="Dacia">Dacia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Macedonia_(region)" title="Macedonia (region)">Macedonia</a>. </p>
      <p>The chief towns of <a href="/wiki/Upper_Moesia" class="mw-redirect" title="Upper Moesia">Upper Moesia</a> (and broader) were: Singidunum (Belgrade), <a href="/wiki/Viminacium" title="Viminacium">Viminacium</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Kostolac" title="Kostolac">Old Kostolac</a>), <a href="/wiki/Remesiana" title="Remesiana">Remesiana</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Bela_Palanka" title="Bela Palanka">Bela Palanka</a>), Naissos (Niš), and <a href="/wiki/Sirmium" title="Sirmium">Sirmium</a> (now <a href="/wiki/Sremska_Mitrovica" title="Sremska Mitrovica">Sremska Mitrovica</a>), the latter of which served as a Roman capital during the <a href="/wiki/Tetrarchy" title="Tetrarchy">Tetrarchy</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMirković201779_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMirković201779-26">[24]</a></sup> Seventeen Roman Emperors were born in the area of modern-day Serbia, second only to contemporary Italy.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKuzmanovićMihajlović2015416-432_27-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKuzmanovićMihajlović2015416-432-27">[25]</a></sup> The most famous of these was <a href="/wiki/Constantine_the_Great" title="Constantine the Great">Constantine the Great</a>, the first Christian Emperor, who issued an edict ordering <a href="/wiki/Edict_of_Milan" title="Edict of Milan">religious tolerance throughout the Empire</a>. </p>
      <p>When the Roman Empire was divided in 395, most of Serbia remained under the <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Roman_Empire" class="mw-redirect" title="Eastern Roman Empire">Eastern Roman Empire</a>. At the same time, its northwestern parts were included in the <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western Roman Empire</a>. By the 6th century, <a href="/wiki/South_Slavs" title="South Slavs">South Slavs</a> migrated into the European provinces of the <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a> in large numbers.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOstrogorsky195684_28-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOstrogorsky195684-28">[26]</a></sup> They merged with the local <a href="/wiki/Romanization_(cultural)" title="Romanization (cultural)">Romanised</a> population that was gradually assimilated.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStipčević197776_29-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStipčević197776-29">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine199138,_41_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine199138,_41-30">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller2005533_31-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller2005533-31">[29]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Middle_ages">Middle ages</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Sorbs_(tribe)" title="Sorbs (tribe)">Sorbs (tribe)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbia_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Serbia in the Middle Ages">Serbia in the Middle Ages</a>
      </div> 
      <p>White Serbs, an <a href="/wiki/Early_Slavic" class="mw-redirect" title="Early Slavic">early Slavic</a> tribe from <a href="/wiki/White_Serbia" title="White Serbia">White Serbia</a> eventually settled in an area between the <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">Sava</a> river and the <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">Dinaric Alps</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine199152-53_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine199152-53-32">[30]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIvić19959_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIvić19959-33">[31]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković200411_34-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković200411-34">[32]</a></sup> By the beginning of the 9th century, Serbia achieved a level of statehood.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFine1991141_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFine1991141-35">[33]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Christianization_of_the_Slavs" title="Christianization of the Slavs">Christianization</a> of Serbia was a gradual process, finalized by the middle of the 9th century.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković200415-17_36-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković200415-17-36">[34]</a></sup> In the mid-10th-century, the <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia_(early_medieval)" title="Principality of Serbia (early medieval)">Serbian state</a> stretched between the <a href="/wiki/Adriatic_Sea" title="Adriatic Sea">Adriatic Sea</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Neretva" title="Neretva">Neretva</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">Sava</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Pomoravlje_(region)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pomoravlje (region)">Morava</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Lake_Skadar" title="Lake Skadar">Skadar</a>. During the 11th and 12th century, <a href="/wiki/Grand_Principality_of_Serbia" title="Grand Principality of Serbia">Serbian state</a> frequently fought with the neighbouring <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Empire" title="Byzantine Empire">Byzantine Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković200423-24_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković200423-24-37">[35]</a></sup> Between 1166 and 1371 Serbia was ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Nemanji%C4%87_dynasty" title="Nemanjić dynasty">Nemanjić dynasty</a> (whose legacy is especially cherished), under whom the state was elevated to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia_(medieval)" title="Kingdom of Serbia (medieval)">a kingdom</a> in 1217,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković200438_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković200438-38">[36]</a></sup> and an <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Empire" title="Serbian Empire">empire</a> in 1346,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković200464_39-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković200464-39">[37]</a></sup> under <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Du%C5%A1an" title="Stefan Dušan">Stefan Dušan</a>. <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_Church" title="Serbian Orthodox Church">Serbian Orthodox Church</a> was organized as an <a href="/wiki/Autocephaly" title="Autocephaly">autocephalous</a> archbishopric in 1219,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković200428_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković200428-40">[38]</a></sup> through the effort of <a href="/wiki/Saint_Sava" title="Saint Sava">Sava</a>, the country's patron saint, and in 1346 it was raised to the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Patriarchate_of_Pe%C4%87" title="Serbian Patriarchate of Peć">Patriarchate</a>. Monuments of the Nemanjić period survive in many <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_monasteries" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Orthodox monasteries">monasteries</a> (several being <a href="/wiki/List_of_World_Heritage_Sites_in_Serbia" title="List of World Heritage Sites in Serbia">World Heritage sites</a>) and <a href="/wiki/Forts_in_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Forts in Serbia">fortifications</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Kosovo,_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87,_1870.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Battle_of_Kosovo%2C_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87%2C_1870.jpg/220px-Battle_of_Kosovo%2C_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87%2C_1870.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="131" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Battle_of_Kosovo%2C_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87%2C_1870.jpg/330px-Battle_of_Kosovo%2C_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87%2C_1870.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Battle_of_Kosovo%2C_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87%2C_1870.jpg/440px-Battle_of_Kosovo%2C_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87%2C_1870.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1255" data-file-height="750"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Kosovo,_Adam_Stefanovi%C4%87,_1870.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kosovo" title="Battle of Kosovo">Battle of Kosovo</a> (1389) is particularly important to Serbian history, tradition and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_national_identity" title="Serbian national identity">national identity</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[39]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During these centuries the Serbian state (and influence) expanded significantly. The northern part (modern <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a>), was ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Hungary" title="Kingdom of Hungary">Kingdom of Hungary</a>. The period after 1371, known as the <a href="/wiki/Fall_of_the_Serbian_Empire" title="Fall of the Serbian Empire">Fall of the Serbian Empire</a> saw the once-powerful state fragmented into several principalities, culminating in the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kosovo" title="Battle of Kosovo">Battle of Kosovo</a> (1389) against the rising <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković200484-85_42-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković200484-85-42">[40]</a></sup> The Ottomans finally conquered the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Despotate" title="Serbian Despotate">Serbian Despotate</a> in 1459. The Ottoman threat and eventual conquest saw massive migrations of Serbs to the west and north.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004107-108_43-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004107-108-43">[41]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ottoman_and_Habsburg_rule">Ottoman and Habsburg rule</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Serbia" title="Ottoman Serbia">Ottoman Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Great_Migrations_of_the_Serbs" title="Great Migrations of the Serbs">Great Migrations of the Serbs</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In all Serbian lands conquered by the Ottomans, the native nobility was eliminated and the peasantry was <a href="/wiki/Serfdom" title="Serfdom">enserfed</a> to Ottoman rulers, while much of the clergy fled or were confined to the isolated monasteries. Under the Ottoman system, Serbs, as well as Christians, were considered an <a href="/wiki/Rayah" title="Rayah">inferior class</a> of people and subjected to heavy taxes, and a portion of the Serbian population experienced <a href="/wiki/Islamization" title="Islamization">Islamization</a>. Many Serbs were recruited during the <a href="/wiki/Devshirme" title="Devshirme">devshirme</a> system, a form of <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Slavery in the Ottoman Empire">slavery in the Ottoman Empire</a>, in which boys from Balkan Christian families were <a href="/wiki/Forced_conversion" title="Forced conversion">forcibly converted</a> to <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> and trained for infantry units of the <a href="/wiki/Military_of_the_Ottoman_Empire" title="Military of the Ottoman Empire">Ottoman army</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Janissaries" class="mw-redirect" title="Janissaries">Janissaries</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEA_́gostonMasters2010383_44-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEA_́gostonMasters2010383-44">[42]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiley-Smith2001251_45-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiley-Smith2001251-45">[43]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERodriguez19976_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERodriguez19976-46">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKia201162_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKia201162-47">[45]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Patriarchate_of_Pe%C4%87" title="Serbian Patriarchate of Peć">Serbian Patriarchate of Peć</a> was extinguished in 1463,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004134_48-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004134-48">[46]</a></sup> but reestablished in 1557,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004135-136_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004135-136-49">[47]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFotić2008519–520_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFotić2008519–520-50">[48]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESotirović2011143–169_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESotirović2011143–169-51">[49]</a></sup> providing for limited continuation of Serbian cultural traditions within the Ottoman Empire, under the <a href="/wiki/Millet_system" class="mw-redirect" title="Millet system">Millet system</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERunciman1968204_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERunciman1968204-52">[50]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKia2011115_53-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKia2011115-53">[51]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the loss of statehood to the Ottoman Empire, Serbian resistance continued in northern regions (modern Vojvodina), under titular despots (until 1537), and popular leaders like <a href="/wiki/Jovan_Nenad" title="Jovan Nenad">Jovan Nenad</a> (1526–1527). From 1521 to 1552, Ottomans conquered Belgrade and regions of Syrmia, Bačka, and Banat.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004115,_119_54-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004115,_119-54">[52]</a></sup> Continuing wars and various rebellions constantly challenged Ottoman rule. One of the most significant was the <a href="/wiki/Banat_Uprising" class="mw-redirect" title="Banat Uprising">Banat Uprising</a> in 1594 and 1595, which was part of the <a href="/wiki/Long_War_(Ottoman_wars)" class="mw-redirect" title="Long War (Ottoman wars)">Long War</a> (1593–1606) between the Habsburgs and the Ottomans.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004141–142_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004141–142-55">[53]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESotirović2011163–164_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESotirović2011163–164-56">[54]</a></sup> The area of modern Vojvodina endured a century-long Ottoman occupation before being ceded to the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Empire</a>, partially by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Karlovci" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Karlovci">Treaty of Karlovci</a> (1699),<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPešalj201029-42_57-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPešalj201029-42-57">[55]</a></sup> and fully by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Po%C5%BEarevac" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of Požarevac">Treaty of Požarevac</a> (1718).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004151_58-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004151-58">[56]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serbmigra.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/48/Serbmigra.jpg/220px-Serbmigra.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/48/Serbmigra.jpg/330px-Serbmigra.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/48/Serbmigra.jpg/440px-Serbmigra.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1070"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serbmigra.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Great_Migrations_of_the_Serbs" title="Great Migrations of the Serbs">Great Migrations of the Serbs</a>, led by Patriarch <a href="/wiki/Arsenije_III_%C4%8Carnojevi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Arsenije III Čarnojević">Arsenije III Čarnojević</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As the <a href="/wiki/Great_Serb_Migrations" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Serb Migrations">Great Serb Migrations</a> depopulated most of southern Serbia, the Serbs sought refuge across the Danube River in <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a> to the north and the <a href="/wiki/Military_Frontier" title="Military Frontier">Military Frontier</a> in the west, where they were granted rights by the Austrian crown under measures such as the <i>Statuta Wallachorum</i> of 1630. Much of central Serbia switched from Ottoman rule to <a href="/wiki/Habsburg-occupied_Serbia_(1686%E2%80%9391)" title="Habsburg-occupied Serbia (1686–91)">Habsburg control (1686–91)</a> during the <a href="/wiki/Great_Turkish_War" title="Great Turkish War">Habsburg-Ottoman war (1683-1699)</a>. Following several petitions, Emperor <a href="/wiki/Leopold_I,_Holy_Roman_Emperor" title="Leopold I, Holy Roman Emperor">Leopold I</a> formally granted Serbs who wished to settle in the northern regions the right to their autonomous <a href="/wiki/Crown_land" title="Crown land">crown land</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETodorović20067–8_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETodorović20067–8-59">[57]</a></sup> The ecclesiastical centre of the Serbs also moved northwards, to the <a href="/wiki/Metropolitanate_of_Karlovci" title="Metropolitanate of Karlovci">Metropolitanate of Karlovci</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004150_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004150-60">[58]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Patriarchate_of_Pe%C4%87" title="Serbian Patriarchate of Peć">Serbian Patriarchate of Peć</a> was once-again abolished by the Ottomans in 1766.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJelavich1983a94_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJelavich1983a94-61">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004177_62-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004177-62">[60]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 1718–39, the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a> occupied much of <a href="/wiki/Central_Serbia" title="Central Serbia">Central Serbia</a> and established the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia_(1718%E2%80%9339)" title="Kingdom of Serbia (1718–39)">Kingdom of Serbia</a> as <a href="/wiki/Crownland" class="mw-redirect" title="Crownland">crownland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004151_58-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004151-58">[56]</a></sup> Those gains were lost by the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Belgrade" title="Treaty of Belgrade">Treaty of Belgrade</a> in 1739, when the Ottomans retook the region.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004176_63-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004176-63">[61]</a></sup> Apart from territory of modern Vojvodina which remained under the Habsburg Empire, central regions of Serbia were occupied once again by the Habsburgs in <a href="/wiki/Habsburg-occupied_Serbia_(1788%E2%80%9392)" class="mw-redirect" title="Habsburg-occupied Serbia (1788–92)">1788–1792</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Revolution_and_independence">Revolution and independence</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Revolution" title="Serbian Revolution">Serbian Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Serbia" title="Principality of Serbia">Principality of Serbia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Revolution" title="Serbian Revolution">Serbian Revolution</a> for independence from the Ottoman Empire lasted eleven years, from 1804 until 1815.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJelavich1983a193-204_64-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJelavich1983a193-204-64">[62]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200229-32_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200229-32-65">[63]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERadosavljević2010171-178_66-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERadosavljević2010171-178-66">[64]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERajić2010143-148_67-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERajić2010143-148-67">[65]</a></sup> The revolution comprised two separate uprisings which gained autonomy from the Ottoman Empire (1830) that eventually evolved towards full independence (1878). During the <a href="/wiki/First_Serbian_Uprising" title="First Serbian Uprising">First Serbian Uprising</a> (1804–1813), led by vožd <a href="/wiki/Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Karađorđe Petrović">Karađorđe Petrović</a>, Serbia was independent for almost a decade before the Ottoman army was able to reoccupy the country.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004179-183_68-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004179-183-68">[66]</a></sup> Shortly after this, the <a href="/wiki/Second_Serbian_Uprising" title="Second Serbian Uprising">Second Serbian Uprising</a> began in 1815. Led by <a href="/wiki/Milo%C5%A1_Obrenovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Miloš Obrenović">Miloš Obrenović</a>, it ended with a compromise between Serbian revolutionaries and Ottoman authorities.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004190-196_69-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004190-196-69">[67]</a></sup> Likewise, Serbia was one of the first nations in the Balkans to abolish <a href="/wiki/Feudalism" title="Feudalism">feudalism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004191_70-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004191-70">[68]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Akkerman_Convention" title="Akkerman Convention">Akkerman Convention</a> in 1826, the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Adrianople_(1829)" title="Treaty of Adrianople (1829)">Treaty of Adrianople</a> in 1829 and finally, the <a href="/wiki/Hatt-i_Sharif" class="mw-redirect" title="Hatt-i Sharif">Hatt-i Sharif</a>, recognised the <a href="/wiki/Suzerainty" title="Suzerainty">suzerainty</a> of Serbia. The <a href="/wiki/Sretenje_Constitution" title="Sretenje Constitution">First Serbian Constitution</a> was adopted on 15 February 1835 (the anniversary of the outbreak of the First Serbian Uprising), making the country one of the first to adopt a democratic constitution in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStavrianos2000248–250_71-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStavrianos2000248–250-71">[69]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004195_72-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004195-72">[70]</a></sup> 15 February is now commemorated as <a href="/wiki/Statehood_Day_(Serbia)" title="Statehood Day (Serbia)">Statehood Day</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Public_holidays_in_Serbia" title="Public holidays in Serbia">public holiday</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[71]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:322px;max-width:322px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:165px;max-width:165px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:211px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Arsa_Teodorovi%C4%87,_Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87,_1818,_oil_on_canvas,_National_Museum_of_Serbia.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Arsa_Teodorovi%C4%87%2C_Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87%2C_1818%2C_oil_on_canvas%2C_National_Museum_of_Serbia.jpg/163px-Arsa_Teodorovi%C4%87%2C_Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87%2C_1818%2C_oil_on_canvas%2C_National_Museum_of_Serbia.jpg" decoding="async" width="163" height="212" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Arsa_Teodorovi%C4%87%2C_Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87%2C_1818%2C_oil_on_canvas%2C_National_Museum_of_Serbia.jpg/245px-Arsa_Teodorovi%C4%87%2C_Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87%2C_1818%2C_oil_on_canvas%2C_National_Museum_of_Serbia.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/Arsa_Teodorovi%C4%87%2C_Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87%2C_1818%2C_oil_on_canvas%2C_National_Museum_of_Serbia.jpg/326px-Arsa_Teodorovi%C4%87%2C_Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87%2C_1818%2C_oil_on_canvas%2C_National_Museum_of_Serbia.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2128" data-file-height="2768"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:153px;max-width:153px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:211px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87,_by_Vladimir_Borovikovsky,_1816.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87%2C_by_Vladimir_Borovikovsky%2C_1816.jpg/151px-Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87%2C_by_Vladimir_Borovikovsky%2C_1816.jpg" decoding="async" width="151" height="211" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87%2C_by_Vladimir_Borovikovsky%2C_1816.jpg/227px-Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87%2C_by_Vladimir_Borovikovsky%2C_1816.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/14/Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87%2C_by_Vladimir_Borovikovsky%2C_1816.jpg/302px-Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87%2C_by_Vladimir_Borovikovsky%2C_1816.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="1430"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <b>Left:</b> <a href="/wiki/Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87" title="Dositej Obradović">Dositej Obradović</a>, a protagonist of the national and cultural renaissance
          <br><b>Right:</b> <a href="/wiki/Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e_Petrovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Karađorđe Petrović">Karađorđe Petrović</a>, leader of the <a href="/wiki/First_Serbian_Uprising" title="First Serbian Uprising">First Serbian Uprising</a>
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Following the clashes between the Ottoman army and Serbs in Belgrade in 1862,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004214-215_74-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004214-215-74">[72]</a></sup> and under pressure from the <a href="/wiki/Great_Powers" class="mw-redirect" title="Great Powers">Great Powers</a>, by 1867 the last Turkish soldiers left the Principality, making the country <i>de facto</i> independent.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJelavich1983a246_75-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJelavich1983a246-75">[73]</a></sup> By enacting a new constitution in 1869,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200258_76-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200258-76">[74]</a></sup> without consulting the Porte, <a href="/wiki/Jovan_Ristic" class="mw-redirect" title="Jovan Ristic">Serbian diplomats</a> confirmed the <i>de facto</i> independence of the country. In 1876, Serbia declared war on the Ottoman Empire, siding with the ongoing Christian uprisings in <a href="/wiki/Uprising_in_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina_(1875-1878)" class="mw-redirect" title="Uprising in Bosnia and Herzegovina (1875-1878)">Bosnia-Herzegovina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_Uprising_of_1876" class="mw-redirect" title="Bulgarian Uprising of 1876">Bulgaria</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200263-64_77-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200263-64-77">[75]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004224_78-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004224-78">[76]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The formal independence of the country was internationally recognised at the <a href="/wiki/Congress_of_Berlin" title="Congress of Berlin">Congress of Berlin</a> in 1878, which ended the <a href="/wiki/Russo-Turkish_War_(1877%E2%80%931878)" title="Russo-Turkish War (1877–1878)">Russo-Turkish War</a>; this treaty, however, prohibited Serbia from uniting with other Serbian regions by placing Bosnia and Herzegovina under <a href="/wiki/Austria-Hungary" title="Austria-Hungary">Austro-Hungarian</a> occupation, alongside the occupation of the region of <a href="/wiki/Ra%C5%A1ka_(region)" title="Raška (region)">Raška</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004225_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004225-79">[77]</a></sup> From 1815 to 1903, the Principality of Serbia was ruled by the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Obrenovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Obrenović">House of Obrenović</a>, save for the rule of Prince <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Kara%C4%91or%C4%91evi%C4%87,_Prince_of_Serbia" title="Alexander Karađorđević, Prince of Serbia">Aleksandar Karađorđević</a> between 1842 and 1858. In 1882, Principality of Serbia became the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a>, ruled by <a href="/wiki/Milan_I_of_Serbia" title="Milan I of Serbia">King Milan I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200270_80-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200270-80">[78]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/House_of_Kara%C4%91or%C4%91evi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Karađorđević">House of Karađorđević</a>, descendants of the revolutionary leader Karađorđe Petrović, assumed power in 1903 following the <a href="/wiki/May_Overthrow" class="mw-redirect" title="May Overthrow">May Overthrow</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200273_81-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200273-81">[79]</a></sup> In the north, the <a href="/wiki/Revolutions_of_1848_in_the_Habsburg_areas" class="mw-redirect" title="Revolutions of 1848 in the Habsburg areas">1848 revolution in Austria</a> led to the establishment of the autonomous territory of <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Vojvodina" title="Serbian Vojvodina">Serbian Vojvodina</a>; by 1849, the region was transformed into the <a href="/wiki/Voivodeship_of_Serbia_and_Banat_of_Temeschwar" title="Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar">Voivodeship of Serbia and Banat of Temeschwar</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004203_82-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004203-82">[80]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="The_Balkan_Wars_and_World_War_I">The Balkan Wars and World War I</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Wars" title="Balkan Wars">Balkan Wars</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Campaign_of_World_War_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Campaign of World War I">Serbian Campaign of World War I</a>
      </div> 
      <p>In the course of the <a href="/wiki/First_Balkan_War" title="First Balkan War">First Balkan War</a> in 1912, the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_League" title="Balkan League">Balkan League</a> defeated the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and captured its <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_London,_1913" class="mw-redirect" title="Treaty of London, 1913">European territories</a>, which enabled territorial expansion of the Kingdom of Serbia into regions of <a href="/wiki/Ra%C5%A1ka_(region)" title="Raška (region)">Raška</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_(region)" class="mw-redirect" title="Kosovo (region)">Kosovo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Metohija" title="Metohija">Metohija</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vardarian_Macedonia" class="mw-redirect" title="Vardarian Macedonia">Vardarian Macedonia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Second_Balkan_War" title="Second Balkan War">Second Balkan War</a> soon ensued when Bulgaria turned on its former allies, but was defeated, resulting in the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Bucharest_(1913)" title="Treaty of Bucharest (1913)">Treaty of Bucharest</a>. In two years, Serbia enlarged its territory and its population by 50%,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2018)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> it also suffered high casualties on the eve of World War I, with more than 36,000 dead.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHall2000135_83-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHall2000135-83">[81]</a></sup> Austria-Hungary became wary of the rising regional power on its borders and its potential to become an anchor for unification of Serbs and other South Slavs, and the relationship between the two countries became tense. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg/220px-Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="158" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg/330px-Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg/440px-Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg 2x" data-file-width="577" data-file-height="415"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serbian_retreat_WWI.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Great_Retreat_(Serbian)" title="Great Retreat (Serbian)">Great Serbian Retreat</a> in 1915; <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Serbia</a> lost about 850,000 people during the war, a quarter of its pre-war population<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECurtis199228_84-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECurtis199228-84">[82]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Assassination_in_Sarajevo" class="mw-redirect" title="Assassination in Sarajevo">assassination</a> of <a href="/wiki/Archduke_Franz_Ferdinand_of_Austria" title="Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria">Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria</a> on 28 June 1914 in <a href="/wiki/Sarajevo" title="Sarajevo">Sarajevo</a> by <a href="/wiki/Gavrilo_Princip" title="Gavrilo Princip">Gavrilo Princip</a>, a member of the <a href="/wiki/Young_Bosnia" title="Young Bosnia">Young Bosnia</a> organisation, led to Austria-Hungary declaring war on Serbia, on 28 July.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004246-247_85-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004246-247-85">[83]</a></sup> Local war escalated when <a href="/wiki/German_Empire" title="German Empire">Germany</a> declared war on <a href="/wiki/Russian_Empire" title="Russian Empire">Russia</a> and invaded <a href="/wiki/French_Third_Republic" title="French Third Republic">France</a> and <a href="/wiki/Belgium" title="Belgium">Belgium</a>, thus drawing <a href="/wiki/United_Kingdom_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland" title="United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland">Great Britain</a> into the conflict that became the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" class="mw-redirect" title="First World War">First World War</a>. Serbia won the first major battles of World War I, including the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Cer" title="Battle of Cer">Battle of Cer</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMitrović200769_86-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMitrović200769-86">[84]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Kolubara" title="Battle of Kolubara">Battle of Kolubara</a>, marking the first <a href="/wiki/Allies_of_World_War_I" title="Allies of World War I">Allied</a> victories against the <a href="/wiki/Central_Powers" title="Central Powers">Central Powers</a> in World War I.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMitrović2007104_87-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMitrović2007104-87">[85]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Despite initial success, it was eventually overpowered by the Central Powers in 1915 and <a href="/wiki/Austro-Hungarian_occupation_of_Serbia" title="Austro-Hungarian occupation of Serbia">Austro-Hungarian occupation of Serbia</a> followed. Most of its army and some people <a href="/wiki/Serbian_army%27s_retreat_through_Albania" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian army's retreat through Albania">retreated</a> through <a href="/wiki/Principality_of_Albania" title="Principality of Albania">Albania</a> to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Greece" title="Kingdom of Greece">Greece</a> and <a href="/wiki/Corfu" title="Corfu">Corfu</a>, suffering immense losses on the way. Serbia was occupied by the Central Powers. After the Central Powers military situation on other fronts worsened, the remains of the Serb army returned east and led a final breakthrough through enemy lines on 15 September 1918, liberating Serbia and defeating Bulgaria and Austria-Hungary.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004250-251_88-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004250-251-88">[86]</a></sup> Serbia, with its <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Campaign_(World_War_I)" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Campaign (World War I)">campaign</a>, was a major Balkan Entente Power<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[87]</a></sup> which contributed significantly to the Allied victory in the Balkans in November 1918, especially by helping France force Bulgaria's <a href="/wiki/Capitulation_(surrender)" title="Capitulation (surrender)">capitulation</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[88]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg/220px-Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="121" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg/330px-Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg/440px-Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2006" data-file-height="1101"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Velika-narodna-skupstina-1918.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Great Assembly of <a href="/wiki/Serbs" title="Serbs">Serbs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bunjevci" title="Bunjevci">Bunjevci</a>, and other Slavs proclaimed the unification of Vojvodina region with the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a> in Novi Sad in 1918
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia's casualties accounted for 8% of the total Entente military deaths; 58% (243,600) soldiers of the Serbian army perished in the war.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[89]</a></sup> The total number of casualties is placed around 700,000,<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[90]</a></sup> more than 16% of Serbia's prewar size,<sup id="cite_ref-The_Balkan_Wars_and_World_War_I_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-The_Balkan_Wars_and_World_War_I-93">[91]</a></sup> and a majority (57%) of its overall male population.<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[92]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[93]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[94]</a></sup> Serbia suffered <a href="/wiki/World_War_I_casualties" title="World War I casualties">the biggest casualty rate in World War I</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[95]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>As the Austro-Hungarian Empire collapsed, the territory of Syrmia united with Serbia on 24 November 1918.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (May 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Just a day later on 25 November 1918 Grand National Assembly of Serbs, Bunjevci and other Slavs in Banat, Bačka and Baranja declared the unification of <a href="/wiki/Banat" title="Banat">Banat</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ba%C4%8Dka" title="Bačka">Bačka</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Baranya_County_(former)" title="Baranya County (former)">Baranja</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Serbia" title="Kingdom of Serbia">Kingdom of Serbia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[96]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia.2C_World_War_II.2C_and_the_socialist_Yugoslavia"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia,_World_War_II,_and_the_socialist_Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia, World War II, and the socialist Yugoslavia</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Kingdom of Yugoslavia">Kingdom of Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_in_Yugoslavia" title="World War II in Yugoslavia">World War II in Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Genocide_of_Serbs_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Genocide of Serbs in the Independent State of Croatia">Genocide of Serbs in the Independent State of Croatia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>On 26 November 1918, the <a href="/wiki/Podgorica_Assembly" title="Podgorica Assembly">Podgorica Assembly</a> deposed the <a href="/wiki/House_of_Petrovi%C4%87-Njego%C5%A1" class="mw-redirect" title="House of Petrović-Njegoš">House of Petrović-Njegoš</a> and united Montenegro with Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[97]</a></sup> On 1 December 1918, in Belgrade, Serbian Prince Regent <a href="/wiki/Alexander_I_of_Yugoslavia" title="Alexander I of Yugoslavia">Alexander Karađorđević</a> proclaimed the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_the_Serbs,_Croats,_and_Slovenes" class="mw-redirect" title="Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes">Kingdom of the Serbs, Croats, and Slovenes</a>, under King <a href="/wiki/Peter_I_of_Serbia" title="Peter I of Serbia">Peter I of Serbia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch2002108-109_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch2002108-109-100">[98]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004251-252_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEĆirković2004251-252-101">[99]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>King Peter was succeeded by his son, Alexander, in August 1921. Serb centralists and Croat autonomists clashed in the parliament, and most governments were fragile and short-lived. <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Pa%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Nikola Pašić">Nikola Pašić</a>, a conservative prime minister, headed or dominated most governments until his death. King Alexander established a <a href="/wiki/6_January_Dictatorship" title="6 January Dictatorship">dictatorship</a> in 1929 with the aim of establishing the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavism" title="Yugoslavism">Yugoslav ideology</a> and single <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavs" title="Yugoslavs">Yugoslav nation</a>, changed the name of the country to Yugoslavia and changed the internal divisions from the 33 <a href="/wiki/Oblasts" class="mw-redirect" title="Oblasts">oblasts</a> to nine new <a href="/wiki/Subdivisions_of_the_Kingdom_of_Yugoslavia" title="Subdivisions of the Kingdom of Yugoslavia">banovinas</a>. The effect of Alexander's dictatorship was to further alienate the non-Serbs living in Yugoslavia from the idea of unity.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStavrianos2000624_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStavrianos2000624-102">[100]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Alexander was assassinated in <a href="/wiki/Marseille" title="Marseille">Marseille</a>, during an official visit in 1934 by <a href="/wiki/Vlado_Chernozemski" title="Vlado Chernozemski">Vlado Chernozemski</a>, member of the <a href="/wiki/Internal_Macedonian_Revolutionary_Organization" title="Internal Macedonian Revolutionary Organization">IMRO</a>. Alexander was succeeded by his eleven-year-old son <a href="/wiki/Peter_II_of_Yugoslavia" title="Peter II of Yugoslavia">Peter II</a> and a regency council was headed by his cousin, <a href="/wiki/Prince_Paul_of_Yugoslavia" title="Prince Paul of Yugoslavia">Prince Paul</a>. In August 1939 the <a href="/wiki/Cvetkovi%C4%87%E2%80%93Ma%C4%8Dek_Agreement" title="Cvetković–Maček Agreement">Cvetković–Maček Agreement</a> established an autonomous <a href="/wiki/Banate_of_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="Banate of Croatia">Banate of Croatia</a> as a solution to Croatian concerns. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia,_1941-43.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia%2C_1941-43.png/330px-Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia%2C_1941-43.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="365" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia%2C_1941-43.png/495px-Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia%2C_1941-43.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia%2C_1941-43.png/660px-Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia%2C_1941-43.png 2x" data-file-width="1076" data-file-height="1190"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Axis_occupation_of_Yugoslavia,_1941-43.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Government_of_National_Salvation" title="Government of National Salvation">Serbia</a> after Kingdom of Yugoslavia's occupation by the Axis and neighbouring puppet states during World War II
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1941, in spite of Yugoslav attempts to remain neutral in the war, the <a href="/wiki/Axis_powers" title="Axis powers">Axis powers</a> invaded Yugoslavia. The territory of modern Serbia was divided between Hungary, Bulgaria, the Independent State of Croatia and Italy (Greater Albania and Montenegro), while the remaining part of the occupied Serbia was placed under the <a href="/wiki/Territory_of_the_Military_Commander_in_Serbia" title="Territory of the Military Commander in Serbia">military administration</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Nazi_Germany" title="Nazi Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Government_of_National_Salvation" title="Government of National Salvation">Serbian puppet governments</a> led by <a href="/wiki/Milan_A%C4%87imovi%C4%87" title="Milan Aćimović">Milan Aćimović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Milan_Nedi%C4%87" title="Milan Nedić">Milan Nedić</a> assisted by <a href="/wiki/Dimitrije_Ljoti%C4%87" title="Dimitrije Ljotić">Dimitrije Ljotić</a>'s fascist organization <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_National_Movement" title="Yugoslav National Movement">Yugoslav National Movement</a> (Zbor). </p>
      <p>The Yugoslav territory was the scene of a civil war between <a href="/wiki/Chetniks" title="Chetniks">royalist Chetniks</a> commanded by <a href="/wiki/Dra%C5%BEa_Mihailovi%C4%87" title="Draža Mihailović">Draža Mihailović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Partisans_(Yugoslavia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Partisans (Yugoslavia)">communist partisans</a> commanded by <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a>. Axis auxiliary units of the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Volunteer_Corps_(World_War_II)" title="Serbian Volunteer Corps (World War II)">Serbian Volunteer Corps</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_State_Guard" title="Serbian State Guard">Serbian State Guard</a> fought against both of these forces. <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Kraljevo" title="Siege of Kraljevo">Siege of Kraljevo</a> was a major battle of the <a href="/wiki/Uprising_in_Serbia_(1941)" title="Uprising in Serbia (1941)">Uprising in Serbia</a>, led by Chetnik forces against the Nazis. Several days after the battle began the German forces committed a massacre of approximately 2,000 civilians in an event known as the <a href="/wiki/Kraljevo_massacre" title="Kraljevo massacre">Kraljevo massacre</a>, in a reprisal for the attack. <a href="/wiki/Loznica" title="Loznica">Draginac and Loznica massacre</a> of 2,950 villagers in Western Serbia in 1941 was the first large execution of civilians in occupied Serbia by <a href="/wiki/Nazi" class="mw-redirect" title="Nazi">Germans</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Kragujevac_massacre" title="Kragujevac massacre">Kragujevac massacre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Novi_Sad_Raid" class="mw-redirect" title="Novi Sad Raid">Novi Sad Raid</a> of Jews and Serbs by Hungarian fascists being the most notorious, with over 3,000 victims in each case.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200862_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPavlowitch200862-103">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[102]</a></sup> After one year of occupation, around 16,000 <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Jews" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Jews">Serbian Jews</a> were murdered in the area, or around 90% of its pre-war Jewish population during <a href="/wiki/The_Holocaust_in_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="The Holocaust in Serbia">The Holocaust in Serbia</a>. Many concentration camps were established across the area. <a href="/wiki/Banjica_concentration_camp" title="Banjica concentration camp">Banjica concentration camp</a> was the largest concentration camp and jointly run by the German army and Nedić's regime,<sup id="cite_ref-Israeli2013_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Israeli2013-105">[103]</a></sup> with primary victims being Serbian Jews, <a href="/wiki/Romani_people" title="Romani people">Roma</a>, and Serb political prisoners.<sup id="cite_ref-JewishHeritage_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-JewishHeritage-106">[104]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg/220px-Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg/330px-Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/21/Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg/440px-Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2560" data-file-height="1920"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Da.se.ne.zaboravi.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <i>Interrupted Flight</i> is a part of <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0umarice_Memorial_Park" title="Šumarice Memorial Park">Šumarice Memorial Park</a> dedicated to the hundreds of children murdered by German Nazis on 21 October 1941 in <a href="/wiki/Kragujevac_massacre" title="Kragujevac massacre">Kragujevac massacre</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>During this period, hundreds of thousands of ethnic Serbs fled the Axis <a href="/wiki/Puppet_state" title="Puppet state">puppet state</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Independent State of Croatia">Independent State of Croatia</a> and sought refuge in German-occupied Serbia, seeking to escape the large-scale persecution and genocide of Serbs, Jews, and Roma being committed by the <a href="/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e" title="Ustaše">Ustaše</a> regime.<sup id="cite_ref-107" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-107">[105]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/Josip_Broz_Tito" title="Josip Broz Tito">Josip Broz Tito</a> himself, Serbs made up the vast majority of <a href="/wiki/Anti-fascism" title="Anti-fascism">Anti-fascist</a> fighters and <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans" title="Yugoslav Partisans">Yugoslav Partisans</a> for the whole course of <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">World War II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[106]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_U%C5%BEice" title="Republic of Užice">Republic of Užice</a> was a short-lived liberated territory established by the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Partisans" title="Yugoslav Partisans">Partisans</a> and the first liberated territory in World War II Europe, organised as a military mini-state that existed in the autumn of 1941 in the west of <a href="/wiki/Serbia_under_German_occupation" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbia under German occupation">occupied Serbia</a>. By late 1944, the <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Offensive" title="Belgrade Offensive">Belgrade Offensive</a> swung in favour of the partisans in the civil war; the partisans subsequently gained control of Yugoslavia.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[107]</a></sup> Following the Belgrade Offensive, the <a href="/wiki/Syrmian_Front" title="Syrmian Front">Syrmian Front</a> was the last major military action of World War II in Serbia. A study by <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_%C5%BDerjavi%C4%87" title="Vladimir Žerjavić">Vladimir Žerjavić</a> estimates total <a href="/wiki/World_War_II_casualties" title="World War II casualties">war related deaths</a> in Yugoslavia at 1,027,000, including 273,000 in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[108]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Usta%C5%A1e" title="Ustaše">Ustaše</a> regime committed the <a href="/wiki/Genocide_of_Serbs_in_the_Independent_State_of_Croatia" title="Genocide of Serbs in the Independent State of Croatia">Genocide of Serbs</a> and systematically murdered approximately 300,000 to 500,000 Serbs.<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[109]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[110]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-113" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-113">[111]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The victory of the Communist Partisans resulted in the abolition of the monarchy and a subsequent constitutional referendum. A <a href="/wiki/One-party_state" title="One-party state">one-party state</a> was soon established in Yugoslavia by the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Communists_of_Yugoslavia" title="League of Communists of Yugoslavia">Communist Party of Yugoslavia</a>. It is claimed between 60,000 and 70,000 people died in Serbia during the <a href="/wiki/Communist_purges_in_Serbia_in_1944%E2%80%9345" title="Communist purges in Serbia in 1944–45">1944–45 communist takeover and purge</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[112]</a></sup> All opposition was suppressed and people deemed to be promoting opposition to socialism or promoting separatism were imprisoned or executed for sedition. Serbia became a <a href="/wiki/Constituent_state" title="Constituent state">constituent republic</a> within the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">SFRY</a> known as the <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Republic_of_Serbia" title="Socialist Republic of Serbia">Socialist Republic of Serbia</a>, and had a republic-branch of the federal communist party, the <a href="/wiki/League_of_Communists_of_Serbia" title="League of Communists of Serbia">League of Communists of Serbia</a>. </p>
