      <p>Serbia's most powerful and influential politician in Tito-era Yugoslavia was <a href="/wiki/Aleksandar_Rankovi%C4%87" title="Aleksandar Ranković">Aleksandar Ranković</a>, one of the "big four" Yugoslav leaders, alongside Tito, <a href="/wiki/Edvard_Kardelj" title="Edvard Kardelj">Edvard Kardelj</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Milovan_%C4%90ilas" title="Milovan Đilas">Milovan Đilas</a>. Ranković was later removed from the office because of the disagreements regarding Kosovo's <a href="/wiki/Nomenklatura" title="Nomenklatura">nomenklatura</a> and the unity of Serbia. Ranković's dismissal was highly unpopular among Serbs. Pro-decentralisation reformers in Yugoslavia succeeded in the late 1960s in attaining substantial decentralisation of powers, creating substantial autonomy in Kosovo and Vojvodina, and recognising a distinctive "<a href="/wiki/Muslims_(ethnicity)" class="mw-redirect" title="Muslims (ethnicity)">Muslim</a>" nationality. As a result of these reforms, there was a massive overhaul of Kosovo's nomenklatura and police, that shifted from being Serb-dominated to ethnic Albanian-dominated through firing Serbs on a large scale. Further concessions were made to the ethnic Albanians of Kosovo in response to unrest, including the creation of the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Pristina_(1969%E2%80%931999)" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Pristina (1969–1999)">University of Pristina</a> as an <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian language</a> institution. These changes created widespread fear among Serbs of being treated as <a href="/wiki/Second-class_citizen" title="Second-class citizen">second-class citizens</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[113]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Belgrade, the capital of SFR Yugoslavia and SR Serbia, hosted the first <a href="/wiki/Non-Aligned_Movement" title="Non-Aligned Movement">Non-Aligned Movement</a> Summit in September 1961, as well as the first major gathering of the <a href="/wiki/Organization_for_Security_and_Co-operation_in_Europe" title="Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe">Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe</a> (OSCE) with the aim of implementing the <a href="/wiki/Helsinki_Accords" title="Helsinki Accords">Helsinki Accords</a> from October 1977 to March 1978.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[114]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[115]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/1972_Yugoslav_smallpox_outbreak" title="1972 Yugoslav smallpox outbreak">1972 smallpox outbreak</a> in SAP Kosovo and other parts of SR Serbia was the last major outbreak of <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> in <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> since World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[116]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="Breakup_of_Yugoslavia.2C_political_transition_and_contemporary_period"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Breakup_of_Yugoslavia,_political_transition_and_contemporary_period">Breakup of Yugoslavia, political transition and contemporary period</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Breakup_of_Yugoslavia" title="Breakup of Yugoslavia">Breakup of Yugoslavia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbia_and_Montenegro" title="Serbia and Montenegro">Serbia and Montenegro</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Serbia_(1992%E2%80%932006)" title="Republic of Serbia (1992–2006)">Republic of Serbia (1992–2006)</a>, and <a href="/wiki/History_of_Serbia#Independent_Serbia_(2006–present)" title="History of Serbia">History of Serbia §&nbsp;Independent Serbia (2006–present)</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:332px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png/330px-Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png" decoding="async" width="330" height="217" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png/495px-Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png/660px-Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png 2x" data-file-width="1887" data-file-height="1242"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Former_Yugoslavia_wartime.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a> and territories of Serb breakaway states (<a href="/wiki/Republika_Srpska" title="Republika Srpska">Republika Srpska</a> and <a href="/wiki/Republika_Srpska_Krajina" class="mw-redirect" title="Republika Srpska Krajina">Republika Srpska Krajina</a>) during the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav wars">Yugoslav wars</a> (1991–95)
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>In 1989, <a href="/wiki/Slobodan_Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87" title="Slobodan Milošević">Slobodan Milošević</a> rose to power in Serbia. Milošević promised a reduction of powers for the autonomous provinces of Kosovo and Vojvodina, where his allies subsequently took over power, during the <a href="/wiki/Anti-bureaucratic_revolution" title="Anti-bureaucratic revolution">Anti-bureaucratic revolution</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[117]</a></sup> This ignited tensions between the communist leadership of the other republics of <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" title="Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>, and awoke ethnic nationalism across Yugoslavia that eventually resulted in its <a href="/wiki/Breakup_of_Yugoslavia" title="Breakup of Yugoslavia">breakup</a>, with <a href="/wiki/Slovenia" title="Slovenia">Slovenia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatia" title="Croatia">Croatia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Macedonia" class="mw-redirect" title="Republic of Macedonia">Macedonia</a> declaring independence during 1991 and 1992.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[118]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template noprint noexcerpt Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS" class="mw-redirect" title="Wikipedia:NOTRS"><span title="This claim needs references to better sources. (March 2017)">better&nbsp;source&nbsp;needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Serbia and Montenegro remained together as the <a href="/wiki/Federal_Republic_of_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="Federal Republic of Yugoslavia">Federal Republic of Yugoslavia</a> (FRY).<sup id="cite_ref-SCGSuccession_13-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SCGSuccession-13">[11]</a></sup> However, according to the <a href="/wiki/Arbitration_Commission_of_the_Peace_Conference_on_Yugoslavia" title="Arbitration Commission of the Peace Conference on Yugoslavia">Badinter Commission</a>, the country was not legally considered a continuation of the former SFRY, but a new state. </p>
      <p>Fueled by ethnic tensions, the <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars" title="Yugoslav Wars">Yugoslav Wars</a> (1991–2001) erupted, with the most severe conflicts taking place in <a href="/wiki/War_in_Croatia" class="mw-redirect" title="War in Croatia">Croatia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_War" title="Bosnian War">Bosnia</a>, where the large ethnic Serb communities opposed independence from Yugoslavia. The FRY remained outside the conflicts, but provided logistic, military and financial support to Serb forces in the wars. In response, the UN imposed <a href="/wiki/Sanctions_against_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Sanctions against Serbia">sanctions against Serbia</a> which led to political isolation and the collapse of the economy (GDP decreased from $24 billion in 1990 to under $10 billion in 1993). Following the rise of nationalism and political tensions after Slobodan Milošević came to power, numerous <a href="/wiki/Anti-war_movement" title="Anti-war movement">anti-war movements</a> developed in Serbia and many <a href="/wiki/1991%E2%80%931992_anti-war_protests_in_Belgrade" title="1991–1992 anti-war protests in Belgrade">anti-war protests</a> were held in Belgrade.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[119]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[120]</a></sup> Multi-party democracy was introduced in Serbia in 1990, officially dismantling the one-party system. Critics of Milošević stated that the government continued to be authoritarian despite constitutional changes, as Milošević maintained strong political influence over the state media and security apparatus.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[121]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[122]</a></sup> When the ruling <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Serbia" title="Socialist Party of Serbia">Socialist Party of Serbia</a> refused to accept its defeat in municipal elections in 1996, Serbians engaged in <a href="/wiki/1996%E2%80%931997_protests_in_Serbia" title="1996–1997 protests in Serbia">large protests</a> against the government. </p>
      <p>In 1998, <a href="/wiki/Insurgency_in_Kosovo_(1995%E2%80%9398)" title="Insurgency in Kosovo (1995–98)">continued clashes</a> between the Albanian guerilla <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_Liberation_Army" title="Kosovo Liberation Army">Kosovo Liberation Army</a> and Yugoslav security forces led to the short <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo War</a> (1998–99), in which <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> intervened, leading to the withdrawal of Serbian forces and the establishment of <a href="/wiki/UNMIK" class="mw-redirect" title="UNMIK">UN administration</a> in the province.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[123]</a></sup> After the Yugoslav Wars, Serbia became home to highest number of <a href="/wiki/Refugee" title="Refugee">refugees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Internally_displaced_person" title="Internally displaced person">internally displaced persons</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[124]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[125]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[126]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After <a href="/wiki/2000_Yugoslavian_general_election" title="2000 Yugoslavian general election">presidential elections</a> in September 2000, opposition parties accused Milošević of <a href="/wiki/Electoral_fraud" title="Electoral fraud">electoral fraud</a>. A campaign of <a href="/wiki/Civil_resistance" title="Civil resistance">civil resistance</a> followed, led by the <a href="/wiki/Democratic_Opposition_of_Serbia" title="Democratic Opposition of Serbia">Democratic Opposition of Serbia</a> (DOS), a broad coalition of anti-Milošević parties. This culminated on 5 October when half a million people from all over the country congregated in Belgrade, compelling Milošević to concede defeat.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[127]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Overthrow_of_Slobodan_Milo%C5%A1evi%C4%87" title="Overthrow of Slobodan Milošević">fall of Milošević</a> ended Yugoslavia's <a href="/wiki/International_isolation" title="International isolation">international isolation</a>. Milošević was sent to the <a href="/wiki/International_Criminal_Tribunal_for_the_former_Yugoslavia" title="International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia">International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia</a>. The DOS announced that FR Yugoslavia would seek to join the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>. In 2003, the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia was renamed <a href="/wiki/Serbia_and_Montenegro" title="Serbia and Montenegro">Serbia and Montenegro</a>;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMiller2005529–581_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMiller2005529–581-130">[128]</a></sup> the EU opened negotiations with the country for the <a href="/wiki/Stabilization_and_Association_Agreement" class="mw-redirect" title="Stabilization and Association Agreement">Stabilisation and Association Agreement</a>. Serbia's political climate remained tense and in 2003, the Prime Minister <a href="/wiki/Zoran_%C4%90in%C4%91i%C4%87" title="Zoran Đinđić">Zoran Đinđić</a> was <a href="/wiki/Assassination_of_Zoran_%C4%90in%C4%91i%C4%87" title="Assassination of Zoran Đinđić">assassinated</a> as result of a plot originating from circles of organised crime and former security officials. In 2004 <a href="/wiki/2004_unrest_in_Kosovo" title="2004 unrest in Kosovo">unrest in Kosovo</a> took place, leaving 19 people dead and a number of Serbian Orthodox churches and monasteries destroyed or damaged.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[129]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[130]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 21 May 2006, Montenegro held a <a href="/wiki/2006_Montenegrin_independence_referendum" title="2006 Montenegrin independence referendum">referendum</a> to determine whether to end its union with Serbia. The results showed 55.4% of voters in favour of independence, which was just above the 55% required by the referendum. On 5 June 2006, the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_of_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="National Assembly of Serbia">National Assembly of Serbia</a> declared Serbia to be the legal successor to the former state union.<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[131]</a></sup> The Assembly of Kosovo unilaterally declared independence from Serbia on 17 February 2008. Serbia immediately condemned the declaration and continues to deny any statehood to Kosovo. The declaration has sparked varied responses from the international community, some welcoming it, while others condemned the unilateral move.<sup id="cite_ref-New_York_Sun_134-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-New_York_Sun-134">[132]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Belgrade-Pristina_negotiations" class="mw-redirect" title="Belgrade-Pristina negotiations">Status-neutral talks</a> between Serbia and Kosovo-Albanian authorities are held in <a href="/wiki/Brussels" title="Brussels">Brussels</a>, mediated by the EU. </p>
      <p>In April 2008 Serbia was invited to join the <a href="/wiki/Intensified_Dialogue" class="mw-redirect" title="Intensified Dialogue">Intensified Dialogue</a> programme with <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, despite the diplomatic rift with the alliance over Kosovo.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[133]</a></sup> Serbia officially applied for membership in the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a> on 22 December 2009,<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[134]</a></sup> and received candidate status on 1 March 2012, following a delay in December 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-bbc_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bbc-137">[135]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[136]</a></sup> Following a positive recommendation of the <a href="/wiki/European_Commission" title="European Commission">European Commission</a> and <a href="/wiki/European_Council" title="European Council">European Council</a> in June 2013, negotiations to join the EU commenced in January 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[137]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since <a href="/wiki/Aleksandar_Vu%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Aleksandar Vučić">Aleksandar Vučić</a> came to power, Serbia has suffered from <a href="/wiki/Democratic_backsliding" title="Democratic backsliding">democratic backsliding</a> into <a href="/wiki/Authoritarianism" title="Authoritarianism">authoritarianism</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Freedom_House_2019_140-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Freedom_House_2019-140">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[140]</a></sup> followed by a decline in <a href="/wiki/Media_freedom_in_Serbia" title="Media freedom in Serbia">media freedom</a> and civil liberties.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[141]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[142]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Serbian_protests_(2018%E2%80%93present)" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian protests (2018–present)">Massive anti-government protests</a> began in 2018 and continued into 2020, making them one of Europe's longest-running protests.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[143]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic" title="COVID-19 pandemic">COVID-19 pandemic</a> spread <a href="/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Serbia" title="COVID-19 pandemic in Serbia">to Serbia</a> in March 2020, a <a href="/wiki/State_of_emergency" title="State of emergency">state of emergency</a> was declared and a <a href="/wiki/Curfew" title="Curfew">curfew</a> was introduced for the first time in Serbia since World War II.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[144]</a></sup> In January 2021 Serbia carried the second-fastest vaccine rollout in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[145]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[146]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Geography">Geography</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Geography_of_Serbia" title="Geography of Serbia">Geography of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:312px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serbien_topo.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Serbien_topo.png/310px-Serbien_topo.png" decoding="async" width="310" height="284" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Serbien_topo.png/465px-Serbien_topo.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Serbien_topo.png/620px-Serbien_topo.png 2x" data-file-width="1200" data-file-height="1100"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serbien_topo.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Topographic map
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Situated at the crossroads between Central<sup id="cite_ref-Serbia:_On_the_Way_to_EU_Accession_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serbia:_On_the_Way_to_EU_Accession-17">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[147]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[148]</a></sup> and Southern Europe, Serbia is located in the <a href="/wiki/Balkan_peninsula" class="mw-redirect" title="Balkan peninsula">Balkan peninsula</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Plain" class="mw-redirect" title="Pannonian Plain">Pannonian Plain</a>. Serbia lies between latitudes <a href="/wiki/41st_parallel_north" title="41st parallel north">41°</a> and <a href="/wiki/47th_parallel_north" title="47th parallel north">47° N</a>, and longitudes <a href="/wiki/18th_meridian_east" title="18th meridian east">18°</a> and <a href="/wiki/23rd_meridian_east" title="23rd meridian east">23° E</a>. The country covers a total of 88,361&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> (including Kosovo), which places it at <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_area" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries and outlying territories by area">113th</a> place in the world; with Kosovo excluded, the total area is 77,474&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup>,<sup id="cite_ref-cia_profile_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> which would make it 117th. Its total border length amounts to 2,027&nbsp;km (Albania 115&nbsp;km, Bosnia and Herzegovina 302&nbsp;km, Bulgaria 318&nbsp;km, Croatia 241&nbsp;km, Hungary 151&nbsp;km, North Macedonia 221&nbsp;km, Montenegro 203&nbsp;km and Romania 476&nbsp;km).<sup id="cite_ref-cia_profile_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> All of Kosovo's border with Albania (115&nbsp;km), North Macedonia (159&nbsp;km) and Montenegro (79&nbsp;km)<sup id="cite_ref-cia_kosovo_151-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cia_kosovo-151">[149]</a></sup> are under control of the Kosovo border police.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[150]</a></sup> Serbia treats the 352&nbsp;km long border between Kosovo and rest of Serbia as an "administrative line"; it is under shared control of Kosovo border police and Serbian police forces, and there are 11 crossing points.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[151]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Basin" title="Pannonian Basin">Pannonian Plain</a> covers the northern third of the country (<a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ma%C4%8Dva" title="Mačva">Mačva</a><sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[152]</a></sup>) while the easternmost tip of Serbia extends into the <a href="/wiki/Wallachian_Plain" title="Wallachian Plain">Wallachian Plain</a>. The terrain of the central part of the country, with the region of <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0umadija" title="Šumadija">Šumadija</a> at its heart, consists chiefly of hills traversed by rivers. Mountains dominate the southern third of Serbia. <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Alps" title="Dinaric Alps">Dinaric Alps</a> stretch in the west and the southwest, following the flow of the rivers <a href="/wiki/Drina" title="Drina">Drina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ibar_(river)" title="Ibar (river)">Ibar</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> and <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Mountains" title="Balkan Mountains">Balkan Mountains</a> stretch in a north–south direction in eastern Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[153]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Ancient mountains in the southeast corner of the country belong to the <a href="/wiki/Rhodopes" class="mw-redirect" title="Rhodopes">Rilo-Rhodope Mountain</a> system. Elevation ranges from the <a href="/wiki/Mid%C5%BEor" title="Midžor">Midžor</a> peak of the Balkan Mountains at 2,169 metres (7,116 feet) (the highest peak in Serbia, excluding Kosovo) to the lowest point of just 17 metres (56 feet) near the Danube river at <a href="/wiki/Prahovo" title="Prahovo">Prahovo</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[154]</a></sup> The largest lake is <a href="/wiki/%C4%90erdap_Lake" class="mw-redirect" title="Đerdap Lake">Đerdap Lake</a> (163 square kilometres) and the longest river passing through Serbia is the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> (587.35 kilometres). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Climate">Climate</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Climate_of_Serbia" title="Climate of Serbia">Climate of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The climate of Serbia is under the influences of the landmass of Eurasia and the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean" title="Atlantic Ocean">Atlantic Ocean</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mediterranean_Sea" title="Mediterranean Sea">Mediterranean Sea</a>. With mean January temperatures around 0&nbsp;°C (32&nbsp;°F), and mean July temperatures of 22&nbsp;°C (72&nbsp;°F), it can be classified as a <a href="/wiki/Humid_continental_climate" title="Humid continental climate">warm-humid continental</a> or <a href="/wiki/Humid_subtropical_climate" title="Humid subtropical climate">humid subtropical climate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[155]</a></sup> In the north, the climate is more continental, with cold winters, and hot, humid summers along with well-distributed rainfall patterns. In the south, summers and autumns are drier, and winters are relatively cold, with heavy inland snowfall in the mountains. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Stara_planina14.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Stara_planina14.jpg/220px-Stara_planina14.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Stara_planina14.jpg/330px-Stara_planina14.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/81/Stara_planina14.jpg/440px-Stara_planina14.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3602" data-file-height="2401"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Stara_planina14.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Landscapes in <a href="/wiki/Balkan_Mountains" title="Balkan Mountains">Stara Planina</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Differences in elevation, proximity to the Adriatic Sea and large river basins, as well as exposure to the winds account for climate variations.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[156]</a></sup> Southern Serbia is subject to Mediterranean influences.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[157]</a></sup> The Dinaric Alps and other mountain ranges contribute to the cooling of most of the warm air masses. Winters are quite harsh in the <a href="/wiki/Pe%C5%A1ter" title="Pešter">Pešter</a> plateau, because of the mountains which encircle it.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[158]</a></sup> One of the climatic features of Serbia is <a href="/wiki/Ko%C5%A1ava_(wind)" title="Košava (wind)">Košava</a>, a cold and very <a href="/wiki/Squall" title="Squall">squally</a> southeastern wind which starts in the <a href="/wiki/Carpathian_Mountains" title="Carpathian Mountains">Carpathian Mountains</a> and follows the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> northwest through the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Gate_(Danube)" class="mw-redirect" title="Iron Gate (Danube)">Iron Gate</a> where it gains a <a href="/wiki/Mountain_jet" title="Mountain jet">jet effect</a> and continues to <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a> and can spread as far south as <a href="/wiki/Ni%C5%A1" title="Niš">Niš</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-AMS_161-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-AMS-161">[159]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The average annual air temperature for the period 1961–1990 for the area with an altitude of up to 300&nbsp;m (984&nbsp;ft) is 10.9&nbsp;°C (51.6&nbsp;°F). The areas with an altitude of 300 to 500&nbsp;m (984 to 1,640&nbsp;ft) have an average annual temperature of around 10.0&nbsp;°C (50.0&nbsp;°F), and over 1,000&nbsp;m (3,281&nbsp;ft) of altitude around 6.0&nbsp;°C (42.8&nbsp;°F).<sup id="cite_ref-RHMZ_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-RHMZ-162">[160]</a></sup> The lowest recorded temperature in Serbia was −39.5&nbsp;°C (−39.1&nbsp;°F) on 13 January 1985, <a href="/wiki/Karajuki%C4%87a_Bunari" title="Karajukića Bunari">Karajukića Bunari</a> in Pešter, and the highest was 44.9&nbsp;°C (112.8&nbsp;°F), on 24 July 2007, recorded in <a href="/wiki/Smederevska_Palanka" title="Smederevska Palanka">Smederevska Palanka</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[161]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia is one of few European countries with <i>very high risk</i> exposure to natural hazards (earthquakes, storms, floods, droughts).<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[162]</a></sup> It is estimated that potential floods, particularly in areas of Central Serbia, threaten over 500 larger settlements and an area of 16,000 square kilometres.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[163]</a></sup> The most disastrous were the <a href="/wiki/2014_Southeast_Europe_floods" title="2014 Southeast Europe floods">floods in May 2014</a>, when 57 people died and a damage of over a 1.5 billion euro was inflicted.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[164]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hydrology">Hydrology</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       For a more comprehensive list, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_rivers_of_Serbia" title="List of rivers of Serbia">List of rivers of Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/List_of_lakes_of_Serbia" title="List of lakes of Serbia">List of lakes of Serbia</a>.
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Veliki_Kazan.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Veliki_Kazan.jpg/220px-Veliki_Kazan.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="127" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Veliki_Kazan.jpg/330px-Veliki_Kazan.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Veliki_Kazan.jpg/440px-Veliki_Kazan.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5000" data-file-height="2887"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Veliki_Kazan.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Iron_Gates" title="Iron Gates">Iron Gates</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Almost all of Serbia's rivers drain to the <a href="/wiki/Black_Sea" title="Black Sea">Black Sea</a>, by way of the Danube river. The <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a>, the second largest European river, passes through Serbia with 588 kilometres<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[165]</a></sup> (21% of its overall length) and represents the major source of fresh water.<sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[166]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[167]</a></sup> It is joined by its biggest tributaries, the <a href="/wiki/Great_Morava" title="Great Morava">Great Morava</a> (longest river entirely in Serbia with 493&nbsp;km of length<sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[168]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">Sava</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tisza" title="Tisza">Tisza</a> rivers.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[169]</a></sup> One notable exception is the <a href="/wiki/P%C4%8Dinja_(river)" title="Pčinja (river)">Pčinja</a> which flows into the <a href="/wiki/Aegean_Sea" title="Aegean Sea">Aegean</a>. <a href="/wiki/Drina" title="Drina">Drina</a> river forms the natural border between <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a> and Serbia, and represents the main <a href="/wiki/Kayaking" title="Kayaking">kayaking</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rafting" title="Rafting">rafting</a> attraction in both countries. </p>
      <p>Due to configuration of the terrain, natural lakes are sparse and small; most of them are located in the lowlands of Vojvodina, like the aeolian lake <a href="/wiki/Pali%C4%87_lake" class="mw-redirect" title="Palić lake">Palić</a> or numerous <a href="/wiki/Oxbow_lake" title="Oxbow lake">oxbow lakes</a> along river flows (like <a href="/wiki/Zasavica_(river)" title="Zasavica (river)">Zasavica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Carska_Bara" title="Carska Bara">Carska Bara</a>). However, there are numerous <a href="/wiki/Artificial_lake" class="mw-redirect" title="Artificial lake">artificial lakes</a>, mostly due to hydroelectric dams, the biggest being <a href="/wiki/Iron_Gate_(Danube)" class="mw-redirect" title="Iron Gate (Danube)">Đerdap (Iron Gates)</a> on the Danube with 163&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> on the Serbian side<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[170]</a></sup> (a total area of 253&nbsp;km<sup>2</sup> is shared with Romania); <a href="/wiki/Peru%C4%87ac" title="Perućac">Perućac</a> on the Drina, and <a href="/wiki/Vlasina_Lake" title="Vlasina Lake">Vlasina</a>. The largest waterfall, <a href="/wiki/Jelovarnik" title="Jelovarnik">Jelovarnik</a>, located in Kopaonik, is 71 m high.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup> Abundance of relatively unpolluted surface waters and numerous underground natural and mineral water sources of high <a href="/wiki/Water_quality" title="Water quality">water quality</a> presents a chance for export and economy improvement; however, more extensive exploitation and production of bottled water began only recently. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Environment">Environment</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/List_of_protected_natural_resources_in_Serbia" title="List of protected natural resources in Serbia">List of protected natural resources in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Banjska_stena77.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Banjska_stena77.jpg/220px-Banjska_stena77.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Banjska_stena77.jpg/330px-Banjska_stena77.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4b/Banjska_stena77.jpg/440px-Banjska_stena77.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2400" data-file-height="1600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Banjska_stena77.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Picea_omorika" title="Picea omorika">Picea omorika</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Species" title="Species">species</a> of <a href="/wiki/Pinophyta" title="Pinophyta">coniferous tree</a> <a href="/wiki/Endemic_(ecology)" class="mw-redirect" title="Endemic (ecology)">endemic</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Tara_(mountain)" title="Tara (mountain)">Tara</a> mountain in western Serbia
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia contains four terrestrial ecoregions: <a href="/wiki/Balkan_mixed_forests" title="Balkan mixed forests">Balkan mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dinaric_Mountains_mixed_forests" title="Dinaric Mountains mixed forests">Dinaric Mountains mixed forests</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_mixed_forests" title="Pannonian mixed forests">Pannonian mixed forests</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Rodope_montane_mixed_forests" title="Rodope montane mixed forests">Rodope montane mixed forests</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DinersteinOlson2017_174-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DinersteinOlson2017-174">[172]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>With 29.1% of its territory covered by forest, Serbia is considered to be a middle-forested country, compared on a global scale to world forest coverage at 30%, and European average of 35%. The total forest area in Serbia is 2,252,000 ha (1,194,000 ha or 53% are state-owned, and 1,058,387 ha or 47% are privately owned) or 0.3 ha per inhabitant.<sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[173]</a></sup> It had a 2019 <a href="/wiki/Forest_Landscape_Integrity_Index" title="Forest Landscape Integrity Index">Forest Landscape Integrity Index</a> mean score of 5.29/10, ranking it 105th globally out of 172 countries.<sup id="cite_ref-FLII-Supplementary_176-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FLII-Supplementary-176">[174]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The most common trees are oak, beech, pines, and firs. Serbia is a country of rich ecosystem and species diversity—covering only 1.9% of the whole European territory, Serbia is home to 39% of European vascular flora, 51% of European fish fauna, 40% of European reptiles and amphibian fauna, 74% of European bird fauna, and 67% European mammal fauna.<sup id="cite_ref-iucn.org_177-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iucn.org-177">[175]</a></sup> Its abundance of mountains and rivers make it an ideal environment for a variety of animals, many of which are protected including wolves, lynx, bears, foxes, and stags. There are 17 snake species living all over the country, 8 of them are venomous.<sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[176]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Mountain of <a href="/wiki/Tara_(mountain)" title="Tara (mountain)">Tara</a> in western Serbia is one of the last regions in Europe where bears can still live in absolute freedom.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[177]</a></sup> Serbia is home home to about 380 species of birds. In <a href="/wiki/Carska_Bara" title="Carska Bara">Carska Bara</a>, there are over 300 bird species on just a few square kilometres.<sup id="cite_ref-180" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-180">[178]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Uvac" title="Uvac">Uvac Gorge</a> is considered one of the last habitats of the <a href="/wiki/Griffon_vulture" title="Griffon vulture">Griffon vulture</a> in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[179]</a></sup> In area around the city of <a href="/wiki/Kikinda" title="Kikinda">Kikinda</a>, in the northernmost part of the country, some 145 endangered <a href="/wiki/Long-eared_owl" title="Long-eared owl">long-eared owls</a> are noted, making it the world's biggest settlement of these species.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[180]</a></sup> The country is considerably rich with threatened species of bats and butterflies as well.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[181]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are 380 <a href="/wiki/List_of_protected_natural_resources_in_Serbia" title="List of protected natural resources in Serbia">protected areas of Serbia</a>, encompassing 4,947 square kilometres or 6.4% of the country. The "Spatial plan of the Republic of Serbia" states that the total protected area should be increased to 12% by 2021.<sup id="cite_ref-iucn.org_177-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-iucn.org-177">[175]</a></sup> Those protected areas include 5 national parks (<a href="/wiki/%C4%90erdap_National_Park" class="mw-redirect" title="Đerdap National Park">Đerdap</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tara_(mountain)" title="Tara (mountain)">Tara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kopaonik" title="Kopaonik">Kopaonik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fru%C5%A1ka_Gora" title="Fruška Gora">Fruška Gora</a> and <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0ar_Mountain" class="mw-redirect" title="Šar Mountain">Šar Mountain</a>), 15 <a href="/wiki/Nature_park" title="Nature park">nature parks</a>, 15 "landscapes of outstanding features", 61 nature reserves, and 281 natural monuments.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg/220px-Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="105" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg/330px-Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg/440px-Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3101" data-file-height="1473"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Uvac_River_and_Eagle.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Uvac" title="Uvac">Uvac Gorge</a>, one of the last habitats of the <a href="/wiki/Griffon_vulture" title="Griffon vulture">griffon vulture</a> in Europe
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Air pollution is a significant problem in <a href="/wiki/Bor,_Serbia" title="Bor, Serbia">Bor</a> area, due to work of large copper mining and smelting complex, and <a href="/wiki/Pan%C4%8Devo" title="Pančevo">Pančevo</a> where oil and <a href="/wiki/Petrochemical_industry" title="Petrochemical industry">petrochemical industry</a> is based.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[182]</a></sup> Some cities suffer from water supply problems, due to mismanagement and low investments in the past, as well as water pollution (like the pollution of the <a href="/wiki/Ibar_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Ibar River">Ibar River</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Trep%C4%8Da_Mines" title="Trepča Mines">Trepča</a> <a href="/wiki/Zinc" title="Zinc">zinc</a>-lead combinate,<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[183]</a></sup> affecting the city of <a href="/wiki/Kraljevo" title="Kraljevo">Kraljevo</a>, or the presence of natural <a href="/wiki/Arsenic" title="Arsenic">arsenic</a> in underground waters in <a href="/wiki/Zrenjanin" title="Zrenjanin">Zrenjanin</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[184]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Poor waste management has been identified as one of the most important environmental problems in Serbia and the <a href="/wiki/Recycling" title="Recycling">recycling</a> is a fledgling activity, with only 15% of its waste being turned back for reuse.<sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[185]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia" title="NATO bombing of Yugoslavia">1999 NATO bombing</a> caused serious damage to the environment, with several thousand tonnes of toxic chemicals stored in targeted factories and refineries released into the soil and water basins.<sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[186]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Politics">Politics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Politics_of_Serbia" title="Politics of Serbia">Politics of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia is a <a href="/wiki/Parliamentary_republic" title="Parliamentary republic">parliamentary republic</a>, with the government divided into legislative, executive, and judiciary branches. Serbia had one of the first modern constitutions in Europe, the 1835 Constitution (known as the <a href="/wiki/Sretenje_Constitution" title="Sretenje Constitution">Sretenje Constitution</a>), which was at the time considered among the most progressive and liberal constitutions in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[188]</a></sup> Since then it has adopted 10 different constitutions.<sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[189]</a></sup> The current constitution was adopted in 2006 in the aftermath of <a href="/wiki/2006_Montenegrin_independence_referendum" title="2006 Montenegrin independence referendum">Montenegro independence referendum</a> which by consequence renewed the independence of Serbia itself.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[190]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Court_of_Serbia" title="Constitutional Court of Serbia">Constitutional Court</a> rules on matters regarding the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Serbia" title="Constitution of Serbia">Constitution</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left:auto;margin-right:auto;overflow:hidden;width:auto;max-width:608px">
       <div class="thumbinner">
        <div class="noresize" style="overflow:auto">
         <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg" class="image" title="House of the National Assembly"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg/600px-%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg" decoding="async" width="600" height="252" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg/900px-%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg/1200px-%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4614" data-file-height="1940"></a>
        </div>
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:%D0%94%D0%BE%D0%BC_%D0%9D%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D0%BA%D1%83%D0%BF%D1%88%D1%82%D0%B8%D0%BD%D0%B5_%D0%A1%D1%80%D0%B1%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B5.jpg" title="File:Дом Народне Скупштине Србије.jpg"> </a>
         </div>
         <center>
          <a href="/wiki/House_of_the_National_Assembly_of_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="House of the National Assembly of Serbia">House of the National Assembly</a>
         </center>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/President_of_Serbia" title="President of Serbia">President of the Republic</a> (<i>Predsednik Republike</i>) is the <a href="/wiki/Head_of_state" title="Head of state">head of state</a>, is elected by popular vote to a five-year term and is limited by the Constitution to a maximum of two terms. In addition to being the <a href="/wiki/Commander_in_chief" class="mw-redirect" title="Commander in chief">commander in chief</a> of the armed forces, the president has the procedural duty of appointing the prime minister with the consent of the parliament, and has some influence on foreign policy.<sup id="cite_ref-President_193-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-President-193">[191]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aleksandar_Vu%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Aleksandar Vučić">Aleksandar Vučić</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Progressive_Party" title="Serbian Progressive Party">Serbian Progressive Party</a> is the current president following the 2017 presidential election.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[192]</a></sup> Seat of the presidency is <a href="/wiki/Andri%C4%87ev_Venac" title="Andrićev Venac">Novi Dvor</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Government_of_Serbia" title="Government of Serbia">Government</a> (<i>Vlada</i>) is composed of the <a href="/wiki/Prime_Minister_of_Serbia" title="Prime Minister of Serbia">prime minister</a> and cabinet ministers. The Government is responsible for proposing legislation and a budget, executing the laws, and guiding the foreign and internal policies. The current prime minister is <a href="/wiki/Ana_Brnabi%C4%87" title="Ana Brnabić">Ana Brnabić</a>, nominated by the Serbian Progressive Party.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Parliament of Serbia">National Assembly</a> (<i>Narodna skupština</i>) is a <a href="/wiki/Unicameral" class="mw-redirect" title="Unicameral">unicameral</a> legislative body. The National Assembly has the power to enact laws, approve the budget, schedule presidential elections, select and dismiss the Prime Minister and other ministers, declare war, and ratify international treaties and agreements.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[194]</a></sup> It is composed of 250 <a href="/wiki/Proportional_representation" title="Proportional representation">proportionally</a> elected members who serve four-year terms. </p>
      <p>Since 2020, the largest political parties in Serbia by parliamentary seats are the populist <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Progressive_Party" title="Serbian Progressive Party">Serbian Progressive Party</a>, leftist <a href="/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Serbia" title="Socialist Party of Serbia">Socialist Party of Serbia</a> and the national-conservative <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Patriotic_Alliance" title="Serbian Patriotic Alliance">Serbian Patriotic Alliance</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[195]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2021 Serbia was the 5th country in Europe by the number of women holding high-ranking public functions.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[196]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Law_and_criminal_justice">Law and criminal justice</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Law_of_Serbia" title="Law of Serbia">Law of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia is the fourth modern-day European country, after <a href="/wiki/France" title="France">France</a>, <a href="/wiki/Austria" title="Austria">Austria</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Netherlands" title="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, to have a codified legal system.<sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[197]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The country has a three-tiered judicial system, made up of the <a href="/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_Cassation_(Serbia)" title="Supreme Court of Cassation (Serbia)">Supreme Court of Cassation</a> as the court of the last resort, <a href="/wiki/Court_of_Appeal" class="mw-redirect" title="Court of Appeal">Courts of Appeal</a> as the appellate instance, and Basic and High courts as the general jurisdictions at first instance.<sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[199]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Courts of special jurisdictions are the Administrative Court, commercial courts (including the Commercial Court of Appeal at second instance) and misdemeanor courts (including High Misdemeanor Court at second instance).<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[200]</a></sup> The judiciary is overseen by the Ministry of Justice. Serbia has a typical <a href="/wiki/Civil_law_(legal_system)" title="Civil law (legal system)">civil law</a> legal system. </p>
      <p>Law enforcement is the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Police_of_Serbia" title="Police of Serbia">Serbian Police</a>, which is subordinate to the Ministry of the Interior. Serbian Police fields 27,363 uniformed officers.<sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[201]</a></sup> National security and counterintelligence are the responsibility of the <a href="/wiki/Security_Intelligence_Agency" title="Security Intelligence Agency">Security Intelligence Agency (BIA)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[202]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_relations">Foreign relations</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Foreign_relations_of_Serbia" title="Foreign relations of Serbia">Foreign relations of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Accession_of_Serbia_to_the_European_Union" title="Accession of Serbia to the European Union">Accession of Serbia to the European Union</a> and <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Kosovo" title="Political status of Kosovo">Political status of Kosovo</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg/240px-CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg.png" decoding="async" width="240" height="109" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg/360px-CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0d/CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg/480px-CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="1650" data-file-height="750"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:CountriesRecognizingKosovo.svg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r981673959">.mw-parser-output .legend{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .legend-color{display:inline-block;min-width:1.25em;height:1.25em;line-height:1.25;margin:1px 0;text-align:center;border:1px solid black;background-color:transparent;color:black}.mw-parser-output .legend-text{}</style>
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:grey; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;States which recognize the Province of Kosovo as an integral part of Serbia
         </div>
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:green; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;States which recognize Kosovo as an independent country
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia has established diplomatic relations with 191 <a href="/wiki/UN_member_states" class="mw-redirect" title="UN member states">UN member states</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Holy_See" title="Holy See">Holy See</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Sovereign_Military_Order_of_Malta" title="Sovereign Military Order of Malta">Sovereign Military Order of Malta</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/European_Union" title="European Union">European Union</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-DList_205-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DList-205">[203]</a></sup> Foreign relations are conducted through the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Serbia has a network of 65 embassies and 23 consulates internationally.<sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[204]</a></sup> There are 69 <a href="/wiki/List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Serbia" title="List of diplomatic missions in Serbia">foreign embassies</a>, 5 consulates and 4 liaison offices in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[205]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[206]</a></sup> Serbian foreign policy is focused on achieving the strategic goal of becoming a <a href="/wiki/Member_state_of_the_European_Union" title="Member state of the European Union">member state of the European Union</a> (EU). Serbia started the process of joining the EU by signing of the <a href="/wiki/Stabilisation_and_Association_Process" title="Stabilisation and Association Process">Stabilisation and Association Agreement</a> on 29 April 2008 and officially applied for membership in the European Union on 22 December 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[207]</a></sup> It received a full <a href="/wiki/Future_enlargement_of_the_European_Union#Recognised_candidates" class="mw-redirect" title="Future enlargement of the European Union">candidate status</a> on 1 March 2012 and started <a href="/wiki/Enlargement_of_the_EU" class="mw-redirect" title="Enlargement of the EU">accession talks</a> on 21 January 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-Council_of_the_EU_210-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Council_of_the_EU-210">[208]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-211" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-211">[209]</a></sup> The European Commission considers accession possible by 2025.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[210]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On 17 February 2008, Kosovo unilaterally <a href="/wiki/2008_Kosovo_declaration_of_independence" title="2008 Kosovo declaration of independence">declared independence</a> from Serbia. In protest, Serbia initially recalled its ambassadors from countries that recognised Kosovo's independence.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[211]</a></sup> The resolution of 26 December 2007 by the <a href="/wiki/National_Assembly_(Serbia)" title="National Assembly (Serbia)">National Assembly</a> stated that both the <a href="/wiki/2008_Kosovo_declaration_of_independence" title="2008 Kosovo declaration of independence">Kosovo declaration of independence</a> and recognition thereof by any state would be gross violation of international law.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[212]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia began cooperation and dialogue with <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> in 2006, when the country joined the <a href="/wiki/Partnership_for_Peace" title="Partnership for Peace">Partnership for Peace</a> programme and the <a href="/wiki/Euro-Atlantic_Partnership_Council" title="Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council">Euro-Atlantic Partnership Council</a>. The country's military neutrality was formally proclaimed by a resolution adopted by Serbia's parliament in December 2007, which makes joining any military alliance contingent on a popular referendum,<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[213]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[214]</a></sup> a stance acknowledged by NATO.<sup id="cite_ref-natorelations_217-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natorelations-217">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[216]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[217]</a></sup> On the other hand, Serbia's relations with Russia are habitually described by mass media as a "centuries-old religious, ethnic and political alliance"<sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[218]</a></sup> and Russia is said to have sought to solidify <a href="/wiki/Russia%E2%80%93Serbia_relations" title="Russia–Serbia relations">its relationship with Serbia</a> since the imposition of <a href="/wiki/International_sanctions_during_the_Ukrainian_crisis" title="International sanctions during the Ukrainian crisis">sanctions against Russia</a> in 2014.<sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[219]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military">Military</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Armed_Forces" title="Serbian Armed Forces">Serbian Armed Forces</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_history_of_Serbia" title="Military history of Serbia">Military history of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg/220px-MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="154" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg/330px-MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg/440px-MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1440" data-file-height="1008"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:MiG-29_RV_i_PVO_VS_-_Odbrana_slobode_2019_Ni%C5%A1_15.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Serbian_Air_Force" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Air Force">Serbian Air Force</a> <a href="/wiki/MiG-29" class="mw-redirect" title="MiG-29">MiG-29 fighter</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Serbian Armed Forces are subordinate to the <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Defence_(Serbia)" title="Ministry of Defence (Serbia)">Ministry of Defence</a>, and are composed of the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Army" title="Serbian Army">Army</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Air_Force_and_Air_Defence" title="Serbian Air Force and Air Defence">Air Force</a>. Although a <a href="/wiki/Landlocked_country" title="Landlocked country">landlocked country</a>, Serbia operates a <a href="/wiki/Serbian_River_Flotilla" title="Serbian River Flotilla">River Flotilla</a> which patrols on the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">Sava</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Tisza" title="Tisza">Tisza</a> rivers. The Serbian <a href="/wiki/Chief_of_the_General_Staff_(Serbia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Chief of the General Staff (Serbia)">Chief of the General Staff</a> reports to the Defence Minister. The Chief of Staff is appointed by the <a href="/wiki/President_of_Serbia" title="President of Serbia">President</a>, who is the <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">Commander-in-chief</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-President_193-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-President-193">[191]</a></sup> As of 2019<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Serbia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, Serbian defence budget amounts to $804 million.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[220]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Traditionally having relied on a large number of conscripts, Serbian Armed Forces went through a period of downsizing, restructuring and <a href="/wiki/Professionalisation" class="mw-redirect" title="Professionalisation">professionalisation</a>. <a href="/wiki/Conscription" title="Conscription">Conscription</a> was abolished in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[221]</a></sup> Serbian Armed Forces have 28,000 active troops,<sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[222]</a></sup> supplemented by the "active reserve" which numbers 20,000 members and "passive reserve" with about 170,000.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[224]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia participates in the <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a> <a href="/wiki/Individual_Partnership_Action_Plan" title="Individual Partnership Action Plan">Individual Partnership Action Plan</a> programme,<sup id="cite_ref-natorelations_217-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-natorelations-217">[215]</a></sup> but has no intention of joining <a href="/wiki/NATO" title="NATO">NATO</a>, due to significant popular rejection, largely a legacy of the <a href="/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia" title="NATO bombing of Yugoslavia">NATO bombing of Yugoslavia</a> in 1999.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[225]</a></sup> It is an observer member of the Collective Securities Treaty Organisation (CSTO)<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[226]</a></sup> The country also signed the <a href="/wiki/Stability_Pact_for_South_Eastern_Europe" class="mw-redirect" title="Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe">Stability Pact for South Eastern Europe</a>. The Serbian Armed Forces take part in several multinational peacekeeping missions, including deployments in <a href="/wiki/Lebanon" title="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cyprus" title="Cyprus">Cyprus</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ivory_Coast" title="Ivory Coast">Ivory Coast</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Liberia" title="Liberia">Liberia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[227]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia is a major producer and exporter of military equipment in the region. Defence exports totaled around $600 million in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-230" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-230">[228]</a></sup> The defence industry has seen significant growth over the years and it continues to grow on a yearly basis.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[229]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[230]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Administrative_divisions">Administrative divisions</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Administrative_divisions_of_Serbia" title="Administrative divisions of Serbia">Administrative divisions of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia is a <a href="/wiki/Unitary_state" title="Unitary state">unitary state</a><sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[231]</a></sup> composed of <a href="/wiki/Municipalities_of_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Municipalities of Serbia">municipalities</a>/<a href="/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Serbia" title="List of cities in Serbia">cities</a>, districts, and two autonomous provinces. In Serbia, excluding Kosovo, there are 145 municipalities (<i>opštine</i>) and 29 cities (<i>gradovi</i>), which form the basic units of local self-government.<sup id="cite_ref-zakon_234-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zakon-234">[232]</a></sup> Apart from municipalities/cities, there are 24 <a href="/wiki/List_of_districts_of_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="List of districts of Serbia">districts</a> (<i>okruzi</i>, 10 most populated listed below), with the City of Belgrade constituting an additional district. Except for Belgrade, which has an elected local government, districts are regional centres of state authority, but have no powers of their own; they present purely administrative divisions.<sup id="cite_ref-zakon_234-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zakon-234">[232]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Serbia" title="Constitution of Serbia">Constitution of Serbia</a> recognizes two autonomous provinces, <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a> in the north, and the <a href="/wiki/Political_status_of_Kosovo" title="Political status of Kosovo">disputed</a> territory of <a href="/wiki/Autonomous_Province_of_Kosovo_and_Metohija" title="Autonomous Province of Kosovo and Metohija">Kosovo and Metohija</a> in the south,<sup id="cite_ref-zakon_234-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-zakon-234">[232]</a></sup> while the remaining area of <a href="/wiki/Central_Serbia" title="Central Serbia">Central Serbia</a> never had its own regional authority. Following the <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_War" title="Kosovo War">Kosovo War</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Interim_Administration_Mission_in_Kosovo" title="United Nations Interim Administration Mission in Kosovo">UN peacekeepers</a> entered Kosovo and Metohija, as per <a href="/wiki/UN_Security_Council_Resolution_1244" class="mw-redirect" title="UN Security Council Resolution 1244">UNSC Resolution 1244</a>. The government of Serbia does not recognise Kosovo's February 2008 declaration of declaration, considering it illegal and illegitimate.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[233]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table style="margin:auto;" cellpadding="10"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr>

      </table> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Demographics_of_Serbia" title="Demographics of Serbia">Demographics of Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Demographic_history_of_Serbia" title="Demographic history of Serbia">Demographic history of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>As of 2011<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Serbia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup> census, Serbia (excluding Kosovo) has a total population of 7,186,862 and the overall <a href="/wiki/List_of_sovereign_states_and_dependent_territories_by_population_density" class="mw-redirect" title="List of sovereign states and dependent territories by population density">population density</a> is medium as it stands at 92.8 inhabitants per square kilometre.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[234]</a></sup> The census was not conducted in <a href="/wiki/Kosovo" title="Kosovo">Kosovo</a> which held its own census that numbered their total population at 1,739,825,<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[235]</a></sup> excluding Serb-inhabited <a href="/wiki/North_Kosovo" title="North Kosovo">North Kosovo</a>, as <a href="/wiki/Serbs_of_Kosovo" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbs of Kosovo">Serbs</a> from that area (about 50,000) boycotted the census. </p> 
      <div class="barbox tleft" style="overflow-x: auto;"> 
       <div style="border:1px solid silver; font-size:88%; padding:0.4em; width:230px; background: white;"> 
        <table style="text-align:left; border-collapse:collapse; width:100%;"> 
         <tbody>
          <tr style="background:#ddd">
           <th style="text-align:center;" colspan="5">Ethnic composition (2011)</th>
          </tr> 
          <tr style="font-size:88%; height:4px;"> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td style="width:100px; text-align:left;"></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding:0 4px; width:1em; text-align:right;"></td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Serbs</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:blue; width:83.3%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td>

          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Hungarians</td>

            <div style="background:orange; width:3.5%; overflow: hidden;">

          </tr> 
          <tr>

            <div style="background:yellow; width:2.1%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td>

          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Bosniaks</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:green; width:2%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">2%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Croats</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:red; width:0.8%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.8%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Slovaks</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:black; width:0.7%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">0.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Other</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:purple; width:4.7%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">4.7%</td> 
          </tr> 
          <tr> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; min-width: 8em;">Unspecified/Unknown</td> 
           <td style="width: 100px; border-left: solid 1px silver; border-right: solid 1px silver;">
            <div style="background:gray; width:3.3%; overflow: hidden;">
              
            </div></td> 
           <td colspan="2" style="padding-left: 0.4em; padding-right: 0.4em; text-align: right;">3.3%</td> 
          </tr> 
         </tbody>
        </table> 
       </div> 
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia has been enduring a demographic crisis since the beginning of the 1990s, with a <a href="/wiki/Death_rate" class="mw-redirect" title="Death rate">death rate</a> that has continuously exceeded its <a href="/wiki/Birth_rate" title="Birth rate">birth rate</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[236]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[237]</a></sup> It is estimated that 300,000 people left Serbia during the 1990s, 20% of whom had a higher education.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[238]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-survey_241-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-survey-241">[239]</a></sup> Serbia subsequently has one of the oldest populations in the world, with the average age of 42.9 years,<sup id="cite_ref-stat.gov.rs_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stat.gov.rs-2">[2]</a></sup> and its population is shrinking at one of the fastest rates in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[240]</a></sup> A fifth of all households consist of only one person, and just one-fourth of four and more persons.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[241]</a></sup> Average <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_life_expectancy" title="List of countries by life expectancy">life expectancy in Serbia</a> at birth is 76.1 years.<sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[242]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the 1990s, Serbia had the largest refugee population in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[243]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Refugees" class="mw-redirect" title="Refugees">Refugees</a> and <a href="/wiki/Internally_displaced_person" title="Internally displaced person">internally displaced persons</a> (IDPs) in Serbia formed between 7% and 7.5% of its population at the time – about half a million refugees sought refuge in the country following the series of <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_wars" class="mw-redirect" title="Yugoslav wars">Yugoslav wars</a>, mainly from Croatia (and to a lesser extent from Bosnia and Herzegovina) and the IDPs from Kosovo.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[244]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Serbs" title="Serbs">Serbs</a> with 5,988,150 are the largest ethnic group in Serbia, representing 83% of the total population (excluding Kosovo). Serbia is one of the European countries with high numbers of registered national minorities, while the province of <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a> is recognizable for its <a href="/wiki/Multinational_state" title="Multinational state">multi-ethnic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Multiculturalism" title="Multiculturalism">multi-cultural</a> identity.<sup id="cite_ref-Gov_on_Slovakia_national_minority_247-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Gov_on_Slovakia_national_minority-247">[245]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Taylor_&amp;_Francis_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Taylor_&amp;_Francis-248">[246]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Filep_Politics_of_Good_Neighbourhood_p._71_249-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Filep_Politics_of_Good_Neighbourhood_p._71-249">[247]</a></sup> With a population of 253,899, <a href="/wiki/Hungarians_in_Serbia" title="Hungarians in Serbia">Hungarians</a> are the largest ethnic minority in Serbia, concentrated predominantly in northern Vojvodina and representing 3.5% of the country's population (13% in Vojvodina). Romani population stands at 147,604 according to the 2011 census but unofficial estimates place their actual number between 400,000 and 500,000.<sup id="cite_ref-250" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-250">[248]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks_of_Serbia" title="Bosniaks of Serbia">Bosniaks</a> with 145,278 are concentrated in <a href="/wiki/Sand%C5%BEak" title="Sandžak">Raška (Sandžak)</a>, in the southwest. Other minority groups include <a href="/wiki/Croats_of_Serbia" title="Croats of Serbia">Croats</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovaks_in_Serbia" title="Slovaks in Serbia">Slovaks</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albanians_in_Serbia" title="Albanians in Serbia">Albanians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Montenegrins_of_Serbia" title="Montenegrins of Serbia">Montenegrins</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vlachs_of_Serbia" title="Vlachs of Serbia">Vlachs</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanians_in_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Romanians in Serbia">Romanians</a>, <a href="/wiki/Macedonians_in_Serbia" title="Macedonians in Serbia">Macedonians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians_in_Serbia" title="Bulgarians in Serbia">Bulgarians</a>. <a href="/wiki/Chinese_people_in_Serbia" title="Chinese people in Serbia">Chinese</a>, estimated at about 15,000, are the only significant non-European <a href="/wiki/Immigrant" class="mw-redirect" title="Immigrant">immigrant</a> minority.<sup id="cite_ref-251" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-251">[249]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[250]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The majority of the population, or 59.4%, reside in urban areas and some 16.1% in Belgrade alone. Belgrade is the only city with more than a million inhabitants and there are four more with over 100,000 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-census2011_253-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-census2011-253">[251]</a></sup> </p> 
      <table class="navbox"> 
       <tbody>
        <tr> 
         <th colspan="10" class="navbox-title">
          <div style="float:right; width:6em; height:2.6em">
           &nbsp;

          <div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini" style="float: left;height:2.6em;">

           </ul>

      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion">Religion</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Serbia" title="Religion in Serbia">Religion in Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_Church" title="Serbian Orthodox Church">Serbian Orthodox Church</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
