        <a href="/wiki/File:St._Sava_Temple.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/St._Sava_Temple.jpg/220px-St._Sava_Temple.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/St._Sava_Temple.jpg/330px-St._Sava_Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a5/St._Sava_Temple.jpg/440px-St._Sava_Temple.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1022" data-file-height="767"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:St._Sava_Temple.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Church_of_Saint_Sava" title="Church of Saint Sava">Church of Saint Sava</a> in Belgrade is one of the <a href="/wiki/List_of_largest_Eastern_Orthodox_church_buildings" title="List of largest Eastern Orthodox church buildings">largest Orthodox churches</a> in the world<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[252]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The Constitution of Serbia defines it as a <a href="/wiki/Secular_state" title="Secular state">secular state</a> with guaranteed religious freedom. Orthodox Christians with 6,079,396 comprise 84.5% of country's population. The <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Orthodox_Church" title="Serbian Orthodox Church">Serbian Orthodox Church</a> is the largest and traditional church of the country, adherents of which are overwhelmingly Serbs. Other Orthodox Christian communities in Serbia include Montenegrins, Romanians, Vlachs, <a href="/wiki/Macedonians_(ethnic_group)" title="Macedonians (ethnic group)">Macedonians</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bulgarians" title="Bulgarians">Bulgarians</a>. </p>
      <p>In 2011, <a href="/wiki/Roman_Catholicism_in_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Roman Catholicism in Serbia">Roman Catholics</a> numbered 356,957 in Serbia, or roughly 6% of the population, mostly in northern Vojvodina which is home to ethnic minority groups such as Hungarians, Croats, and <a href="/wiki/Bunjevci" title="Bunjevci">Bunjevci</a>, as well as to some Slovaks and Czechs.<sup id="cite_ref-popis2011.stat.rs_255-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-popis2011.stat.rs-255">[253]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Protestantism" title="Protestantism">Protestantism</a> accounts for about 1% of the country's population, chiefly <a href="/wiki/Lutheranism" title="Lutheranism">Lutheranism</a> among <a href="/wiki/Slovaks_in_Vojvodina" class="mw-redirect" title="Slovaks in Vojvodina">Slovaks in Vojvodina</a> as well as <a href="/wiki/Calvinism" title="Calvinism">Calvinism</a> among <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_Reformed_Church" class="mw-redirect" title="Hungarian Reformed Church">Reformed Hungarians</a>. <a href="/wiki/Apostolic_Exarchate_of_Serbia_and_Montenegro" class="mw-redirect" title="Apostolic Exarchate of Serbia and Montenegro">Greek Catholic Church</a> is adhered by around 25,000 citizens (0.37% of the population), mostly <a href="/wiki/Pannonian_Rusyns" title="Pannonian Rusyns">Rusyns</a> in Vojvodina.<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[254]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Muslims" title="Muslims">Muslims</a>, with 222,282 or 3% of the population, form the third largest religious group. Islam has a strong historic following in the southern regions of Serbia, primarily in southern Raška. <a href="/wiki/Bosniaks" title="Bosniaks">Bosniaks</a> are the largest Islamic community in Serbia; estimates are that around a third of the country's Roma people are Muslim. </p>
      <p>In 2011, there were only 578 <a href="/wiki/Jews_in_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Jews in Serbia">Jews in Serbia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-257">[255]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Atheists" class="mw-redirect" title="Atheists">Atheists</a> numbered 80,053, or 1.1% of the population, and an additional 4,070 declared themselves to be <a href="/wiki/Agnostic" class="mw-redirect" title="Agnostic">agnostics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-257">[255]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language">Language</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Languages_of_Serbia" title="Languages of Serbia">Languages of Serbia</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_language" title="Serbian language">Serbian language</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG/200px-Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG" decoding="async" width="200" height="150" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG/300px-Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b3/Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG/400px-Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3264" data-file-height="2448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Folk_Theater_Subotica_Serbia.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>An inscription on the front of <a href="/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Subotica" title="National Theatre in Subotica">National Theatre in Subotica</a> in the official <a href="/wiki/Serbian_language" title="Serbian language">Serbian language</a> and two minority languages, Hungarian and Croatian.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The official language is <a href="/wiki/Serbian_language" title="Serbian language">Serbian</a>, native to 88% of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_257-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-257">[255]</a></sup> Serbian is the only European language with active <a href="/wiki/Digraphia" title="Digraphia">digraphia</a>, using both <a href="/wiki/Cyrillic" class="mw-redirect" title="Cyrillic">Cyrillic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Gaj%27s_Latin_alphabet" title="Gaj's Latin alphabet">Latin</a> alphabets. <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Cyrillic" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian Cyrillic">Serbian Cyrillic</a> is designated in the Constitution as the "official script" and was devised in 1814 by Serbian philologist <a href="/wiki/Vuk_Karad%C5%BEi%C4%87" title="Vuk Karadžić">Vuk Karadžić</a>, who based it on phonemic principles.<sup id="cite_ref-Alexander2006_258-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Alexander2006-258">[256]</a></sup> A survey from 2014 showed that 47% of Serbians favour the Latin alphabet, 36% favour the Cyrillic one and 17% have no preference.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[257]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Standard Serbian is based on the most widespread <a href="/wiki/Shtokavian_dialect" class="mw-redirect" title="Shtokavian dialect">Shtokavian dialect</a> (more specifically on the dialects of <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0umadija-Vojvodina_dialect" class="mw-redirect" title="Šumadija-Vojvodina dialect">Šumadija-Vojvodina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Herzegovinian_dialect" title="Eastern Herzegovinian dialect">Eastern Herzegovina</a><sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[258]</a></sup>). </p>
      <p>Recognised minority languages are: <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bosnian_language" title="Bosnian language">Bosnian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">Slovak</a>, <a href="/wiki/Croatian_language" title="Croatian language">Croatian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Albanian_language" title="Albanian language">Albanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Romanian_language" title="Romanian language">Romanian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bulgarian_language" title="Bulgarian language">Bulgarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rusyn_language" title="Rusyn language">Rusyn</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Macedonian_language" title="Macedonian language">Macedonian</a>. All these languages are in official use in municipalities or cities where the ethnic minority exceeds 15% of the total population.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[259]</a></sup> In Vojvodina, the provincial administration uses, besides Serbian, five other languages (Slovak, Hungarian, Croatian, Romanian and Rusyn). </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Healthcare">Healthcare</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Healthcare_in_Serbia" title="Healthcare in Serbia">Healthcare in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Zgrada_VMA_(1).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Zgrada_VMA_%281%29.jpg/220px-Zgrada_VMA_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Zgrada_VMA_%281%29.jpg/330px-Zgrada_VMA_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4e/Zgrada_VMA_%281%29.jpg/440px-Zgrada_VMA_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="900" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Zgrada_VMA_(1).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Building of the Military Medical Academy in Belgrade
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The healthcare system in Serbia is organized and managed by the three primary institutions: <a href="/wiki/Ministry_of_Health_(Serbia)" title="Ministry of Health (Serbia)">The Ministry of Health</a>, The Institute of Public Health of Serbia "Dr Milan Jovanović Batut" and the <a href="/wiki/Military_Medical_Academy_(Serbia)" title="Military Medical Academy (Serbia)">Military Medical Academy</a>. The right to healthcare protections is defined as a constitutional right in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[260]</a></sup> The Serbian public health system is based on the principles of equity and solidarity, organized on the model of <a href="/wiki/Universal_health_care#Compulsory_insurance" title="Universal health care">compulsory health insurance contributions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Stosić_Karanović_263-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stosić_Karanović-263">[261]</a></sup> Private health care is not integrated into the public health system, but certain services may be included by contracting.<sup id="cite_ref-Stosić_Karanović_263-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Stosić_Karanović-263">[261]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The Ministry of Health determines the healthcare policy and adopts standards for the work of the healthcare service. The Ministry is also in charge of the health care system, health insurance, preservation and improvement of health of citizens, health inspection, supervision over the work of the healthcare service and other tasks in the field of health care. </p>
      <p>The Institute of Public Health of Serbia "Dr Milan Jovanović Batut" is responsible for <a href="/wiki/Medical_statistics" title="Medical statistics">medical statistics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Epidemiology" title="Epidemiology">epidemiology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hygiene" title="Hygiene">hygiene</a>. This central, tertiary institution manages and coordinates a dense network of municipal and regional Centers of Public Health, spread across the entire country, that provide services in the domain of <a href="/wiki/Epidemiology" title="Epidemiology">epidemiology</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hygiene" title="Hygiene">hygiene</a> on the primary and secondary level.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[262]</a></sup> The Republic Health Insurance Institute finances the functioning of health care at all levels.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[263]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>One of the most important health institutions in Serbia is the <a href="/wiki/Military_Medical_Academy_(Serbia)" title="Military Medical Academy (Serbia)">Military Medical Academy</a> in Belgrade.<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[264]</a></sup> It takes care of about 30,000 patients a year (military and civilian insured). The Academy performs around 30,000 surgical interventions and more than 500,000 specialist examinations.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[265]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Clinical_Centre_of_Serbia" title="Clinical Centre of Serbia">Clinical Centre of Serbia</a> spreads over 34 hectares in Belgrade and consists of about 50 buildings, while also has 3,150 beds considered to be the highest number in Europe,<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[266]</a></sup> and among <a href="/wiki/List_of_hospitals_by_capacity" class="mw-redirect" title="List of hospitals by capacity">highest in the world</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[267]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other important health institutions include: KBC Dr Dragiša Mišović, Cardiovascular institute Detinje,<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[268]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Clinical_Centre_of_Kragujevac" title="Clinical Centre of Kragujevac">Clinical Centre of Kragujevac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clinical_Centre_of_Ni%C5%A1" title="Clinical Centre of Niš">Clinical Centre of Niš</a>, <a href="/wiki/Clinical_Center_of_Vojvodina" title="Clinical Center of Vojvodina">Clinical Center of Vojvodina</a> and others. </p>
      <p>Medical specialists from Serbia have performed a number of operations which have been descirbed as "pioneer works".<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[269]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-272" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-272">[270]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Economy">Economy</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Economy_of_Serbia" title="Economy of Serbia">Economy of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_(1).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg/220px-NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="164" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg/330px-NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg/440px-NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_%281%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4608" data-file-height="3440"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:NIS-ova_zgrada_-_panoramio_(1).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Naftna_Industrija_Srbije" title="Naftna Industrija Srbije">NIS</a> headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Novi_Sad" title="Novi Sad">Novi Sad</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia has an emerging <a href="/wiki/Market_economy" title="Market economy">market economy</a> in upper-middle income range.<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[271]</a></sup> According to the <a href="/wiki/International_Monetary_Fund" title="International Monetary Fund">International Monetary Fund</a>, Serbian <a href="/wiki/Nominal_GDP" class="mw-redirect" title="Nominal GDP">nominal GDP</a> in 2018 is officially estimated at $50.651 billion or $7,243 per capita while <a href="/wiki/Purchasing_power_parity" title="Purchasing power parity">purchasing power parity</a> GDP stood at $122.759 billion or $17,555 per capita.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[272]</a></sup> The economy is dominated by <a href="/wiki/Service_(economics)" title="Service (economics)">services</a> which accounts for 67.9% of GDP, followed by industry with 26.1% of GDP, and agriculture at 6% of GDP.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_275-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-275">[273]</a></sup> The official currency of Serbia is <a href="/wiki/Serbian_dinar" title="Serbian dinar">Serbian dinar</a> (<a href="/wiki/ISO_4217" title="ISO 4217">ISO</a> code: RSD), and the central bank is <a href="/wiki/National_Bank_of_Serbia" title="National Bank of Serbia">National Bank of Serbia</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Stock_Exchange" title="Belgrade Stock Exchange">Belgrade Stock Exchange</a> is the only stock exchange in the country, with market capitalisation of $8.65 billion and <a href="/wiki/BELEX15" title="BELEX15">BELEX15</a> as the main index representing the 15 most liquid stocks.<sup id="cite_ref-276" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-276">[274]</a></sup> The country is ranked 52nd on the <a href="/wiki/List_of_countries_by_Social_Progress_Index" class="mw-redirect" title="List of countries by Social Progress Index">Social Progress Index</a><sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[275]</a></sup> as well as 51st on the <a href="/wiki/Global_Peace_Index" title="Global Peace Index">Global Peace Index</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[276]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The economy has been affected by the <a href="/wiki/Great_Recession" title="Great Recession">global economic crisis</a>. After almost a decade of strong economic growth (average of 4.45% per year), Serbia entered the recession in 2009 with negative growth of −3% and again in 2012 and 2014 with −1% and −1.8%, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[277]</a></sup> As the government was fighting effects of crisis the public debt has more than doubled: from pre-crisis level of just under 30% to about 70% of GDP and trending downwards recently to around 50%.<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[278]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[279]</a></sup> Labour force stands at 3.2 million, with 56% employed in services sector, 28.1% in industry and 15.9% in the agriculture.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-282">[280]</a></sup> The average monthly net salary in May 2019 stood at 47,575 dinars or $525.<sup id="cite_ref-283" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-283">[281]</a></sup> The unemployment remains an acute problem, with rate of 12.7% as of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Serbia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>.<sup id="cite_ref-auto1_282-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-auto1-282">[280]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Since 2000, Serbia has attracted over $40 billion in <a href="/wiki/Foreign_direct_investment" title="Foreign direct investment">foreign direct investment</a> (FDI).<sup id="cite_ref-284" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-284">[282]</a></sup> Blue-chip corporations making investments include: <a href="/wiki/Fiat_Chrysler_Automobiles" title="Fiat Chrysler Automobiles">Fiat Chrysler Automobiles</a>, <a href="/wiki/Siemens" title="Siemens">Siemens</a>, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Bosch_GmbH" title="Robert Bosch GmbH">Bosch</a>, <a href="/wiki/Philip_Morris_International" title="Philip Morris International">Philip Morris</a>, <a href="/wiki/Michelin" title="Michelin">Michelin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a>, <a href="/wiki/Carlsberg_Group" title="Carlsberg Group">Carlsberg</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-belgrade.usembassy.gov_285-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-belgrade.usembassy.gov-285">[283]</a></sup> In the energy sector, Russian energy giants, <a href="/wiki/Gazprom" title="Gazprom">Gazprom</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lukoil" title="Lukoil">Lukoil</a> have made large investments.<sup id="cite_ref-economy.gov.ru_286-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-economy.gov.ru-286">[284]</a></sup> In metallurgy sector, Chinese steel and copper giants, <a href="/wiki/Hesteel" class="mw-redirect" title="Hesteel">Hesteel</a> and <a href="/wiki/Zijin_Mining" title="Zijin Mining">Zijin Mining</a> have acquired key complexes.<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[285]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia has an unfavourable trade balance: imports exceed exports by 25%. Serbia's exports, however, recorded a steady growth in last couple of years reaching $19.2 billion in 2018.<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[286]</a></sup> The country has <a href="/wiki/Free_trade_agreement" title="Free trade agreement">free trade agreements</a> with the <a href="/wiki/European_Free_Trade_Association" title="European Free Trade Association">EFTA</a> and <a href="/wiki/Central_European_Free_Trade_Agreement" title="Central European Free Trade Agreement">CEFTA</a>, a preferential trade regime with the European Union, a <a href="/wiki/Generalized_System_of_Preferences" title="Generalized System of Preferences">Generalised System of Preferences</a> with the United States, and individual free trade agreements with Russia, Belarus, Kazakhstan, and Turkey.<sup id="cite_ref-SIEPA_-_Liberalized_Trade_289-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SIEPA_-_Liberalized_Trade-289">[287]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Agriculture">Agriculture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Agriculture_in_Serbia" title="Agriculture in Serbia">Agriculture in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Framboise_sauvage2.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Framboise_sauvage2.JPG/220px-Framboise_sauvage2.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Framboise_sauvage2.JPG/330px-Framboise_sauvage2.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/06/Framboise_sauvage2.JPG/440px-Framboise_sauvage2.JPG 2x" data-file-width="3648" data-file-height="2736"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Framboise_sauvage2.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Serbia is among the world's largest producer of raspberries as of 2016<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[288]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[289]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia has very favourable natural conditions (land and climate) for varied agricultural production. It has 5,056,000 ha of agricultural land (0.7 ha per capita), out of which 3,294,000 ha is arable land (0.45 ha per capita).<sup id="cite_ref-pks.rs_292-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pks.rs-292">[290]</a></sup> In 2016, Serbia exported agricultural and food products worth $3.2 billion, and the export-import ratio was 178%.<sup id="cite_ref-293" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-293">[291]</a></sup> Agricultural exports constitute more than one-fifth of all Serbia's sales on the world market. Serbia is one of the largest provider of frozen fruit to the EU (largest to the French market, and 2nd largest to the German market).<sup id="cite_ref-siepa.gov.rs_294-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-siepa.gov.rs-294">[292]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Agricultural production is most prominent in <a href="/wiki/Vojvodina" title="Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a> on the fertile Pannonian Plain. Other agricultural regions include <a href="/wiki/Ma%C4%8Dva" title="Mačva">Mačva</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pomoravlje_(region)" class="mw-redirect" title="Pomoravlje (region)">Pomoravlje</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tamnava" title="Tamnava">Tamnava</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rasina_District" title="Rasina District">Rasina</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jablanica_District" title="Jablanica District">Jablanica</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_295-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture-295">[293]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the structure of the agricultural production, 70% is from the crop field production and 30% is from the livestock production.<sup id="cite_ref-Agriculture_295-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Agriculture-295">[293]</a></sup> Serbia is world's second largest producer of <a href="/wiki/Plum" title="Plum">plums</a> (582,485 tonnes; second to China), second largest of <a href="/wiki/Raspberry" title="Raspberry">raspberries</a> (89,602 tonnes, second to Poland), it is also a significant producer of maize (6.48 million tonnes, ranked 32nd in the world) and wheat (2.07 million tonnes, ranked 35th in the world).<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[294]</a></sup> Other important agricultural products are: <a href="/wiki/Sunflower" class="mw-redirect" title="Sunflower">sunflower</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sugar_beet" title="Sugar beet">sugar beet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soybean" title="Soybean">soybean</a>, potato, apple, pork meat, beef, <a href="/wiki/Poultry" title="Poultry">poultry</a> and dairy.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>There are 56,000 ha of <a href="/wiki/Serbian_wine" title="Serbian wine">vineyards in Serbia</a>, producing about 230 million litres of wine annually.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-pks.rs_292-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pks.rs-292">[290]</a></sup> Most famous viticulture regions are located in Vojvodina and Šumadija.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Industry">Industry</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       See also: <a href="/wiki/Automotive_industry_in_Serbia" title="Automotive industry in Serbia">Automotive industry in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg/220px-2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg/330px-2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg/440px-2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2456" data-file-height="1632"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:2012_Geneva_Motor_Show_-_Fiat_500L.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Fiat_500L" title="Fiat 500L">Fiat 500L</a> is manufactured in <a href="/wiki/Fiat_Chrysler_Automobiles" title="Fiat Chrysler Automobiles">FCA</a> plant in <a href="/wiki/Kragujevac" title="Kragujevac">Kragujevac</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The industry was the economic sector hardest hit by the <a href="/wiki/United_Nations_Security_Council_Resolution_757" title="United Nations Security Council Resolution 757">UN sanctions and trade embargo</a> and <a href="/wiki/NATO_bombing_of_Yugoslavia" title="NATO bombing of Yugoslavia">NATO bombing</a> during the 1990s and transition to market economy during the 2000s.<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[295]</a></sup> The industrial output saw dramatic downsizing: in 2013 it was expected to be only a half of that of 1989.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[296]</a></sup> Main industrial sectors include: automotive, mining, non-ferrous metals, food-processing, electronics, pharmaceuticals, clothes. Serbia has 14 free economic zones as of September 2017,<sup id="cite_ref-srbeconomiczone2017_299-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-srbeconomiczone2017-299">[297]</a></sup> in which many foreign direct investments are realised. </p>
      <p>Automotive industry (with <a href="/wiki/Fiat_Chrysler_Automobiles" title="Fiat Chrysler Automobiles">Fiat Chrysler Automobiles</a> as a forebearer) is dominated by cluster located in <a href="/wiki/Kragujevac" title="Kragujevac">Kragujevac</a> and its vicinity, and contributes to export with about $2 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[298]</a></sup> Country is a leading steel producer in the wider region of Southeast Europe and had production of nearly 2 million tonnes of raw steel in 2018, coming entirely from <a href="/wiki/Hesteel_Serbia" title="Hesteel Serbia">Smederevo steel mill</a>, owned by the Chinese <a href="/wiki/Hesteel_Group" title="Hesteel Group">Hesteel</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[299]</a></sup> Serbia's mining industry is comparatively strong: Serbia is the 18th largest producer of coal (7th in the Europe) extracted from large deposits in <a href="/wiki/RB_Kolubara" title="RB Kolubara">Kolubara</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kostolac_coal_mine" title="Kostolac coal mine">Kostolac</a> basins; it is also world's 23rd largest (3rd in Europe) producer of copper which is extracted by <a href="/wiki/Zijin_Bor_Copper" class="mw-redirect" title="Zijin Bor Copper">Zijin Bor Copper</a>, a large copper mining company, acquired by Chinese Zijin Mining in 2018; significant gold extraction is developed around <a href="/wiki/Majdanpek" title="Majdanpek">Majdanpek</a>. Serbia notably manufactures <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">intel</a> smartphones named Tesla smartphones.<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[300]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Food industry is well known both regionally and internationally and is one of the strong points of the economy.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[301]</a></sup> Some of the international brand-names established production in Serbia: <a href="/wiki/PepsiCo" title="PepsiCo">PepsiCo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nestl%C3%A9" title="Nestlé">Nestlé</a> in food-processing sector; <a href="/wiki/Coca-Cola" title="Coca-Cola">Coca-Cola</a> (Belgrade), <a href="/wiki/Heineken" title="Heineken">Heineken</a> (Novi Sad) and <a href="/wiki/Carlsberg_Group" title="Carlsberg Group">Carlsberg</a> (Bačka Palanka) in beverage industry; Nordzucker in sugar industry.<sup id="cite_ref-siepa.gov.rs_294-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-siepa.gov.rs-294">[292]</a></sup> Serbia's electronics industry had its peak in the 1980s and the industry today is only a third of what it was back then, but has witnessed a something of revival in last decade with investments of companies such as <a href="/wiki/Siemens" title="Siemens">Siemens</a> (wind turbines) in Subotica, <a href="/wiki/Panasonic" title="Panasonic">Panasonic</a> (lighting devices) in Svilajnac, and <a href="/wiki/Gorenje" title="Gorenje">Gorenje</a> (electrical home appliances) in Valjevo.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[302]</a></sup> The pharmaceutical industry in Serbia comprises a dozen manufacturers of generic drugs, of which <a href="/wiki/Hemofarm_a.d." title="Hemofarm a.d.">Hemofarm</a> in Vršac and <a href="/wiki/Galenika_a.d." title="Galenika a.d.">Galenika</a> in Belgrade, account for 80% of production volume. Domestic production meets over 60% of the local demand.<sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[303]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Energy">Energy</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Energy_in_Serbia" title="Energy in Serbia">Energy in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg/220px-Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg/330px-Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg/440px-Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Dam_Serbia_Djerdap_2.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Iron_Gate_I_Hydroelectric_Power_Station" title="Iron Gate I Hydroelectric Power Station">Đerdap 1 Hydroelectric Power Station</a>, the largest dam on the Danube river and one of the largest hydro power stations in Europe<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[304]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The energy sector is one of the largest and most important sectors to the country's economy. Serbia is a net exporter of electricity and importer of key fuels (such as oil and gas). </p>
      <p>Serbia has an abundance of coal, and significant reserves of oil and gas. Serbia's proven reserves of 5.5 billion tonnes of <a href="/wiki/Lignite" title="Lignite">coal lignite</a> are the 5th largest in the world (second in Europe, after Germany).<sup id="cite_ref-b92.net_307-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b92.net-307">[305]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-308" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-308">[306]</a></sup> Coal is found in two large deposits: <a href="/wiki/RB_Kolubara" title="RB Kolubara">Kolubara</a> (4 billion tonnes of reserves) and <a href="/wiki/Kostolac_coal_mine" title="Kostolac coal mine">Kostolac</a> (1.5 billion tonnes).<sup id="cite_ref-b92.net_307-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-b92.net-307">[305]</a></sup> Despite being small on a world scale, Serbia's oil and gas resources (77.4 million tonnes of oil equivalent and 48.1 billion cubic metres, respectively) have a certain regional importance since they are largest in the region of former Yugoslavia as well as the Balkans (excluding Romania).<sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[307]</a></sup> Almost 90% of the discovered oil and gas are to be found in <a href="/wiki/Banat" title="Banat">Banat</a> and those oil and gas fields are by size among the largest in the Pannonian basin but are average on a European scale.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[308]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The production of electricity in 2015 in Serbia was 36.5 billion kilowatt-hours (KWh), while the final electricity consumption amounted to 35.5 billion kilowatt-hours (KWh).<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[309]</a></sup> Most of the electricity produced comes from thermal-power plants (72.7% of all electricity) and to a lesser degree from <a href="/wiki/Hydroelectricity" title="Hydroelectricity">hydroelectric-power plants</a> (27.3%).<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[310]</a></sup> There are 6 lignite-operated <a href="/wiki/Fossil-fuel_power_station" class="mw-redirect" title="Fossil-fuel power station">thermal-power plants</a> with an installed power of 3,936 MW; largest of which are 1,502 MW-<a href="/wiki/TPP_Nikola_Tesla" title="TPP Nikola Tesla">Nikola Tesla 1</a> and 1,160 MW-<a href="/wiki/TPP_Nikola_Tesla" title="TPP Nikola Tesla">Nikola Tesla 2</a>, both in Obrenovac.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[311]</a></sup> Total installed power of 9 hydroelectric-power plants is 2,831 MW, largest of which is <a href="/wiki/Iron_Gate_I_Hydroelectric_Power_Station" title="Iron Gate I Hydroelectric Power Station">Đerdap 1</a> with capacity of 1,026 MW.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[312]</a></sup> In addition to this, there are mazute and gas-operated thermal-power plants with an installed power of 353 MW.<sup id="cite_ref-315" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-315">[313]</a></sup> The entire production of electricity is concentrated in <a href="/wiki/Elektroprivreda_Srbije" title="Elektroprivreda Srbije">Elektroprivreda Srbije (EPS)</a>, public electric-utility power company. </p>
      <p>The current oil production in Serbia amounts to over 1.1 million tonnes of oil equivalent<sup id="cite_ref-316" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-316">[314]</a></sup> and satisfies some 43% of country's needs while the rest is imported.<sup id="cite_ref-uk.practicallaw.com_317-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uk.practicallaw.com-317">[315]</a></sup> National petrol company, <a href="/wiki/Naftna_Industrija_Srbije" title="Naftna Industrija Srbije">Naftna Industrija Srbije (NIS)</a>, was acquired in 2008 by <a href="/wiki/Gazprom_Neft" title="Gazprom Neft">Gazprom Neft</a>. The company's refinery in <a href="/wiki/Pan%C4%8Devo" title="Pančevo">Pančevo</a> (capacity of 4.8 million tonnes) is one of the most modern oil-refineries in Europe; it also operates network of 334 filling stations in Serbia (74% of domestic market) and additional 36 stations in <a href="/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina" title="Bosnia and Herzegovina">Bosnia and Herzegovina</a>, 31 in <a href="/wiki/Bulgaria" title="Bulgaria">Bulgaria</a>, and 28 in <a href="/wiki/Romania" title="Romania">Romania</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[316]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[317]</a></sup> There are 155 kilometers of crude oil pipelines connecting Pančevo and Novi Sad refineries as a part of trans-national <a href="/wiki/Adria_oil_pipeline" title="Adria oil pipeline">Adria oil pipeline</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[318]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia is heavily dependent on foreign sources of natural gas, with only 17% coming from domestic production (totalling 491 million cubic meters in 2012) and the rest is imported, mainly from Russia (via gas pipelines that run through Ukraine and Hungary).<sup id="cite_ref-uk.practicallaw.com_317-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uk.practicallaw.com-317">[315]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Srbijagas" title="Srbijagas">Srbijagas</a>, public company, operates the natural gas transportation system which comprise 3,177 kilometers of trunk and regional natural gas pipelines and a 450 million cubic meter underground gas storage facility at <a href="/wiki/Banatski_Dvor" title="Banatski Dvor">Banatski Dvor</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[319]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In November 2020 governments of Serbia and Srpska announced construction of three hydropower plants on the Drina estimated at EUR 520 million.<sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[320]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[321]</a></sup> In January 2021 Balkan Stream gas pipeline opened through Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[322]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Transport">Transport</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Transport_in_Serbia" title="Transport in Serbia">Transport in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg/220px-Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="326" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg/330px-Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg/440px-Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="1186"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Map_of_motorways_in_Serbia_decembar27.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Motorway network 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:green; color:white;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;in service
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:red; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;under construction
         </div> 
         <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r981673959">
         <div class="legend">
          <span class="legend-color" style="background-color:grey; color:black;">&nbsp;</span>&nbsp;planned
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia has a strategic transportation location since the country's backbone, <a href="/wiki/Great_Morava" title="Great Morava">Morava Valley</a>, represents the easiest land route from continental Europe to <a href="/wiki/Asia_Minor" class="mw-redirect" title="Asia Minor">Asia Minor</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Near_East" title="Near East">Near East</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Serbian road network carries the bulk of traffic in the country. Total length of roads is 45,419&nbsp;km of which 962&nbsp;km are "class-IA state roads" (i.e. <a href="/wiki/Motorways" class="mw-redirect" title="Motorways">motorways</a>); 4,517&nbsp;km are "class-IB state roads" (national roads); 10,941&nbsp;km are "class-II state roads" (regional roads) and 23,780&nbsp;km are "municipal roads".<sup id="cite_ref-325" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-325">[323]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-326" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-326">[324]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-327" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-327">[325]</a></sup> The road network, except for the most of class-IA roads, are of comparatively lower quality to the Western European standards because of lack of financial resources for their maintenance in the last 20 years. </p>
      <p>Over 300 kilometers of new motorways has been constructed in the last decade and additional 154 kilometers are currently under construction: <a href="/wiki/A5_motorway_(Serbia)" title="A5 motorway (Serbia)">A5 motorway</a> (from north of <a href="/wiki/Kru%C5%A1evac" title="Kruševac">Kruševac</a> to <a href="/wiki/%C4%8Ca%C4%8Dak" title="Čačak">Čačak</a>) and 31&nbsp;km-long segment of <a href="/wiki/A2_motorway_(Serbia)" title="A2 motorway (Serbia)">A2</a> (between <a href="/wiki/%C4%8Ca%C4%8Dak" title="Čačak">Čačak</a> and <a href="/wiki/Po%C5%BEega,_Serbia" title="Požega, Serbia">Požega</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-328" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-328">[326]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-329" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-329">[327]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Coach_(bus)" title="Coach (bus)">Coach</a> transport is very extensive: almost every place in the country is connected by bus, from largest cities to the villages; in addition there are international routes (mainly to countries of Western Europe with large Serb diaspora). Routes, both domestic and international, are served by more than hundred <a href="/wiki/Intercity_bus_service" title="Intercity bus service">intercity coach services</a>, biggest of which are <a href="/wiki/Lasta_Beograd" title="Lasta Beograd">Lasta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ni%C5%A1-Ekspres" title="Niš-Ekspres">Niš-Ekspres</a>. As of 2018<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Serbia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, there were 1,999,771 registered passenger cars or 1 passenger car per 3.5 inhabitants.<sup id="cite_ref-330" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-330">[328]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia has 3,819 kilometres of rail tracks, of which 1,279 are electrified and 283 kilometres are double-track railroad.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup> The major rail hub is Belgrade (and to a lesser degree Niš), while the most important railroads include: Belgrade–Subotica–Budapest (Hungary) (currently upgraded to high-speed status), <a href="/wiki/Belgrade%E2%80%93Bar_railway" title="Belgrade–Bar railway">Belgrade–Bar (Montenegro)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belgrade-%C5%A0id_railway" class="mw-redirect" title="Belgrade-Šid railway">Belgrade–Šid–Zagreb (Croatia)/Belgrade–Niš–Sofia (Bulgaria)</a> (part of <a href="/wiki/Pan-European_Corridor_X" title="Pan-European Corridor X">Pan-European Corridor X</a>), and Niš–Thessaloniki (Greece). Although still a major mode of freight transportation, railroads face increasing problems with the maintenance of the infrastructure and lowering speeds. Rail services are operated by <a href="/wiki/Srbija_Voz" title="Srbija Voz">Srbija Voz</a> (passenger transport) and <a href="/wiki/Srbija_Kargo" title="Srbija Kargo">Srbija Kargo</a> (freight transport).<sup id="cite_ref-331" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-331">[329]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are three airports with regular passenger traffic. <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Nikola_Tesla_Airport" title="Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport">Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport</a> served 6.2 million passengers in 2019 and is a hub of flagship carrier <a href="/wiki/Air_Serbia" title="Air Serbia">Air Serbia</a> which flies to 59 destinations in 32 countries and carried some 2.8 million passengers in 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-332" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-332">[330]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-333" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-333">[331]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Ni%C5%A1_Constantine_the_Great_Airport" title="Niš Constantine the Great Airport">Niš Constantine the Great Airport</a> and <a href="/wiki/Morava_Airport" title="Morava Airport">Morava Airport</a> are mainly catering <a href="/wiki/Low-cost_airline" class="mw-redirect" title="Low-cost airline">low-cost airlines</a> but also serving as secondary Air Serbia hubs.<sup id="cite_ref-334" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-334">[332]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg/220px-Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg/330px-Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/84/Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg/440px-Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="682"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Air_Serbia_ATR-72-202_taking_off_from_Belgrade_Airport.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Air_Serbia" title="Air Serbia">Air Serbia</a>'s airplane taking off from <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Nikola_Tesla_Airport" title="Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport">Belgrade Nikola Tesla Airport</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia has a developed inland water transport since there are 1,716 kilometres of navigable inland waterways (1,043&nbsp;km of navigable rivers and 673&nbsp;km of navigable canals), which are almost all located in northern third of the country.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup> The most important inland waterway is the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a> (part of Pan-European Corridor VII). Other navigable rivers include <a href="/wiki/Sava" title="Sava">Sava</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tisza" title="Tisza">Tisza</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bega_River_(Tisza)" class="mw-redirect" title="Bega River (Tisza)">Begej</a> and <a href="/wiki/Timi%C5%9F_River" class="mw-redirect" title="Timiş River">Timiş River</a>, all of which connect Serbia with Northern and Western Europe through the <a href="/wiki/Rhine%E2%80%93Main%E2%80%93Danube_Canal" title="Rhine–Main–Danube Canal">Rhine–Main–Danube Canal</a> and <a href="/wiki/North_Sea" title="North Sea">North Sea</a> route, to Eastern Europe via the Tisza, Begej and Danube Black Sea routes, and to Southern Europe via the Sava river. More than 8 million tonnes of cargo were transported on Serbian rivers and canals in 2018 while the largest river ports are: Novi Sad, Belgrade, Pančevo, <a href="/wiki/Smederevo" title="Smederevo">Smederevo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prahovo" title="Prahovo">Prahovo</a> and Šabac.<sup id="cite_ref-335" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-335">[333]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-336" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-336">[334]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Telecommunications">Telecommunications</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Telecommunications_in_Serbia" title="Telecommunications in Serbia">Telecommunications in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Fixed telephone lines connect 81% of households in Serbia, and with about 9.1 million users the number of cellphones surpasses the total population of by 28%.<sup id="cite_ref-ratel.rs_337-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratel.rs-337">[335]</a></sup> The largest mobile operator is <a href="/wiki/Telekom_Srbija" class="mw-redirect" title="Telekom Srbija">Telekom Srbija</a> with 4.2 million subscribers, followed by <a href="/wiki/Telenor_Serbia" title="Telenor Serbia">Telenor</a> with 2.8 million users and <a href="/wiki/Vip_mobile" title="Vip mobile">Vip mobile</a> with about 2 million.<sup id="cite_ref-ratel.rs_337-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratel.rs-337">[335]</a></sup> Some 58% of households have fixed-line (non-mobile) broadband Internet connection while 67% are provided with <a href="/wiki/Pay_television" title="Pay television">pay television services</a> (i.e. 38% cable television, 17% IPTV, and 10% satellite).<sup id="cite_ref-ratel.rs_337-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ratel.rs-337">[335]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Digital_television_transition" title="Digital television transition">Digital television transition</a> has been completed in 2015 with <a href="/wiki/DVB-T2" title="DVB-T2">DVB-T2</a> standard for signal transmission.<sup id="cite_ref-EJC_338-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EJC-338">[336]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[337]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourism">Tourism</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Serbia" title="Tourism in Serbia">Tourism in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:392px;max-width:392px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Djavolja_varos_3.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Djavolja_varos_3.jpg/192px-Djavolja_varos_3.jpg" decoding="async" width="192" height="144" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Djavolja_varos_3.jpg/288px-Djavolja_varos_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c8/Djavolja_varos_3.jpg/384px-Djavolja_varos_3.jpg 2x" data-file-width="990" data-file-height="743"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Centar_II,_Subotica,_Serbia_-_panoramio_(5).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Centar_II%2C_Subotica%2C_Serbia_-_panoramio_%285%29.jpg/192px-Centar_II%2C_Subotica%2C_Serbia_-_panoramio_%285%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="192" height="144" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Centar_II%2C_Subotica%2C_Serbia_-_panoramio_%285%29.jpg/288px-Centar_II%2C_Subotica%2C_Serbia_-_panoramio_%285%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/Centar_II%2C_Subotica%2C_Serbia_-_panoramio_%285%29.jpg/384px-Centar_II%2C_Subotica%2C_Serbia_-_panoramio_%285%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4000" data-file-height="3000"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Manastir_Studenica,_Srbija,_061.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Manastir_Studenica%2C_Srbija%2C_061.JPG/192px-Manastir_Studenica%2C_Srbija%2C_061.JPG" decoding="async" width="192" height="144" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Manastir_Studenica%2C_Srbija%2C_061.JPG/288px-Manastir_Studenica%2C_Srbija%2C_061.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Manastir_Studenica%2C_Srbija%2C_061.JPG/384px-Manastir_Studenica%2C_Srbija%2C_061.JPG 2x" data-file-width="4896" data-file-height="3672"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:194px;max-width:194px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Stopi%C4%87a_Pe%C4%87ina2.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Stopi%C4%87a_Pe%C4%87ina2.jpg/192px-Stopi%C4%87a_Pe%C4%87ina2.jpg" decoding="async" width="192" height="128" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Stopi%C4%87a_Pe%C4%87ina2.jpg/288px-Stopi%C4%87a_Pe%C4%87ina2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/62/Stopi%C4%87a_Pe%C4%87ina2.jpg/384px-Stopi%C4%87a_Pe%C4%87ina2.jpg 2x" data-file-width="3880" data-file-height="2586"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          Clockwise from left: 1. <a href="/wiki/%C4%90avolja_Varo%C5%A1" title="Đavolja Varoš">Đavolja Varoš</a> natural monument 2. <a href="/wiki/Subotica" title="Subotica">Subotica</a>, city built in <a href="/wiki/Art_Nouveau" title="Art Nouveau">Art Nouveau</a> style 3. <a href="/wiki/Studenica_Monastery" title="Studenica Monastery">Studenica Monastery</a> 4. <a href="/wiki/Stopi%C4%87a_Cave" title="Stopića Cave">Stopića Cave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zlatibor" title="Zlatibor">Zlatibor</a> mountain
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia is not a mass-tourism destination but nevertheless has a diverse range of touristic products.<sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[338]</a></sup> In 2019, total of over 3.6 million tourists were recorded in accommodations, of which half were foreign.<sup id="cite_ref-:1_341-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:1-341">[339]</a></sup> Foreign exchange earnings from tourism were estimated at $1.5 billion.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[340]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Tourism is mainly focused on the mountains and spas of the country, which are mostly visited by domestic tourists, as well as <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a> and, to a lesser degree, <a href="/wiki/Novi_Sad" title="Novi Sad">Novi Sad</a>, which are preferred choices of foreign tourists (almost two-thirds of all foreign visits are made to these two cities).<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[341]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[342]</a></sup> The most famous mountain resorts are <a href="/wiki/Kopaonik_ski_resort" title="Kopaonik ski resort">Kopaonik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stara_Planina_ski_resort" title="Stara Planina ski resort">Stara Planina</a> and <a href="/wiki/Tornik_ski_resort" title="Tornik ski resort">Zlatibor</a>. There are also many <a href="/wiki/Spa" title="Spa">spas</a> in Serbia, the biggest of which are <a href="/wiki/Vrnja%C4%8Dka_Banja" title="Vrnjačka Banja">Vrnjačka Banja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soko_Banja" class="mw-redirect" title="Soko Banja">Soko Banja</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Banja_Kovilja%C4%8Da" title="Banja Koviljača">Banja Koviljača</a>. City-break and conference tourism is developed in Belgrade and Novi Sad.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[343]</a></sup> Other touristic products that Serbia offer are natural wonders like <a href="/wiki/Djavolja_varos" class="mw-redirect" title="Djavolja varos">Đavolja varoš</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[344]</a></sup> Christian pilgrimage to the many <a href="/wiki/List_of_Serbian_Orthodox_monasteries" title="List of Serbian Orthodox monasteries">Orthodox monasteries</a> across the country and the river cruising along the <a href="/wiki/Danube" title="Danube">Danube</a>. There are several internationally popular music festivals held in Serbia, such as <a href="/wiki/Exit_(festival)" title="Exit (festival)">EXIT</a> (with 25–30,000 foreign visitors coming from 60 different countries) and the <a href="/wiki/Gu%C4%8Da_trumpet_festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Guča trumpet festival">Guča trumpet festival</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[345]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Education_and_science">Education and science</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Education_in_Serbia" title="Education in Serbia">Education in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg/170px-Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="304" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg/255px-Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg/340px-Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg 2x" data-file-width="358" data-file-height="640"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Milutin_Milankovi%C4%87" title="Milutin Milanković">Milutin Milanković</a>, ranked among the top fifteen minds of all time in the field of <a href="/wiki/Earth_science" title="Earth science">earth sciences</a><sup id="cite_ref-348" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-348">[346]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to 2011 census, literacy in Serbia stands at 98% of population while computer literacy is at 49% (complete computer literacy is at 34.2%).<sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[347]</a></sup> Same census showed the following levels of education: 16.2% of inhabitants have higher education (10.6% have bachelors or master's degrees, 5.6% have an associate degree), 49% have a secondary education, 20.7% have an elementary education, and 13.7% have not completed elementary education.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[348]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Education in Serbia is regulated by the Ministry of Education and Science. Education starts in either preschools or elementary schools. Children enroll in elementary schools at the age of seven. Compulsory education consists of eight grades of elementary school. Students have the opportunity to attend <a href="/wiki/Gymnasium_(school)" title="Gymnasium (school)">gymnasiums</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vocational_school" title="Vocational school">vocational schools</a> for another four years, or to enroll in vocational training for 2 to 3 years. Following the completion of gymnasiums or vocational schools, students have the opportunity to attend university.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[349]</a></sup> Elementary and secondary education are also available in languages of recognised minorities in Serbia, where classes are held in <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_language" title="Hungarian language">Hungarian</a>, <a href="/wiki/Slovak_language" title="Slovak language">Slovak</a>, Albanian, Romanian, <a href="/wiki/Rusyn_language" title="Rusyn language">Rusyn</a>, Bulgarian as well as Bosnian and Croatian languages. <a href="/wiki/Petnica_Science_Center" title="Petnica Science Center">Petnica Science Center</a> is a notable institution for extracurricular science education focusing on gifted students.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[350]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are 19 universities in Serbia (nine public universities with a total number of 86 <a href="/wiki/Faculty_(division)" title="Faculty (division)">faculties</a> and ten private universities with 51 faculties).<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[351]</a></sup> In 2018/2019 academic year, 210,480 students attended 19 universities (181,310 at public universities and some 29,170 at private universities) while 47,169 attended 81 "higher schools".<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-enrolledstudents2019_354-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-enrolledstudents2019-354">[352]</a></sup> Public universities in Serbia are: the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Belgrade" title="University of Belgrade">University of Belgrade</a> (oldest, founded in 1808, and largest university with 97,696 undergraduates and graduates<sup id="cite_ref-enrolledstudents2019_354-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-enrolledstudents2019-354">[352]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Novi_Sad" title="University of Novi Sad">University of Novi Sad</a> (founded in 1960 and with student body of 42,489),<sup id="cite_ref-enrolledstudents2019_354-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-enrolledstudents2019-354">[352]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/University_of_Ni%C5%A1" title="University of Niš">University of Niš</a> (founded in 1965; 20,559 students),<sup id="cite_ref-enrolledstudents2019_354-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-enrolledstudents2019-354">[352]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/University_of_Kragujevac" title="University of Kragujevac">University of Kragujevac</a> (founded in 1976; 14,053 students), <a href="/wiki/University_of_Pri%C5%A1tina_(North_Mitrovica)" title="University of Priština (North Mitrovica)">University of Priština</a> (located in <a href="/wiki/North_Mitrovica" title="North Mitrovica">North Mitrovica</a>), <a href="/wiki/State_University_of_Novi_Pazar" title="State University of Novi Pazar">Public University of Novi Pazar</a> as well as three specialist universities – <a href="/wiki/University_of_Arts_(Belgrade)" class="mw-redirect" title="University of Arts (Belgrade)">University of Arts</a>, <a href="/wiki/Military_Academy_(Serbia)" title="Military Academy (Serbia)">University of Defence</a> and University of Criminal Investigation and Police Studies. Largest private universities include <a href="/wiki/Megatrend_University" title="Megatrend University">Megatrend University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Singidunum_University" title="Singidunum University">Singidunum University</a>, both in Belgrade, and Educons University in Novi Sad. The <a href="/wiki/University_of_Belgrade" title="University of Belgrade">University of Belgrade</a> (placed in 301–400 bracket on <a href="/wiki/Academic_Ranking_of_World_Universities" title="Academic Ranking of World Universities">2013 Shanghai Ranking of World Universities</a>, being best-placed university in Southeast Europe after those in Athens and Thessaloniki) and <a href="/wiki/University_of_Novi_Sad" title="University of Novi Sad">University of Novi Sad</a> are generally considered as the best institutions of higher learning in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[353]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:KnezMihailova_ped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/KnezMihailova_ped.jpg/220px-KnezMihailova_ped.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="146" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/KnezMihailova_ped.jpg/330px-KnezMihailova_ped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/41/KnezMihailova_ped.jpg/440px-KnezMihailova_ped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="752" data-file-height="500"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:KnezMihailova_ped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts" title="Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts">Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts</a>, national learned society founded in 1841
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia spent 0.9% of GDP on scientific research in 2017, which is slightly below the European average.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[354]</a></sup> Since 2018, Serbia is a full member of <a href="/wiki/CERN" title="CERN">CERN</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[355]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[356]</a></sup> Serbia has a long history of excellence in maths and computer sciences which has created a strong pool of engineering talent, although economic sanctions during the 1990s and chronic underinvestment in research forced many scientific professionals to leave the country.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[357]</a></sup> Nevertheless, there are several areas in which Serbia still excels such as growing information technology sector, which includes software development as well as outsourcing. It generated over $1.2 billion in exports in 2018, both from international investors and a significant number of dynamic homegrown enterprises.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[358]</a></sup> Serbia is one of the countries with the highest proportion of <a href="/wiki/Women_in_science" title="Women in science">women in science</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[359]</a></sup> Among the scientific institutes operating in Serbia, the largest are the <a href="/wiki/Mihajlo_Pupin_Institute" title="Mihajlo Pupin Institute">Mihajlo Pupin Institute</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vin%C4%8Da_Nuclear_Institute" title="Vinča Nuclear Institute">Vinča Nuclear Institute</a>, both in Belgrade. The <a href="/wiki/Serbian_Academy_of_Sciences_and_Arts" title="Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts">Serbian Academy of Sciences and Arts</a> is a <a href="/wiki/Learned_society" title="Learned society">learned society</a> promoting science and arts from its inception in 1841.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[360]</a></sup> With a strong science and technological ecosystem, Serbia has produced a number of renowned scientists that have greatly contributed to the field of science and technology.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[361]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_culture" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian culture">Serbian culture</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg/220px-Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg/330px-Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg/440px-Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1600" data-file-height="1200"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Muzej_Nikole_Tesle.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Nikola_Tesla_Museum" title="Nikola Tesla Museum">Nikola Tesla Museum</a> ranks among the most visited museums in Serbia<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[362]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[363]</a></sup> and it hosts the <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Tesla" title="Nikola Tesla">Nikola Tesla</a> Archive, which was inscribed on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Memory_of_the_World_Programme" title="Memory of the World Programme">Memory of the World Programme</a>.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>For centuries straddling the boundaries between East and West, the territory of Serbia had been divided among the Eastern and <a href="/wiki/Western_Roman_Empire" title="Western Roman Empire">Western</a> halves of the <a href="/wiki/Roman_Empire" title="Roman Empire">Roman Empire</a>; then between <a href="/wiki/Byzantium" title="Byzantium">Byzantium</a> and the Kingdom of Hungary; and in the Early modern period between the <a href="/wiki/Ottoman_Empire" title="Ottoman Empire">Ottoman Empire</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Empire</a>. These overlapping influences have resulted in cultural varieties throughout Serbia; its north leans to the profile of Central Europe, while the south is characteristic of the wider Balkans and even the Mediterranean. The Byzantine influence on Serbia was profound, firstly through the introduction of <a href="/wiki/Eastern_Christianity" title="Eastern Christianity">Eastern Christianity</a> in the Early Middle Ages. The Serbian Orthodox Church has had an enduring status in Serbia, with the <a href="/wiki/List_of_Serb_Orthodox_monasteries" class="mw-redirect" title="List of Serb Orthodox monasteries">many Serbian monasteries</a> constituting cultural monuments left from <a href="/wiki/Serbia_in_the_Middle_Ages" title="Serbia in the Middle Ages">Serbia in the Middle Ages</a>. Serbia has seen influences of <a href="/wiki/Republic_of_Venice" title="Republic of Venice">Republic of Venice</a> as well, mainly though trade, literature and <a href="/wiki/Romanesque_art" title="Romanesque art">romanesque architecture</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[364]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[365]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbia has five cultural monuments inscribed in the list of <a href="/wiki/World_Heritage_Site" title="World Heritage Site">UNESCO World Heritage</a>: the early medieval capital <a href="/wiki/Stari_Ras" title="Stari Ras">Stari Ras</a> and the 13th-century monastery <a href="/wiki/Sopo%C4%87ani" title="Sopoćani">Sopoćani</a>; the 12th-century <a href="/wiki/Studenica_monastery" class="mw-redirect" title="Studenica monastery">Studenica monastery</a>; the Roman complex of <a href="/wiki/Gamzigrad" title="Gamzigrad">Gamzigrad–Felix Romuliana</a>; medieval tombstones <a href="/wiki/Ste%C4%87ci" class="mw-redirect" title="Stećci">Stećci</a>; and finally the endangered <a href="/wiki/Medieval_Monuments_in_Kosovo" title="Medieval Monuments in Kosovo">Medieval Monuments in Kosovo</a> (the monasteries of <a href="/wiki/Visoki_De%C4%8Dani" title="Visoki Dečani">Visoki Dečani</a>, <a href="/wiki/Our_Lady_of_Ljevi%C5%A1" title="Our Lady of Ljeviš">Our Lady of Ljeviš</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gra%C4%8Danica_Monastery" title="Gračanica Monastery">Gračanica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Patriarchal_Monastery_of_Pe%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Patriarchal Monastery of Peć">Patriarchal Monastery of Peć</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEČanak-MedićTodić2017_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEČanak-MedićTodić2017-368">[366]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are two literary monuments on UNESCO's <a href="/wiki/Memory_of_the_World_Programme" title="Memory of the World Programme">Memory of the World Programme</a>: the 12th-century <i><a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Gospel" title="Miroslav Gospel">Miroslav Gospel</a></i>, and scientist <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Tesla" title="Nikola Tesla">Nikola Tesla</a>'s archive. The <i><a href="/wiki/Slava" title="Slava">slava</a></i> (patron saint veneration), <a href="/wiki/Kolo_(dance)" title="Kolo (dance)">kolo</a> (traditional folk dance), singing to the accompaniment of the <a href="/wiki/Gusle" title="Gusle">gusle</a> and Zlakusa pottery<sup id="cite_ref-369" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-369">[367]</a></sup> are inscribed on <a href="/wiki/UNESCO_Intangible_Cultural_Heritage_Lists" title="UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists">UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage Lists</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Minister_of_Culture_(Serbia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Minister of Culture (Serbia)">Ministry of Culture and Information</a> is tasked with preserving the nation's <a href="/wiki/Cultural_Heritage_of_Serbia" title="Cultural Heritage of Serbia">cultural heritage</a> and overseeing its development. Further activities supporting development of culture are undertaken at local government level. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art_and_architecture">Art and architecture</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_art" title="Serbian art">Serbian art</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_architecture" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian architecture">Serbian architecture</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png/170px-Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png" decoding="async" width="170" height="235" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png/255px-Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/33/Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png/340px-Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png 2x" data-file-width="640" data-file-height="885"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Archangel_Gabriel_Outside_Jesus%27_Tomb_after_Resurrection.png" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>The <a href="/wiki/White_Angel" title="White Angel">White Angel</a> (1235) fresco from Mileševa monastery; sent as a message in the first <a href="/wiki/Satellite_television" title="Satellite television">satellite broadcast</a> signal from <a href="/wiki/Europe" title="Europe">Europe</a> to <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">America</a>, as a <a href="/wiki/Symbol" title="Symbol">symbol</a> of <a href="/wiki/Peace" title="Peace">peace</a> and <a href="/wiki/Civilization" title="Civilization">civilisation</a><sup id="cite_ref-prijepolje_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-prijepolje-370">[368]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Traces of Roman and early Byzantine Empire architectural heritage are found in many royal cities and palaces in Serbia, like <a href="/wiki/Sirmium" title="Sirmium">Sirmium</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gamzigrad" title="Gamzigrad">Felix Romuliana</a> and <a href="/wiki/Justiniana_Prima" title="Justiniana Prima">Justiniana Prima</a>, since 535 the seat of the <a href="/wiki/Archbishopric_of_Justiniana_Prima" title="Archbishopric of Justiniana Prima">Archbishopric of Justiniana Prima</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurlej2016193_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurlej2016193-371">[369]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbian monasteries are the pinnacle of Serbian medieval art. At the beginning, they were under the influence of <a href="/wiki/Byzantine_Art" class="mw-redirect" title="Byzantine Art">Byzantine Art</a> which was particularly felt after the fall of Constantinople in 1204, when many Byzantine artists fled to Serbia.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Noted of these monasteries is <a href="/wiki/Studenica_monastery" class="mw-redirect" title="Studenica monastery">Studenica</a> (built around 1190).
