It was a model for later monasteries, like the <a href="/wiki/Mile%C5%A1eva" class="mw-redirect" title="Mileševa">Mileševa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sopo%C4%87ani" title="Sopoćani">Sopoćani</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDi%C4%8Da" title="Žiča">Žiča</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gra%C4%8Danica_monastery" class="mw-redirect" title="Gračanica monastery">Gračanica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Visoki_De%C4%8Dani" title="Visoki Dečani">Visoki Dečani</a>. Numerous monuments and cultural sites were destroyed at various stages of Serbian history, with <a href="/wiki/Destruction_of_Serbian_heritage_in_Kosovo" title="Destruction of Serbian heritage in Kosovo">destruuction in Kosovo</a> being the recent example. In the end of 14th and the 15th centuries, autochthonous architectural style known as <a href="/wiki/Morava_architectural_school" title="Morava architectural school">Morava style</a> evolved in area around Morava Valley. A characteristic of this style was the wealthy decoration of the frontal church walls. Examples of this include <a href="/wiki/Manasija" title="Manasija">Manasija</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ravanica" title="Ravanica">Ravanica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kaleni%C4%87_Monastery" title="Kalenić Monastery">Kalenić</a> monasteries. </p>
      <p>Icons and fresco paintings are often considered the peak of Serbian art. The most famous frescos are <a href="/wiki/White_Angel" title="White Angel">White Angel</a> (Mileševa monastery), <i>Crucifixion</i> (Studenica monastery) and <i>Dormition of the Virgin</i> (Sopoćani).<sup id="cite_ref-372" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-372">[370]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Country is dotted with many well-preserved medieval fortifications and castles such as <a href="/wiki/Smederevo_Fortress" title="Smederevo Fortress">Smederevo Fortress</a> (largest lowland fortress in Europe),<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[371]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Golubac_Fortress" title="Golubac Fortress">Golubac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Magli%C4%8D" title="Maglič">Maglič</a>, <a href="/wiki/Soko_Grad_(Sokobanja)" title="Soko Grad (Sokobanja)">Soko grad</a>, <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Fortress" title="Belgrade Fortress">Belgrade Fortress</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ostrvica_Fortress" title="Ostrvica Fortress">Ostrvica</a> and <a href="/wiki/Ram_Fortress" title="Ram Fortress">Ram</a>. </p>
      <p>During the time of Ottoman occupation, Serbian art was virtually non-existent, with the exception of several Serbian artists who lived in the lands ruled by the <a href="/wiki/Habsburg_Monarchy" title="Habsburg Monarchy">Habsburg Monarchy</a>. Traditional Serbian art showed <a href="/wiki/Baroque" title="Baroque">Baroque</a> influences at the end of the 18th century as shown in the works of <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Ne%C5%A1kovi%C4%87" title="Nikola Nešković">Nikola Nešković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Teodor_Kra%C4%8Dun" title="Teodor Kračun">Teodor Kračun</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zaharije_Orfelin" title="Zaharije Orfelin">Zaharije Orfelin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Jakov_Orfelin" title="Jakov Orfelin">Jakov Orfelin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[372]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2428" data-file-height="2364"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Marina_Abramovi%C4%87_-_The_Artist_Is_Present_-_Viennale_2012_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87" title="Marina Abramović">Marina Abramović</a>, one of the world's leading performance artists
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbian painting showed the influence of <a href="/wiki/Biedermeier" title="Biedermeier">Biedermeier</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neoclassicism" title="Neoclassicism">Neoclassicism</a> as seen in works by <a href="/wiki/Konstantin_Danil" title="Konstantin Danil">Konstantin Danil</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[373]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Arsenije_Teodorovi%C4%87" title="Arsenije Teodorović">Arsenije Teodorović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Pavel_%C4%90urkovi%C4%87" title="Pavel Đurković">Pavel Đurković</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-376" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-376">[374]</a></sup> Many painters followed the artistic trends set in the 19th century Romanticism, notably <a href="/wiki/%C4%90ura_Jak%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Đura Jakšić">Đura Jakšić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stevan_Todorovi%C4%87" title="Stevan Todorović">Stevan Todorović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Katarina_Ivanovi%C4%87" title="Katarina Ivanović">Katarina Ivanović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Novak_Radoni%C4%87" title="Novak Radonić">Novak Radonić</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[375]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[376]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Important Serbian painters of the first half of the 20th century were <a href="/wiki/Paja_Jovanovi%C4%87" title="Paja Jovanović">Paja Jovanović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uro%C5%A1_Predi%C4%87" title="Uroš Predić">Uroš Predić</a> of <a href="/wiki/Realism_(arts)" title="Realism (arts)">Realism</a>, Cubist <a href="/wiki/Sava_%C5%A0umanovi%C4%87" title="Sava Šumanović">Sava Šumanović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milena_Pavlovi%C4%87-Barili" title="Milena Pavlović-Barili">Milena Pavlović-Barili</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nade%C5%BEda_Petrovi%C4%87" title="Nadežda Petrović">Nadežda Petrović</a> of Impressionism, Expressionist <a href="/wiki/Milan_Konjovi%C4%87" title="Milan Konjović">Milan Konjović</a>. Noted painters of the second half of 20th century include <a href="/wiki/Marko_%C4%8Celebonovi%C4%87" title="Marko Čelebonović">Marko Čelebonović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Petar_Lubarda" title="Petar Lubarda">Petar Lubarda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Milo_Milunovi%C4%87" title="Milo Milunović">Milo Milunović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ljubomir_Popovi%C4%87" title="Ljubomir Popović">Ljubomir Popović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vladimir_Veli%C4%8Dkovi%C4%87" title="Vladimir Veličković">Vladimir Veličković</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[377]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Anastas_Jovanovi%C4%87" title="Anastas Jovanović">Anastas Jovanović</a> was one of the earliest photographes in the world, while <a href="/wiki/Marina_Abramovi%C4%87" title="Marina Abramović">Marina Abramović</a> is one of the world leading performance artists. <a href="/wiki/Pirot_carpet" title="Pirot carpet">Pirot carpet</a> is known as one of the most important traditional handicrafts in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[378]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are around 180 museums in Serbia,<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[380]</a></sup> of which the most prominent is the <a href="/wiki/National_Museum_of_Serbia" title="National Museum of Serbia">National Museum of Serbia</a>, founded in 1844. It houses one of the largest art collections in the Balkans, including many foreign masterpiece collections.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[381]</a></sup> Other art museums of note are <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Contemporary_Art_(Belgrade)" class="mw-redirect" title="Museum of Contemporary Art (Belgrade)">Museum of Contemporary Art</a> in Belgrade, <a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Vojvodina" title="Museum of Vojvodina">Museum of Vojvodina</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Gallery_of_Matica_Srpska" title="Gallery of Matica Srpska">Gallery of Matica Srpska</a> in Novi Sad. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Literature">Literature</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_literature" title="Serbian literature">Serbian literature</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The beginning of Serbian literacy dates back to the activity of the brothers <a href="/wiki/Cyril_and_Methodius" class="mw-redirect" title="Cyril and Methodius">Cyril and Methodius</a> in the Balkans.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Monuments of Serbian literacy from the early 11th century can be found, written in <a href="/wiki/Glagolitic" class="mw-redirect" title="Glagolitic">Glagolitic</a>. Starting in the 12th century, books were written in <a href="/wiki/Cyrillic" class="mw-redirect" title="Cyrillic">Cyrillic</a>. From this epoch, the oldest Serbian Cyrillic book editorial are the <a href="/wiki/Miroslav_Gospels" class="mw-redirect" title="Miroslav Gospels">Miroslav Gospels</a> from 1186. <i>The Miroslav Gospels</i> are considered to be the oldest book of Serbian medieval history and as such has entered <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Memory_of_the_World_Register" class="mw-redirect" title="Memory of the World Register">Memory of the World Register</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-mow_384-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mow-384">[382]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Notable medieval authors include <a href="/wiki/Saint_Sava" title="Saint Sava">Saint Sava</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jefimija" title="Jefimija">Jefimija</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Lazarevi%C4%87" title="Stefan Lazarević">Stefan Lazarević</a>, <a href="/wiki/Constantine_of_Kostenets" title="Constantine of Kostenets">Constantine of Kostenets</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-385" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-385">[383]</a></sup> Due to Ottoman occupation, when every aspect of formal literacy stopped, Serbia stayed excluded from the entire <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> flow in Western culture. However, the tradition of oral story-telling blossomed, shaping itself through <a href="/wiki/Epic_poetry" title="Epic poetry">epic poetry</a> inspired by at the times still recent <a href="/wiki/Kosovo_battle" class="mw-redirect" title="Kosovo battle">Kosovo battle</a> and <a href="/wiki/Folklore" title="Folklore">folk tales</a> deeply rooted in <a href="/wiki/Slavic_mythology" class="mw-redirect" title="Slavic mythology">Slavic mythology</a>. <a href="/wiki/Serbian_epic_poetry" title="Serbian epic poetry">Serbian epic poetry</a> in those times has seen as the most effective way in preserving the national identity.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDragnich199429–30_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDragnich199429–30-386">[384]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-CaseNaimark2003_387-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CaseNaimark2003-387">[385]</a></sup> The oldest known, entirely fictional poems, make up the <i>Non-historic cycle</i>; this one is followed by poems inspired by events before, during and after Kosovo Battle. The special cycles are dedicated to Serbian legendary hero, <a href="/wiki/Prince_Marko" title="Prince Marko">Marko Kraljević</a>, then about <a href="/wiki/Hajduk" title="Hajduk">hajduks</a> and <a href="/wiki/Uskok" class="mw-redirect" title="Uskok">uskoks</a>, and the last one dedicated to the liberation of Serbia in the 19th century. Some of the best known folk ballads are <i>The Death of the Mother of the Jugović Family</i> and <a href="/wiki/Hasanaginica" title="Hasanaginica">The Mourning Song of the Noble Wife of the Asan Aga</a> (1646), translated into European languages by <a href="/wiki/Goethe" class="mw-redirect" title="Goethe">Goethe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">Walter Scott</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pushkin" class="mw-redirect" title="Pushkin">Pushkin</a> and <a href="/wiki/M%C3%A9rim%C3%A9e" class="mw-redirect" title="Mérimée">Mérimée</a>. One of the most notable tales from Serbian folklore is <a href="/wiki/The_Nine_Peahens_and_the_Golden_Apples" title="The Nine Peahens and the Golden Apples">The Nine Peahens and the Golden Apples</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-388">[386]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg/220px-Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg/330px-Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/20/Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg/440px-Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2624" data-file-height="1968"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Miroslav%27s_Gospel_001.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Miroslav%27s_Gospel" class="mw-redirect" title="Miroslav's Gospel">Miroslav's Gospel</a> (1186) is a 362-page illuminated manuscript Gospel book on parchment with very rich decorations. It is a masterpiece of illustration and calligraphy. In 2005 it was inscribed in <a href="/wiki/UNESCO" title="UNESCO">UNESCO's</a> Memory of the World Register.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Stevan_Kragujevic,_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Stevan_Kragujevic%2C_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG/220px-Stevan_Kragujevic%2C_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="220" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Stevan_Kragujevic%2C_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG/330px-Stevan_Kragujevic%2C_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a7/Stevan_Kragujevic%2C_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG/440px-Stevan_Kragujevic%2C_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG 2x" data-file-width="2880" data-file-height="2880"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Stevan_Kragujevic,_Ivo_Andric_u_svom_domu.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Ivo_Andri%C4%87" title="Ivo Andrić">Ivo Andrić</a>, Serbian writer and the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">1961 winner of the Nobel Prize in Literature</a>, in his home in <a href="/wiki/Belgrade" title="Belgrade">Belgrade</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Baroque trends in Serbian literature emerged in the late 17th century. Notable Baroque-influenced authors were <a href="/wiki/Gavril_Stefanovi%C4%87_Venclovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Gavril Stefanović Venclović">Gavril Stefanović Venclović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jovan_Raji%C4%87" title="Jovan Rajić">Jovan Rajić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zaharije_Orfelin" title="Zaharije Orfelin">Zaharije Orfelin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Andrija_Zmajevi%C4%87" title="Andrija Zmajević">Andrija Zmajević</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-389" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-389">[387]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dositej_Obradovi%C4%87" title="Dositej Obradović">Dositej Obradović</a> was a prominent figure of the <a href="/wiki/Age_of_Enlightenment" title="Age of Enlightenment">Age of Enlightenment</a>, while the notable <a href="/wiki/Classicism" title="Classicism">Classicist</a> writer was <a href="/wiki/Jovan_Sterija_Popovi%C4%87" title="Jovan Sterija Popović">Jovan Sterija Popović</a>, although his works also contained elements of Romanticism.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[388]</a></sup> In the era of national revival, in the first half of the 19th century, <a href="/wiki/Vuk_Stefanovi%C4%87_Karad%C5%BEi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Vuk Stefanović Karadžić">Vuk Stefanović Karadžić</a> collected Serbian <a href="/wiki/Folk_literature" class="mw-redirect" title="Folk literature">folk literature</a>, and reformed the Serbian language and spelling,<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[389]</a></sup> paving the way for Serbian Romanticism. The first half of the 19th century was dominated by Romanticism, with <a href="/wiki/Petar_II_Petrovi%C4%87-Njego%C5%A1" title="Petar II Petrović-Njegoš">Petar II Petrović-Njegoš</a>, <a href="/wiki/Branko_Radi%C4%8Devi%C4%87" title="Branko Radičević">Branko Radičević</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C4%90ura_Jak%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Đura Jakšić">Đura Jakšić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jovan_Jovanovi%C4%87_Zmaj" title="Jovan Jovanović Zmaj">Jovan Jovanović Zmaj</a> and <a href="/wiki/Laza_Kosti%C4%87" title="Laza Kostić">Laza Kostić</a> being the notable representatives, while the second half of the century was marked by <a href="/wiki/Literary_realism" title="Literary realism">Realist</a> writers such as <a href="/wiki/Milovan_Gli%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Milovan Glišić">Milovan Glišić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laza_Lazarevi%C4%87" title="Laza Lazarević">Laza Lazarević</a>, <a href="/wiki/Simo_Matavulj" title="Simo Matavulj">Simo Matavulj</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stevan_Sremac" title="Stevan Sremac">Stevan Sremac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vojislav_Ili%C4%87" title="Vojislav Ilić">Vojislav Ilić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Branislav_Nu%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Branislav Nušić">Branislav Nušić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Radoje_Domanovi%C4%87" title="Radoje Domanović">Radoje Domanović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Borisav_Stankovi%C4%87" title="Borisav Stanković">Borisav Stanković</a>. </p>
      <p>The 20th century was dominated by the prose writers <a href="/wiki/Me%C5%A1a_Selimovi%C4%87" title="Meša Selimović">Meša Selimović</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Death_and_the_Dervish" title="Death and the Dervish">Death and the Dervish</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Milo%C5%A1_Crnjanski" title="Miloš Crnjanski">Miloš Crnjanski</a> (<i>Migrations</i>), <a href="/wiki/Isidora_Sekuli%C4%87" title="Isidora Sekulić">Isidora Sekulić</a> (<i>The Cronicle of a Small Town Cemetery</i>), <a href="/wiki/Branko_%C4%86opi%C4%87" title="Branko Ćopić">Branko Ćopić</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Eagles_Fly_Early_(novel)" title="Eagles Fly Early (novel)">Eagles Fly Early</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Borislav_Peki%C4%87" title="Borislav Pekić">Borislav Pekić</a> (<i>The Time of Miracles</i>), <a href="/wiki/Danilo_Ki%C5%A1" title="Danilo Kiš">Danilo Kiš</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Encyclopedia_of_the_Dead" title="The Encyclopedia of the Dead">The Encyclopedia of the Dead</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Dobrica_%C4%86osi%C4%87" title="Dobrica Ćosić">Dobrica Ćosić</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/Koreni_(novel)" title="Koreni (novel)">The Roots</a></i>), <a href="/wiki/Aleksandar_Ti%C5%A1ma" title="Aleksandar Tišma">Aleksandar Tišma</a> (<i>The Use of Man</i>), <a href="/wiki/Milorad_Pavi%C4%87" title="Milorad Pavić">Milorad Pavić</a> and others.<sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[391]</a></sup> Notable poets include <a href="/wiki/Milan_Raki%C4%87" title="Milan Rakić">Milan Rakić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jovan_Du%C4%8Di%C4%87" title="Jovan Dučić">Jovan Dučić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vladislav_Petkovi%C4%87_Dis" title="Vladislav Petković Dis">Vladislav Petković Dis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rastko_Petrovi%C4%87" title="Rastko Petrović">Rastko Petrović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanislav_Vinaver" title="Stanislav Vinaver">Stanislav Vinaver</a>, <a href="/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Mati%C4%87" title="Dušan Matić">Dušan Matić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Branko_Miljkovi%C4%87" title="Branko Miljković">Branko Miljković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vasko_Popa" title="Vasko Popa">Vasko Popa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Oskar_Davi%C4%8Do" title="Oskar Davičo">Oskar Davičo</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miodrag_Pavlovi%C4%87" title="Miodrag Pavlović">Miodrag Pavlović</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Stevan_Rai%C4%8Dkovi%C4%87" title="Stevan Raičković">Stevan Raičković</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[392]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Pavić is widely acclaimed Serbian author of the beginning of the 21st century, most notably for his <i><a href="/wiki/Dictionary_of_the_Khazars" title="Dictionary of the Khazars">Dictionary of the Khazars</a></i>, which has been translated into 38 languages.<sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[393]</a></sup> Notable contemporary authors include <a href="/wiki/David_Albahari" title="David Albahari">David Albahari</a>, <a href="/wiki/Svetislav_Basara" title="Svetislav Basara">Svetislav Basara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goran_Petrovi%C4%87" title="Goran Petrović">Goran Petrović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gordana_Kui%C4%87" title="Gordana Kuić">Gordana Kuić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vuk_Dra%C5%A1kovi%C4%87" title="Vuk Drašković">Vuk Drašković</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vladislav_Bajac" title="Vladislav Bajac">Vladislav Bajac</a>. <a href="/wiki/Serbian_comics" title="Serbian comics">Serbian comics</a> emerged in the 1930s and the medium remains popular today. </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Ivo_Andri%C4%87" title="Ivo Andrić">Ivo Andrić</a> (<i><a href="/wiki/The_Bridge_on_the_Drina" title="The Bridge on the Drina">The Bridge on the Drina</a></i>) is possibly the best-known Serbian author;<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESnel2004209_396-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESnel2004209-396">[394]</a></sup> he was awarded the <a href="/wiki/Nobel_Prize_in_Literature" title="Nobel Prize in Literature">Nobel Prize in Literature</a> in 1961. The most beloved face of Serbian literature was <a href="/wiki/Desanka_Maksimovi%C4%87" title="Desanka Maksimović">Desanka Maksimović</a>, who for seven decades remained <i>the leading lady of Yugoslav poetry</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeliso2009110_397-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeliso2009110-397">[395]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVidan2016494_398-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVidan2016494-398">[396]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawkesworth200015_399-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHawkesworth200015-399">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHawkesworth2000203_400-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHawkesworth2000203-400">[398]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJuraga2002204_401-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJuraga2002204-401">[399]</a></sup> She is honoured with statues, postage stamps, and the names of streets across Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELucić2007_402-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELucić2007-402">[400]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEŠuberKaramanić2012327–328_403-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEŠuberKaramanić2012327–328-403">[401]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHaag2002124_404-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHaag2002124-404">[402]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are 551 public libraries biggest of which are: <a href="/wiki/National_Library_of_Serbia" title="National Library of Serbia">National Library of Serbia</a> in Belgrade with funds of about 6 million items,<sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[403]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Matica_Srpska" class="mw-redirect" title="Matica Srpska">Matica Srpska</a> (the oldest <a href="/wiki/Matica" title="Matica">matica</a> and Serbian cultural institution, founded in 1826) in Novi Sad with nearly 3.5 million volumes.<sup id="cite_ref-406" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-406">[404]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[405]</a></sup> In 2010, there were 10,989 books and brochures published.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup> The book publishing market is dominated by several major publishers such as Laguna and Vulkan (both of which operate their own bookstore chains) and the industry's centrepiece event, annual <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Book_Fair" title="Belgrade Book Fair">Belgrade Book Fair</a>, is the most visited cultural event in Serbia with 158,128 visitors in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-408" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-408">[406]</a></sup> The highlight of the literary scene is awarding of <a href="/wiki/NIN_Prize" class="mw-redirect" title="NIN Prize">NIN Prize</a>, given every January since 1954 for the best newly published novel in Serbian language.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[407]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[408]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Music">Music</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Music_of_Serbia" title="Music of Serbia">Music of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg/170px-Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="266" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg/255px-Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6d/Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg/340px-Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg 2x" data-file-width="344" data-file-height="539"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Filip_Visnjic_guslar.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/Filip_Vi%C5%A1nji%C4%87" title="Filip Višnjić">Filip Višnjić</a> sings to the <a href="/wiki/Gusle" title="Gusle">gusle</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Sreten_Stojanovi%C4%87" title="Sreten Stojanović">Sreten Stojanović</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Composer and <a href="/wiki/Musicology" title="Musicology">musicologist</a> <a href="/wiki/Stevan_Stojanovi%C4%87_Mokranjac" class="mw-redirect" title="Stevan Stojanović Mokranjac">Stevan Stojanović Mokranjac</a> is considered the founder of modern Serbian music.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[409]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-412" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-412">[410]</a></sup> The Serbian composers of the first generation <a href="/wiki/Petar_Konjovi%C4%87" title="Petar Konjović">Petar Konjović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stevan_Hristi%C4%87" title="Stevan Hristić">Stevan Hristić</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Miloje_Milojevi%C4%87" title="Miloje Milojević">Miloje Milojević</a> maintained the national expression and modernised the romanticism into the direction of impressionism.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[411]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[412]</a></sup> Other famous <a href="/wiki/European_classical_music" class="mw-redirect" title="European classical music">classical</a> Serbian composers include <a href="/wiki/Isidor_Baji%C4%87" title="Isidor Bajić">Isidor Bajić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stanislav_Bini%C4%8Dki" title="Stanislav Binički">Stanislav Binički</a> and <a href="/wiki/Josif_Marinkovi%C4%87" title="Josif Marinković">Josif Marinković</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-415" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-415">[413]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[414]</a></sup> There are three opera houses in Serbia: <a href="/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Belgrade" title="National Theatre in Belgrade">Opera of the National Theatre</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madlenianum_Opera_and_Theatre" title="Madlenianum Opera and Theatre">Madlenianum Opera</a>, both in Belgrade, and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_National_Theatre" title="Serbian National Theatre">Opera of the Serbian National Theatre</a> in Novi Sad. Four symphonic orchestra operate in the country: <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Philharmonic_Orchestra" title="Belgrade Philharmonic Orchestra">Belgrade Philharmonic Orchestra</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ni%C5%A1_Symphony_Orchestra" title="Niš Symphony Orchestra">Niš Symphony Orchestra</a>, Novi Sad Philharmonic Orchestra and Symphonic Orchestra of Radio Television of Serbia. The Choir of Radio Television of Serbia is a leading vocal ensemble in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[415]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Belgrade_Music_Festival" title="Belgrade Music Festival">BEMUS</a> is one of the most prominent classical music festivals in the Southeastern Europe. </p>
      <p>Traditional Serbian music includes various kinds of <a href="/wiki/Bagpipes" title="Bagpipes">bagpipes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Flutes" class="mw-redirect" title="Flutes">flutes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Blowing_horn" title="Blowing horn">horns</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trumpet" title="Trumpet">trumpets</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lutes" class="mw-redirect" title="Lutes">lutes</a>, <a href="/wiki/Psalteries" class="mw-redirect" title="Psalteries">psalteries</a>, drums and cymbals. The <i><a href="/wiki/Kolo_(dance)" title="Kolo (dance)">kolo</a></i> is the traditional collective folk dance, which has <a href="/wiki/Serbian_dances" title="Serbian dances">a number of varieties</a> throughout the regions. The most popular are those from <a href="/wiki/U%C5%BEice" title="Užice">Užice</a> and Morava region. <a href="/wiki/Serbian_epic_poetry" title="Serbian epic poetry">Sung epic poetry</a> has been an integral part of Serbian and Balkan music for centuries. In the highlands of Serbia these long poems are typically accompanied on a one-string fiddle called the <i><a href="/wiki/Gusle" title="Gusle">gusle</a></i>, and concern themselves with themes from history and mythology. There are records of <i>gusle</i> being played at the court of the 13th-century King <a href="/wiki/Stefan_Nemanji%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Stefan Nemanjić">Stefan Nemanjić</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-418" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-418">[416]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Serbian_pop" title="Serbian pop">Pop music</a> has mainstream popularity. <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDeljko_Joksimovi%C4%87" title="Željko Joksimović">Željko Joksimović</a> won second place at the <a href="/wiki/2004_Eurovision_Song_Contest" class="mw-redirect" title="2004 Eurovision Song Contest">2004 Eurovision Song Contest</a> and <a href="/wiki/Marija_%C5%A0erifovi%C4%87" title="Marija Šerifović">Marija Šerifović</a> managed to win the <a href="/wiki/2007_Eurovision_Song_Contest" class="mw-redirect" title="2007 Eurovision Song Contest">2007 Eurovision Song Contest</a> with the song "<a href="/wiki/Molitva" title="Molitva">Molitva</a>", and Serbia was the host of the <a href="/wiki/2008_Eurovision_Song_Contest" class="mw-redirect" title="2008 Eurovision Song Contest">2008 edition</a> of the contest. Most popular pop singers include likes of <a href="/wiki/%C4%90or%C4%91e_Bala%C5%A1evi%C4%87" title="Đorđe Balašević">Đorđe Balašević</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zdravko_%C4%8Coli%C4%87" title="Zdravko Čolić">Zdravko Čolić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vlado_Georgiev" title="Vlado Georgiev">Vlado Georgiev</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aleksandra_Radovi%C4%87" title="Aleksandra Radović">Aleksandra Radović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jelena_Toma%C5%A1evi%C4%87" title="Jelena Tomašević">Jelena Tomašević</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nata%C5%A1a_Bekvalac" title="Nataša Bekvalac">Nataša Bekvalac</a> among others. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg/220px-Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg/330px-Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg/440px-Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2048" data-file-height="1367"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Fireworks_at_EXIT_Festival_2018.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Exit_(festival)" title="Exit (festival)">Exit Festival</a> in <a href="/wiki/Novi_Sad" title="Novi Sad">Novi Sad</a>, proclaimed as <i>the Best Major European festival</i> at the EU Festival Awards<sup id="cite_ref-419" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-419">[417]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Serbian_rock" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian rock">Serbian rock</a> which was during the 1960s, 1970s and 1980s part of <a href="/wiki/SFR_Yugoslav_pop_and_rock_scene" class="mw-redirect" title="SFR Yugoslav pop and rock scene">former Yugoslav rock scene</a>, used to be well developed and covered in the media. During the 1990s and 2000s popularity of <a href="/wiki/Rock_music" title="Rock music">rock music</a> declined in Serbia,<sup id="cite_ref-420" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-420">[418]</a></sup> and although several major mainstream acts managed to sustain their popularity, an <a href="/wiki/Underground_music" title="Underground music">underground</a> and <a href="/wiki/Independent_music" title="Independent music">independent music</a> scene developed.<sup id="cite_ref-421" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-421">[419]</a></sup> The 2000s saw a revival of the mainstream scene and the appearance of a large number of notable acts. Notable Serbian rock acts include <a href="/wiki/Riblja_%C4%8Corba" title="Riblja Čorba">Riblja Čorba</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bajaga_i_Instruktori" title="Bajaga i Instruktori">Bajaga i Instruktori</a>, <a href="/wiki/Disciplina_Ki%C4%8Dme" class="mw-redirect" title="Disciplina Kičme">Disciplina Kičme</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ekatarina_Velika" title="Ekatarina Velika">Ekatarina Velika</a>, <a href="/wiki/Partibrejkers" title="Partibrejkers">Partibrejkers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Elektri%C4%8Dni_Orgazam" title="Električni Orgazam">Električni Orgazam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Van_Gogh_(band)" title="Van Gogh (band)">Van Gogh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kerber" title="Kerber">Kerber</a>, <a href="/wiki/Neverne_Bebe" title="Neverne Bebe">Neverne Bebe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ritam_Nereda" title="Ritam Nereda">Ritam Nereda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rambo_Amadeus" title="Rambo Amadeus">Rambo Amadeus</a>, <a href="/wiki/SARS_(band)" title="SARS (band)">S.A.R.S.</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smak" title="Smak">Smak</a>, <a href="/wiki/YU_Grupa" title="YU Grupa">YU Grupa</a> and others. </p>
      <p>Folk music in its original form has been a prominent music style since <a href="/wiki/World_War_One" class="mw-redirect" title="World War One">World War One</a> following the early success of <a href="/wiki/Sofka_Nikoli%C4%87" title="Sofka Nikolić">Sofka Nikolić</a>. The music has been further promoted by Danica Obrenić, Anđelija Milić, <a href="/wiki/Nada_Mamula" title="Nada Mamula">Nada Mamula</a>, and even later, during 60s and 70s, with stars like <a href="/wiki/Silvana_Armenuli%C4%87" title="Silvana Armenulić">Silvana Armenulić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Toma_Zdravkovi%C4%87" title="Toma Zdravković">Toma Zdravković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Lepa_Luki%C4%87" title="Lepa Lukić">Lepa Lukić</a>, Vasilija Radojčić, Vida Pavlović and Gordana Stojićević. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg/220px-ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg/330px-ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg/440px-ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1500" data-file-height="1000"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:ESC_2007_Serbia_-_Marija_Serifovic_-_Molitva.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Serbia won the <a href="/wiki/Eurovision_Song_Contest_2007" title="Eurovision Song Contest 2007">Eurovision Song Contest 2007</a> and became the first debuting country to win Eurovision<sup id="cite_ref-422" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-422">[420]</a></sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p><a href="/wiki/Turbo-folk" title="Turbo-folk">Turbo-folk</a> music is subgenre that has developed in Serbia in the late 1980s and the beginning of the 1990s<sup id="cite_ref-423" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-423">[421]</a></sup> and has since enjoyed an immense popularity<sup id="cite_ref-424" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-424">[422]</a></sup> through acts of <a href="/wiki/Dragana_Mirkovi%C4%87" title="Dragana Mirković">Dragana Mirković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Zorica_Brunclik" title="Zorica Brunclik">Zorica Brunclik</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0aban_%C5%A0auli%C4%87" title="Šaban Šaulić">Šaban Šaulić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ana_Bekuta" title="Ana Bekuta">Ana Bekuta</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sinan_Saki%C4%87" title="Sinan Sakić">Sinan Sakić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vesna_Zmijanac" title="Vesna Zmijanac">Vesna Zmijanac</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mile_Kiti%C4%87" title="Mile Kitić">Mile Kitić</a>, Snežana Đurišić, <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0emsa_Suljakovi%C4%87" title="Šemsa Suljaković">Šemsa Suljaković</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Nada_Top%C4%8Dagi%C4%87" title="Nada Topčagić">Nada Topčagić</a>. It is a blend of <a href="/wiki/Folk_music" title="Folk music">folk music</a> with <a href="/wiki/Pop_music" title="Pop music">pop</a> and/or <a href="/wiki/Dance_music" title="Dance music">dance</a> elements and can be seen as a result of the urbanisation of folk music. In recent period turbo-folk featured even more pop music elements, and some of the performers were labeled as pop-folk. The most famous among them are <a href="/wiki/Svetlana_Ra%C5%BEnatovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Svetlana Ražnatović">Ceca</a> (often considered to be the biggest music star of Serbia<sup id="cite_ref-425" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-425">[423]</a></sup>), <a href="/wiki/Jelena_Karleu%C5%A1a" title="Jelena Karleuša">Jelena Karleuša</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-426" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-426">[424]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aca_Lukas" title="Aca Lukas">Aca Lukas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seka_Aleksi%C4%87" title="Seka Aleksić">Seka Aleksić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dara_Bubamara" title="Dara Bubamara">Dara Bubamara</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indira_Radi%C4%87" title="Indira Radić">Indira Radić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sa%C5%A1a_Mati%C4%87" title="Saša Matić">Saša Matić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Viki_Miljkovi%C4%87" title="Viki Miljković">Viki Miljković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Stoja" title="Stoja">Stoja</a> and <a href="/wiki/Lepa_Brena" title="Lepa Brena">Lepa Brena</a>, arguably the most prominent performer of former <a href="/wiki/Yugoslavia" title="Yugoslavia">Yugoslavia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-427" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-427">[425]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Balkan_Brass_Band" class="mw-redirect" title="Balkan Brass Band">Balkan Brass</a>, or <i>truba</i> ("trumpet") is a popular genre, especially in Central and Southern Serbia where Balkan Brass originated. The music has its tradition from the <a href="/wiki/First_Serbian_Uprising" title="First Serbian Uprising">First Serbian Uprising</a>. The trumpet was used as a military instrument to wake and gather soldiers and announce battles, the trumpet took on the role of entertainment during downtime, as soldiers used it to transpose popular folk songs. When the war ended and the soldiers returned to the rural life, the music entered civilian life and eventually became a music style, accompanying births, baptisms, weddings, and funerals. There are two main varieties of this genre, one from Western Serbia and the other from Southern Serbia, with brass musician <a href="/wiki/Boban_Markovi%C4%87" title="Boban Marković">Boban Marković</a> being one of the most respected names in the world of modern brass band bandleaders.<sup id="cite_ref-428" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-428">[426]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Most popular music festival are <a href="/wiki/Gu%C4%8Da_Trumpet_Festival" title="Guča Trumpet Festival">Guča Trumpet Festival</a> with over 300,000 annual visitors and <a href="/wiki/Exit_(festival)" title="Exit (festival)">EXIT</a> in Novi Sad (won the Best Major Festival award at the <a href="/wiki/European_Festivals_Awards" class="mw-redirect" title="European Festivals Awards">European Festivals Awards</a> for 2013 and 2017.) with 200,000 visitors in 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-429" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-429">[427]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-430" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-430">[428]</a></sup> Other festivals include <a href="/wiki/Ni%C5%A1ville" title="Nišville">Nišville Jazz Festival</a> in Niš and <a href="/wiki/Gitarijada" title="Gitarijada">Gitarijada</a> rock festival in Zaječar. </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Theatre_and_cinema">Theatre and cinema</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Cinema_of_Serbia" title="Cinema of Serbia">Cinema of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia has a well-established theatrical tradition with <a href="/wiki/Joakim_Vuji%C4%87" title="Joakim Vujić">Joakim Vujić</a> considered the founder of modern Serbian theatre.<sup id="cite_ref-Joakim_431-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Joakim-431">[429]</a></sup> Serbia has 38 professional theatres and 11 theatres for children,<sup id="cite_ref-432" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-432">[430]</a></sup> the most important of which are <a href="/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Belgrade" title="National Theatre in Belgrade">National Theatre in Belgrade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Serbian_National_Theatre" title="Serbian National Theatre">Serbian National Theatre</a> in Novi Sad, <a href="/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Subotica" title="National Theatre in Subotica">National Theatre in Subotica</a>, <a href="/wiki/National_Theatre_in_Ni%C5%A1" title="National Theatre in Niš">National Theatre in Niš</a> and <a href="/wiki/Knja%C5%BEevsko-srpski_teatar" class="mw-redirect" title="Knjaževsko-srpski teatar">Knjaževsko-srpski teatar</a> in Kragujevac (the oldest theatre in Serbia, established in 1835). The <a href="/wiki/Bitef" class="mw-redirect" title="Bitef">Belgrade International Theatre Festival – BITEF</a>, founded in 1967, is one of the oldest theatre festivals in the world, and it has become one of the five biggest European festivals.<sup id="cite_ref-433" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-433">[431]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-434" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-434">[432]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Sterijino_pozorje" title="Sterijino pozorje">Sterijino pozorje</a> is, on the other hand, festival showcasing national drama plays. The most important Serbian playwrighters were <a href="/wiki/Jovan_Sterija_Popovi%C4%87" title="Jovan Sterija Popović">Jovan Sterija Popović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Branislav_Nu%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Branislav Nušić">Branislav Nušić</a>, while recent renowned names are <a href="/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Kova%C4%8Devi%C4%87" title="Dušan Kovačević">Dušan Kovačević</a> and <a href="/wiki/Biljana_Srbljanovi%C4%87" title="Biljana Srbljanović">Biljana Srbljanović</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-435" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-435">[433]</a></sup> </p> 
      <link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r978413945/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">
      <div class="thumb tmulti tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px">
        <div class="trow">
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:139px;max-width:139px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:202px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Emir_kusturica_72_9643.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Emir_kusturica_72_9643.jpg/137px-Emir_kusturica_72_9643.jpg" decoding="async" width="137" height="202" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Emir_kusturica_72_9643.jpg/206px-Emir_kusturica_72_9643.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Emir_kusturica_72_9643.jpg/274px-Emir_kusturica_72_9643.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1766" data-file-height="2610"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
         <div class="tsingle" style="width:149px;max-width:149px">
          <div class="thumbimage" style="height:202px;overflow:hidden">
           <a href="/wiki/File:Zzilnik_2008jul.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Zzilnik_2008jul.jpg/147px-Zzilnik_2008jul.jpg" decoding="async" width="147" height="203" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d6/Zzilnik_2008jul.jpg 1.5x" data-file-width="200" data-file-height="276"></a>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="trow" style="display:flex">
         <div class="thumbcaption">
          <b>Left:</b> <a href="/wiki/Emir_Kusturica" title="Emir Kusturica">Emir Kusturica</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Palme_d%27Or" title="Palme d'Or">Palme d'Or</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> in 1985 and 1995, one of only eight filmmakers to win the award twice
          <br><b>Right:</b> <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDelimir_%C5%BDilnik" title="Želimir Žilnik">Želimir Žilnik</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Golden_Bear" title="Golden Bear">Golden Bear</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_International_Film_Festival" title="Berlin International Film Festival">Berlin International Film Festival</a> in 1969
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The foundation of <a href="/wiki/Serbian_cinema" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian cinema">Serbian cinema</a> dates back to 1896 with the release of the oldest movie in the Balkans, <i><a href="/wiki/The_Life_and_Deeds_of_the_Immortal_Vo%C5%BEd_Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e" class="mw-redirect" title="The Life and Deeds of the Immortal Vožd Karađorđe">The Life and Deeds of the Immortal Vožd Karađorđe</a></i>, a biopic about Serbian revolutionary leader, <a href="/wiki/Kara%C4%91or%C4%91e" title="Karađorđe">Karađorđe</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-436" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-436">[434]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-437" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-437">[435]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbian cinema is one of the dynamic smaller European cinematographies. Serbia's film industry is heavily subsidised by the government, mainly through grants approved by the Film Centre of Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-438" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-438">[436]</a></sup> As of 2019, there were 26 feature films produced in Serbia, of which 14 were domestic films.<sup id="cite_ref-439" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-439">[437]</a></sup> There are 23 operating cinemas in the country, of which 13 are <a href="/wiki/Multiplex_(movie_theater)" title="Multiplex (movie theater)">multiplexes</a> (all but two belonging to either <a href="/wiki/Cineplexx_Cinemas" title="Cineplexx Cinemas">Cineplexx</a> or <a href="/wiki/CineStar" title="CineStar">CineStar</a> chains), with total attendance reaching 4.8 million and comparatively high percentage of 20% of total sold tickets for domestic films.<sup id="cite_ref-440" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-440">[438]</a></sup> Modern <a href="/wiki/Pink_International_Company" title="Pink International Company">PFI Studios</a> located in <a href="/wiki/%C5%A0imanovci" title="Šimanovci">Šimanovci</a> is nowadays Serbia's only major film studio complex; it consists of 9 sound stages and attracts mainly international productions, primarily American and West European.<sup id="cite_ref-441" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-441">[439]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Yugoslav_Film_Archive" title="Yugoslav Film Archive">Yugoslav Film Archive</a> used to be former Yugoslavia's and now is Serbia national film archive – with over 100 thousand film prints, it is among five largest film archives in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-442" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-442">[440]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-443" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-443">[441]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Famous Serbian filmmaker <a href="/wiki/Emir_Kusturica" title="Emir Kusturica">Emir Kusturica</a> won two <a href="/wiki/Golden_Palm" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Palm">Golden Palms</a> for Best Feature Film at the <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a>, for <i><a href="/wiki/When_Father_Was_Away_on_Business" title="When Father Was Away on Business">When Father Was Away on Business</a></i> in 1985 and then again for <i><a href="/wiki/Underground_(1995_film)" title="Underground (1995 film)">Underground</a></i> in 1995; he has also won a <a href="/wiki/Jury_Grand_Prix" class="mw-redirect" title="Jury Grand Prix">Silver Bear</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Berlin_Film_Festival" class="mw-redirect" title="Berlin Film Festival">Berlin Film Festival</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/Arizona_Dream" title="Arizona Dream">Arizona Dream</a></i> and a <a href="/wiki/Silver_Lion" title="Silver Lion">Silver Lion</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Venice_Film_Festival" title="Venice Film Festival">Venice Film Festival</a> for <i><a href="/wiki/Black_Cat,_White_Cat" title="Black Cat, White Cat">Black Cat, White Cat</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-444" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-444">[442]</a></sup> Other renowned directors include <a href="/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Makavejev" title="Dušan Makavejev">Dušan Makavejev</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDelimir_%C5%BDilnik" title="Želimir Žilnik">Želimir Žilnik</a> (<a href="/wiki/Golden_Berlin_Bear" class="mw-redirect" title="Golden Berlin Bear">Golden Berlin Bear</a> winner), <a href="/wiki/Aleksandar_Petrovi%C4%87_(film_director)" title="Aleksandar Petrović (film director)">Aleksandar Petrović</a>, <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDivojin_Pavlovi%C4%87" title="Živojin Pavlović">Živojin Pavlović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goran_Paskaljevi%C4%87" title="Goran Paskaljević">Goran Paskaljević</a>, <a href="/wiki/Goran_Markovi%C4%87_(film_director)" class="mw-redirect" title="Goran Marković (film director)">Goran Marković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sr%C4%91an_Dragojevi%C4%87" title="Srđan Dragojević">Srđan Dragojević</a>, <a href="/wiki/Srdan_Golubovi%C4%87" title="Srdan Golubović">Srdan Golubović</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mila_Turajli%C4%87" title="Mila Turajlić">Mila Turajlić</a> among others. Serbian-American screenwriter <a href="/wiki/Steve_Tesich" title="Steve Tesich">Steve Tesich</a> won the <a href="/wiki/Academy_Award" class="mw-redirect" title="Academy Award">Academy Award</a> for <a href="/wiki/Best_Original_Screenplay" class="mw-redirect" title="Best Original Screenplay">Best Original Screenplay</a> in 1979 for the movie <a href="/wiki/Breaking_Away" title="Breaking Away">Breaking Away</a>. </p>
      <p>Prominent movie stars in Serbia have left celebrated heritage in cinematography of Yugoslavia as well. Notable mentions are <a href="/wiki/Zoran_Radmilovi%C4%87" title="Zoran Radmilović">Zoran Radmilović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pavle_Vuisi%C4%87" title="Pavle Vuisić">Pavle Vuisić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ljubi%C5%A1a_Samard%C5%BEi%C4%87" title="Ljubiša Samardžić">Ljubiša Samardžić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olivera_Markovi%C4%87" title="Olivera Marković">Olivera Marković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mija_Aleksi%C4%87" title="Mija Aleksić">Mija Aleksić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Miodrag_Petrovi%C4%87_%C4%8Ckalja" title="Miodrag Petrović Čkalja">Miodrag Petrović Čkalja</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ru%C5%BEica_Soki%C4%87" title="Ružica Sokić">Ružica Sokić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Velimir_Bata_%C5%BDivojinovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Velimir Bata Živojinović">Velimir Bata Živojinović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Danilo_Bata_Stojkovi%C4%87" class="mw-redirect" title="Danilo Bata Stojković">Danilo Bata Stojković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Seka_Sabli%C4%87" title="Seka Sablić">Seka Sablić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Olivera_Katarina" title="Olivera Katarina">Olivera Katarina</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dragan_Nikoli%C4%87" title="Dragan Nikolić">Dragan Nikolić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mira_Stupica" title="Mira Stupica">Mira Stupica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Simi%C4%87_(actor)" title="Nikola Simić (actor)">Nikola Simić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bora_Todorovi%C4%87" title="Bora Todorović">Bora Todorović</a> and others. <a href="/wiki/Milena_Dravi%C4%87" title="Milena Dravić">Milena Dravić</a> was one of the most celebrated actress in Serbian cinematography winning <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival_Award_for_Best_Actress" title="Cannes Film Festival Award for Best Actress">Best Actress Award</a> on <a href="/wiki/Cannes_Film_Festival" title="Cannes Film Festival">Cannes Film Festival</a> in 1980.<sup id="cite_ref-445" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-445">[443]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-446" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-446">[444]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Media">Media</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Media_of_Serbia" class="mw-redirect" title="Media of Serbia">Media of Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>The freedom of the press and the freedom of speech are guaranteed by the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_Serbia" title="Constitution of Serbia">constitution of Serbia</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-447" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-447">[445]</a></sup> Serbia is ranked 90th out of 180 countries in the 2019 <a href="/wiki/Press_Freedom_Index" title="Press Freedom Index">Press Freedom Index</a> report compiled by <a href="/wiki/Reporters_Without_Borders" title="Reporters Without Borders">Reporters Without Borders</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-448" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-448">[446]</a></sup> Report noted that media outlets and journalists continue to face partisan and government pressure over editorial policies. Also, the media are now more heavily dependent on advertising contracts and government subsidies to survive financially.<sup id="cite_ref-449" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-449">[447]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-450" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-450">[448]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-451" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-451">[449]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serpol7nd.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ac/Serpol7nd.jpg/170px-Serpol7nd.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="250" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/ac/Serpol7nd.jpg/255px-Serpol7nd.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/a/ac/Serpol7nd.jpg 2x" data-file-width="260" data-file-height="383"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serpol7nd.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><i><a href="/wiki/Politika" title="Politika">Politika</a></i>, country's papers of record and the oldest daily newspaper still in circulation in the <a href="/wiki/Balkans" title="Balkans">Balkans</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2020)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>According to <a href="/wiki/European_Broadcasting_Union" title="European Broadcasting Union">EBU</a> research in 2018, Serbs on average watch five and a half hours of television per day, making it the second highest average in Europe.<sup id="cite_ref-452" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-452">[450]</a></sup> There are seven nationwide <a href="/wiki/Free-to-air" title="Free-to-air">free-to-air</a> television channels, with public broadcaster <a href="/wiki/Radio_Television_of_Serbia" title="Radio Television of Serbia">Radio Television of Serbia (RTS)</a> operating three (<a href="/wiki/RTS1" class="mw-redirect" title="RTS1">RTS1</a>, <a href="/wiki/RTS2" class="mw-redirect" title="RTS2">RTS2</a> and RTS3) and private broadcasters operating four (<a href="/wiki/RTV_Pink" class="mw-redirect" title="RTV Pink">Pink</a>, <a href="/wiki/Prva_Srpska_Televizija" title="Prva Srpska Televizija">Prva</a>, <a href="/wiki/Happy_TV" class="mw-redirect" title="Happy TV">Happy</a>, and <a href="/wiki/B92" title="B92">O2</a>). In 2019, preferred usage of these channels were as follows: 19.3% for RTS1, 17.6% for Pink, 10.5% for Prva, 6.9% for Happy, 4.1% for O2, and 1.6% for RTS2.<sup id="cite_ref-453" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-453">[451]</a></sup> There are 28 regional television channels and 74 local television channels.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup> Besides terrestrial channels there are dozens Serbian television channels available only on cable or satellite. </p>
      <p>There are 247 radio stations in Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-pod2.stat.gov.rs_173-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pod2.stat.gov.rs-173">[171]</a></sup> Out of these, six are radio stations with national coverage, including two of public broadcaster <a href="/wiki/Radio_Television_of_Serbia" title="Radio Television of Serbia">Radio Television of Serbia</a> (<a href="/wiki/Radio_Belgrade" title="Radio Belgrade">Radio Belgrade 1</a> and <a href="/wiki/Radio_Belgrade" title="Radio Belgrade">Radio Belgrade 2/Radio Belgrade 3</a>) and four private ones (Radio S1, Radio S2, Play Radio, and Radio Hit FM). Also, there are 34 regional stations and 207 local stations.<sup id="cite_ref-454" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-454">[452]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>There are 305 <a href="/wiki/Newspapers" class="mw-redirect" title="Newspapers">newspapers</a> published in Serbia<sup id="cite_ref-webrzs.stat.gov.rs_455-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-webrzs.stat.gov.rs-455">[453]</a></sup> of which 12 are daily newspapers. Dailies <i><a href="/wiki/Politika" title="Politika">Politika</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Danas_(newspaper)" title="Danas (newspaper)">Danas</a></i> are Serbia's <a href="/wiki/Papers_of_record" class="mw-redirect" title="Papers of record">papers of record</a>, former being the oldest newspaper in the Balkans, founded in 1904.<sup id="cite_ref-456" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-456">[454]</a></sup> Highest circulation newspapers are tabloids <i><a href="/wiki/Ve%C4%8Dernje_Novosti" class="mw-redirect" title="Večernje Novosti">Večernje Novosti</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Blic" title="Blic">Blic</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Kurir" title="Kurir">Kurir</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Informer_(newspaper)" title="Informer (newspaper)">Informer</a></i>, all with more than 100,000 copies sold.<sup id="cite_ref-457" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-457">[455]</a></sup> There are one daily newspaper devoted to sports – <i><a href="/wiki/Sportski_%C5%BEurnal" title="Sportski žurnal">Sportski žurnal</a></i>, one business daily <i>Privredni pregled</i>, two regional newspapers (<i><a href="/wiki/Dnevnik_(Serbia)" class="mw-redirect" title="Dnevnik (Serbia)">Dnevnik</a></i> published in Novi Sad and <i>Narodne novine</i> from Niš), and one minority-language daily (<i><a href="/wiki/Magyar_Szo" class="mw-redirect" title="Magyar Szo">Magyar Szo</a></i> in Hungarian, published in Subotica). </p>
      <p>There are 1,351 <a href="/wiki/Magazines" class="mw-redirect" title="Magazines">magazines</a> published in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-webrzs.stat.gov.rs_455-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-webrzs.stat.gov.rs-455">[453]</a></sup> Those include weekly <a href="/wiki/News_magazine" title="News magazine">news magazines</a> <i><a href="/wiki/NIN_(magazine)" title="NIN (magazine)">NIN</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Vreme" title="Vreme">Vreme</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Nedeljnik" title="Nedeljnik">Nedeljnik</a></i>, popular science magazine of <i><a href="/wiki/Politikin_Zabavnik" title="Politikin Zabavnik">Politikin Zabavnik</a></i>, women's <i><a href="/wiki/Lepota_%26_Zdravlje" title="Lepota &amp; Zdravlje">Lepota &amp; Zdravlje</a></i>, auto magazine <i>SAT revija</i>, IT magazine <i><a href="/wiki/Svet_kompjutera" title="Svet kompjutera">Svet kompjutera</a></i>. In addition, there is a wide selection of Serbian editions of international magazines, such as <i><a href="/wiki/Cosmopolitan_(magazine)" title="Cosmopolitan (magazine)">Cosmopolitan</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Elle_(magazine)" title="Elle (magazine)">Elle</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Men%27s_Health_(magazine)" class="mw-redirect" title="Men's Health (magazine)">Men's Health</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/National_Geographic_(magazine)" class="mw-redirect" title="National Geographic (magazine)">National Geographic</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Le_Monde_diplomatique" title="Le Monde diplomatique">Le Monde diplomatique</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Playboy" title="Playboy">Playboy</a></i>, and <i><a href="/wiki/Hello!" class="mw-redirect" title="Hello!">Hello!</a></i>, among others. </p>
      <p>The main news agencies are <a href="/wiki/Tanjug" title="Tanjug">Tanjug</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beta_News_Agency" title="Beta News Agency">Beta</a> and Fonet. </p>
      <p>As of 2017<sup class="plainlinks noexcerpt noprint asof-tag update" style="display:none;"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Serbia&amp;action=edit">[update]</a></sup>, out of 432 web-portals (mainly on the <a href="/wiki/.rs" title=".rs">.rs</a> domain)<sup id="cite_ref-458" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-458">[456]</a></sup> the most visited are online editions of printed dailies <a href="/wiki/Blic" title="Blic">Blic</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kurir" title="Kurir">Kurir</a>, news web-portal <a href="/wiki/B92" title="B92">B92</a>, and classifieds <a href="/wiki/Kupujemprodajem.com" title="Kupujemprodajem.com">KupujemProdajem</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-459" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-459">[457]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cuisine">Cuisine</span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Serbian_cuisine" title="Serbian cuisine">Serbian cuisine</a>
      </div> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg/220px-Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="166" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg/330px-Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg/440px-Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4581" data-file-height="3448"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serbian_Christmas_meal.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Typical Christmas table in Serbia with roasted <a href="/wiki/Pork" title="Pork">pork</a>, <a href="/wiki/Russian_salad" class="mw-redirect" title="Russian salad">Russian salad</a> and <a href="/wiki/Serbian_wine" title="Serbian wine">wine</a>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbian cuisine is largely heterogeneous in a way characteristic of the Balkans and, especially, the <a href="/wiki/Former_Yugoslavia" class="mw-redirect" title="Former Yugoslavia">former Yugoslavia</a>. It features foods characteristic of lands formerly under <a href="/wiki/Turkish_cuisine" title="Turkish cuisine">Turkish</a> suzerainty as well as cuisine originating from other parts of <a href="/wiki/Central_Europe" title="Central Europe">Central Europe</a> (especially <a href="/wiki/Austrian_cuisine" title="Austrian cuisine">Austria</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hungarian_cuisine" title="Hungarian cuisine">Hungary</a>). Food is very important in Serbian social life, particularly during religious holidays such as <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmas</a>, <a href="/wiki/Easter" title="Easter">Easter</a> and feast days i.e. <a href="/wiki/Slava" title="Slava">slava</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeynink2011330_460-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeynink2011330-460">[458]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Staples of the Serbian diet include bread, meat, fruits, vegetables, and dairy products. Bread is the basis of all Serbian meals, and it plays an important role in Serbian cuisine and can be found in religious rituals. A traditional Serbian welcome is to offer bread and <a href="/wiki/Salt" title="Salt">salt</a> to guests. Meat is widely consumed, as is fish. Serbian specialties include <a href="/wiki/%C4%86evap%C4%8Di%C4%87i" class="mw-redirect" title="Ćevapčići">ćevapčići</a> (caseless sausages made of minced meat, which is always grilled and seasoned), <a href="/wiki/Pljeskavica" title="Pljeskavica">pljeskavica</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarma_(food)" title="Sarma (food)">sarma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kajmak" class="mw-redirect" title="Kajmak">kajmak</a> (a dairy product similar to <a href="/wiki/Clotted_cream" title="Clotted cream">clotted cream</a>), <a href="/wiki/Gibanica" title="Gibanica">gibanica</a> (cheese and kajmak pie), <a href="/wiki/Ajvar" title="Ajvar">ajvar</a> (a roasted red pepper spread), <a href="/wiki/Proja" title="Proja">proja</a> (cornbread), and <a href="/wiki/Ka%C4%8Damak" title="Kačamak">kačamak</a> (corn-flour porridge).<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMeynink2011329–330_461-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMeynink2011329–330-461">[459]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Serbians claim their country as the birthplace of <a href="/wiki/Rakia" title="Rakia">rakia</a> (<i>rakija</i>), a highly alcoholic drink primarily distilled from fruit. Rakia in various forms is found throughout the Balkans, notably in Bulgaria, Croatia, Slovenia, Montenegro, Hungary and Turkey. <a href="/wiki/Slivovitz" title="Slivovitz">Slivovitz</a> (<i>šljivovica</i>), a plum brandy, is a type of rakia which is considered the national drink of Serbia.<sup id="cite_ref-462" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-462">[460]</a></sup> </p>
      <p><a href="/wiki/Serbian_wine" title="Serbian wine">Winemaking traditions in Serbia</a> dates back to Roman times.<sup id="cite_ref-463" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-463">[461]</a></sup> Serbian wines are produced in 22 different geographical regions, with white wine dominating the total amount.<sup id="cite_ref-464" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-464">[462]</a></sup> Besides rakia and beer, wine is a very popular alcoholic beverage in the country.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (January 2021)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Sports">Sports</span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sport_in_Serbia" title="Sport in Serbia">Sport in Serbia</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Sports play an important role in Serbian society, and the country has a strong sporting history. The most popular sports in Serbia are <a href="/wiki/Association_football" title="Association football">football</a>, <a href="/wiki/Basketball" title="Basketball">basketball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tennis" title="Tennis">tennis</a>, <a href="/wiki/Volleyball" title="Volleyball">volleyball</a>, <a href="/wiki/Water_polo" title="Water polo">water polo</a> and <a href="/wiki/Handball" title="Handball">handball</a>. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg/220px-Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="165" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg/330px-Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg/440px-Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2883" data-file-height="2158"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Novak_Djokovic_Queen%27s_Club_2018.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>, considered one of the greatest tennis players of all time
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Professional sports in Serbia are organised by sporting federations and leagues (in case of team sports). One of particularities of Serbian professional sports is existence of many multi-sports clubs (called "sports societies"), biggest and most successful of which are <a href="/wiki/SD_Crvena_Zvezda" title="SD Crvena Zvezda">Red Star</a>, <a href="/wiki/JSD_Partizan" title="JSD Partizan">Partizan</a>, and <a href="/wiki/OSD_Beograd" title="OSD Beograd">Beograd</a> in Belgrade, <a href="/wiki/SD_Vojvodina" title="SD Vojvodina">Vojvodina</a> in Novi Sad, <a href="/wiki/FK_Radni%C4%8Dki_1923" title="FK Radnički 1923">Radnički</a> in Kragujevac, <a href="/wiki/FK_Spartak_Zlatibor_Voda" class="mw-redirect" title="FK Spartak Zlatibor Voda">Spartak</a> in Subotica. </p>
      <p>Football is the most popular sport in Serbia, and the <a href="/wiki/Football_Association_of_Serbia" title="Football Association of Serbia">Football Association of Serbia</a> with 146,845 registered players, is the largest sporting association in the country.<sup id="cite_ref-465" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-465">[463]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/FK_Ba%C4%8Dka_1901" title="FK Bačka 1901">FK Bačka 1901</a> is the oldest football club in Serbia and the former Yugoslavia.<sup id="cite_ref-466" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-466">[464]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dragan_D%C5%BEaji%C4%87" title="Dragan Džajić">Dragan Džajić</a> was officially recognised as "the best Serbian player of all times" by the Football Association of Serbia, and more recently the likes of <a href="/wiki/Nemanja_Vidi%C4%87" title="Nemanja Vidić">Nemanja Vidić</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dejan_Stankovi%C4%87" title="Dejan Stanković">Dejan Stanković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Branislav_Ivanovi%C4%87" title="Branislav Ivanović">Branislav Ivanović</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aleksandar_Kolarov" title="Aleksandar Kolarov">Aleksandar Kolarov</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nemanja_Mati%C4%87" title="Nemanja Matić">Nemanja Matić</a> play for the elite European clubs, developing the nation's reputation as one of the world's biggest exporters of footballers.<sup id="cite_ref-467" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-467">[465]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-468" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-468">[466]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Serbia_national_football_team" title="Serbia national football team">Serbia national football team</a> lacks relative success although it qualified for three of the last four <a href="/wiki/FIFA_World_Cup" title="FIFA World Cup">FIFA World Cups</a>. Serbia national youth football teams have won <a href="/wiki/2013_UEFA_European_Under-19_Championship" title="2013 UEFA European Under-19 Championship">2013 U-19 European Championship</a> and <a href="/wiki/2015_FIFA_U-20_World_Cup" title="2015 FIFA U-20 World Cup">2015 U-20 World Cup</a>. The two main football clubs in Serbia are <a href="/wiki/Red_Star_Belgrade" title="Red Star Belgrade">Red Star</a> (winner of the <a href="/wiki/1990%E2%80%9391_European_Cup" title="1990–91 European Cup">1991 European Cup</a>) and <a href="/wiki/FK_Partizan" title="FK Partizan">Partizan</a> (finalist of the <a href="/wiki/1965%E2%80%9366_European_Cup" title="1965–66 European Cup">1966 European Cup</a>), both from Belgrade. The rivalry between the two clubs is known as the "<a href="/wiki/Eternal_derby_(Serbia)" title="Eternal derby (Serbia)">Eternal Derby</a>", and is often cited as one of the most exciting sports rivalries in the world.<sup id="cite_ref-469" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-469">[467]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_(cropped).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_%28cropped%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="170" height="232" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_%28cropped%29.jpg/255px-Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_%28cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7e/Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_%28cropped%29.jpg/340px-Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_%28cropped%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="948" data-file-height="1291"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Nikola_Jokic_free_throw_(cropped).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div><a href="/wiki/Nikola_Joki%C4%87" title="Nikola Jokić">Nikola Jokić</a>, two-time <a href="/wiki/List_of_NBA_All-Stars" title="List of NBA All-Stars">NBA All-Star</a> and <a href="/wiki/2018%E2%80%9319_NBA_season" title="2018–19 NBA season">2018–19</a> <a href="/wiki/All-NBA_Team" title="All-NBA Team">All-NBA First team</a>. Serbia is one of the countries with the <a href="/wiki/List_of_foreign_NBA_players" title="List of foreign NBA players">largest number of NBA players</a> and with the greatest success in FIBA international competitions.
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Serbia is one of the traditional powerhouses of world basketball,<sup id="cite_ref-470" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-470">[468]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-471" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-471">[469]</a></sup> as <a href="/wiki/Serbian_national_basketball_team" class="mw-redirect" title="Serbian national basketball team">Serbia men's national basketball team</a> have won two <a href="/wiki/FIBA_World_Championship" class="mw-redirect" title="FIBA World Championship">World Championships</a> (in 1998 and 2002), three <a href="/wiki/EuroBasket" title="EuroBasket">European Championships</a> (1995, 1997, and 2001) and two Olympic silver medals (in <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_1996_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the 1996 Summer Olympics">1996</a> and <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics" title="Basketball at the 2016 Summer Olympics">2016</a>) as well. <a href="/wiki/Serbia_women%27s_national_basketball_team" title="Serbia women's national basketball team">The women's national basketball team</a> won the European Championship in 2015 and <a href="/wiki/Basketball_at_the_2016_Summer_Olympics_-_Women%27s_tournament" class="mw-redirect" title="Basketball at the 2016 Summer Olympics - Women's tournament">Olympic bronze medal</a> in 2016. A total of 31 Serbian players have played in the NBA in last three decades, including <a href="/wiki/Nikola_Joki%C4%87" title="Nikola Jokić">Nikola Jokić</a> (2019 <a href="/wiki/All-NBA_Team" title="All-NBA Team">All-NBA First team</a> and two-time <a href="/wiki/List_of_NBA_All-Stars" title="List of NBA All-Stars">NBA All-Star</a>), <a href="/wiki/Peja_Stojakovi%C4%87" title="Peja Stojaković">Predrag "Peja" Stojaković</a> (2011 NBA champion and three-time <a href="/wiki/List_of_NBA_All-Stars" title="List of NBA All-Stars">NBA All-Star</a>), and <a href="/wiki/Vlade_Divac" title="Vlade Divac">Vlade Divac</a> (2001 NBA All-Star and <a href="/wiki/Naismith_Memorial_Basketball_Hall_of_Fame" title="Naismith Memorial Basketball Hall of Fame">Basketball Hall of Famer</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-472" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-472">[470]</a></sup> The renowned "Serbian coaching school" produced many of the most successful European basketball coaches of all times, such as <a href="/wiki/%C5%BDeljko_Obradovi%C4%87" title="Željko Obradović">Željko Obradović</a> (who won a record 9 Euroleague titles as a coach), <a href="/wiki/Du%C5%A1an_Ivkovi%C4%87" title="Dušan Ivković">Dušan Ivković</a>, <a href="/wiki/Svetislav_Pe%C5%A1i%C4%87" title="Svetislav Pešić">Svetislav Pešić</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Igor_Koko%C5%A1kov" title="Igor Kokoškov">Igor Kokoškov</a> (the first coach born and raised outside of North America to be hired as a head coach in the NBA). <a href="/wiki/KK_Partizan" title="KK Partizan">KK Partizan</a> basketball club was the <a href="/wiki/Euroleague_Basketball" title="Euroleague Basketball">1992 European champion</a>. </p>
      <p>The <a href="/wiki/Serbia_men%27s_national_water_polo_team" title="Serbia men's national water polo team">Serbia men's national water polo team</a> is the one of the most successful national teams, having won Olympic gold medal in 2016, three <a href="/wiki/Water_polo_at_the_World_Aquatics_Championships" title="Water polo at the World Aquatics Championships">World Championships</a> (2005, 2009 and 2015), and seven <a href="/wiki/European_Water_Polo_Championship" title="European Water Polo Championship">European Championships</a> in 2001, 2003, 2006, 2012, 2014, 2016 and 2018, respectively.<sup id="cite_ref-473" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-473">[471]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/VK_Partizan" title="VK Partizan">VK Partizan</a> has won a joint-record seven <a href="/wiki/LEN_Euroleague" class="mw-redirect" title="LEN Euroleague">European champion</a> titles. </p>
